business.start.para: The SPEAKER (Hon. David Hawker) took the chair at 9.00 am and read prayers.

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Pyne, and read a first time.

talker.name: Pyne, Chris, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing
talker.name: Mr PYNE

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: This bill makes a number of amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989—the act—to better secure compliance with Australia’s high standards for therapeutic goods.

These amendments follow on amendments to the act made in May 2003 in the wake of a succession of serious safety and quality breaches by a major Australian manufacturer of therapeutic goods—Pan Pharmaceuticals Ltd—which necessitated unprecedented regulatory action to protect the Australian public from medicines manufactured in a way that posed a threat to public health and safety. Since that time evidence from further monitoring and auditing by Australia’s therapeutic goods regulator, the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), has shown that further amendments to the act are required to more effectively address continuing failure by other manufacturers to adequately comply with regulatory requirements.

The main purpose of the amendments is to provide new alternative enforcement options to enable the TGA to deal more effectively and efficiently with suppliers and manufacturers who may place public health and safety at risk by failing to fully comply with regulatory requirements including product and manufacturing standards. The amendments represent the government’s determination to respond to deficiencies arising from the limited range of enforcement measures presently available to the TGA and are considered necessary to enable the TGA to adequately protect public health and safety. Existing options for dealing with breaches of regulatory requirements are restricted to either criminal prosecution or administrative sanctions such as withdrawing the sponsor’s or manufacturer’s right to continue marketing or manufacturing therapeutic goods. Resort to either of these options may not, in some circumstances, be appropriate or achieve the optimal regulatory outcome, given the time and resources taken to prosecute offenders and the possible need to maintain supply of products to the public because of their essential nature or the lack of available substitute products.

These new provisions are designed to overcome these difficulties and ensure that the TGA can take timely, appropriate and effective action to discourage sponsors and manufacturers from not fully complying with regulatory requirements, particularly when this is driven or influenced by commercial considerations at the expense of public health and safety.
The new package of sanctions is built on existing conduct already regulated as an offence under the act.
Several important measures are introduced in this bill.

In relation to a number of significant existing offences the bill introduces a tiered regime of criminal offences that is intended to better tailor penalties for criminal conduct so that more serious offences resulting in, or likely to cause, harm or injury will attract heavier criminal sanctions. The penalties for higher tiered offences, that require proof of an aggravating element relating to harm or injury, are significantly higher than the corresponding offences without the aggravating element to reflect the more serious consequences flowing from breaches of regulatory requirements that result in, or will pose, a serious and direct threat to public health and safety. The level of penalties for offences with an aggravating element is comparable to those contained in other Commonwealth legislation.
Under the bill penalty levels for some offences are increased to ensure consistency of penalties across the act.

The bill allows for alternative verdicts in respect of the various tiered offences in relation to the same conduct regulated under the act. This measure allows a jury to convict a person of the lesser offence, if the jury acquits the person of an offence specifying an aggravating element but is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt of facts that prove the person is guilty of the lesser offence relating to the same conduct. This provision is necessary in view of the tiered offence regime regulating conduct that consists of the same physical elements. This approach is modelled on similar alternative verdict provisions in other Commonwealth legislation.

Under the bill a defendant may be required to provide a pre-disclosure notice of evidence, in support of a defence to an offence related to dealings with unapproved goods, prior to the defendant being committed to trial or the determination or hearing by a court of summary jurisdiction. It provides the Director of Public Prosecutions with a way of adequately assessing evidence of an exception to the offence claimed by a defendant prior to committal or hearing. The pre-trial disclosure requirement is similar to that provided under the New South Wales Criminal Procedure Act 1986.

The bill introduces a parallel civil penalty regime for breaches of the act. The inclusion in the act of civil penalties, alongside criminal penalties, will allow for an alternative and quicker process for dealing with a wide range of legislative breaches. Civil penalties are expected to be more effective in deterring and preventing noncompliance with regulatory requirements by body corporates, who represent the bulk of those regulated under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 and regulations.

Higher penalty levels attach to civil penalties because they are designed to provide adequate incentives, especially in relation to well-resourced corporate entities, for deterring breaches of regulatory requirements under the act. The inclusion of alternative civil penalties and criminal offences is an effective strategy that has worked well under other Commonwealth legislation.

The bill introduces infringement notices (on-the-spot fines) for strict liability offences and for conduct that is subject to the new civil penalty regime. Use of infringement notices will allow appropriate enforcement action to be taken where readily assessable elements of a breach are identified and where use of other enforcement options are not warranted. An infringement notice, which will set out the particulars of the offence, is intended to give the offender the option of either paying the penalty specified in the notice or electing to have the matter dealt with by a court. If paid on time no further liability arises. If not so paid, the matter may be subject to subsequent court proceedings. The bill introduces provisions that enable the TGA to accept enforceable undertakings by a person either to remedy breaches of regulatory requirements or to not engage in future contraventions. Enforceable undertakings are a form of administrative resolution based on voluntary undertakings given by the person concerned as an alternative to litigation or regulatory action. If an undertaking is breached the TGA may seek enforcement of the undertaking by the Federal Court. The use of this measure may be more efficient and productive in particular circumstances, such as where a deficiency in a manufacturing process needs to be rectified by a manufacturer whose general manufacturing ability is not in question. The use of enforceable undertakings in appropriate situations will ensure that public health and safety is assured while access to therapeutic goods for which the public has a continuing need is maintained. The power to accept enforceable undertakings is already given under Commonwealth legislation to other regulators such as the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission and the Australian Securities and Investments Commission.
Enforceable undertakings cannot be unilaterally enforced by the TGA and can only be used where those regulated agree to their use.

The bill provides for certain offences to extend to conduct by an Australian citizen or Australian body corporate outside Australia, and to conduct by an Australian resident outside Australia where there is an equivalent offence in the laws of the relevant overseas jurisdiction.

The offences that will be extended extraterritorially relate to the making of false and misleading statements in a material particular in connection with an application to include therapeutic goods in the register, the manufacture, supply, export or import of counterfeit therapeutic goods, the manufacture or supply of tampered goods and the failure to notify the secretary or the National Manager of the Therapeutic Goods Administration about actual or potential tampering of therapeutic goods.

These particular offence provisions have been given extended extraterritorial application in order to ensure that a person who would ordinarily be subject to the laws of Australia, had the conduct occurred within Australia, will be held accountable for the same conduct undertaken whilst the person is not in Australia, on the basis that the conduct, undertaken externally, could result in a significant impact on the health and safety of the Australian community.

The bill extends the powers by an authorised person available under monitoring warrants to secure appropriate evidence in respect of a contravention or suspected contravention of civil penalty provisions. The bill also introduces a new search and seizure warrant relating to contraventions of civil penalty provisions. The provisions reflect similar requirements in the act for offence related warrants.

The bill extends the liability of a body corporate to executive officers who are directly involved in its day-to-day management if the body corporate commits an offence or contravenes a civil penalty provision. This measure ensures that executive officers who are in a position to prevent a contravention by the body corporate will be deemed liable for the contravention if they fail to take reasonable steps to do so.

The bill extends the circumstances in which the TGA is authorised to release information it holds in relation to therapeutic goods. The bill specifically permits the public release of information relating to any regulatory decisions and actions taken under the act and regulations. In addition, the bill also authorises the release of information relating to a breach or an alleged breach of the act or regulations involving therapeutic goods to Australian and overseas regulatory agencies. This extra capacity to disseminate such information will assist in improving the TGA’s ability to protect public health and safety.

The bill provides substantial measures to improve the regulation of therapeutic goods. The expanded range of enforcement mechanisms under the bill provides a more flexible approach to securing compliance with the regulatory scheme. The introduction of civil penalties means that noncompliant persons can be fined rather than prosecuted in appropriate circumstances. In a number of cases this may be the TGA’s preferred course of action unless the conduct has the characteristic of criminality and is likely to cause or has caused harm or injury to consumers. The level of fines applicable in a particular case will be determined by a court and will reflect its assessment of the seriousness of the conduct in question. The payment of fines rather than conviction is likely to be preferable to many persons in view of the adverse consequences on a person following a conviction.

With the new measures the TGA will be better placed to deter a company’s continuing breaches of regulatory requirements before they become so serious that administrative action has to be taken that could put the company out of business.

Deterring noncompliance by the industry as a whole is important in protecting consumers but it also creates a fairer environment for all players as law-abiding sponsors and manufacturers are not unfairly disadvantaged by their noncompliant competitors. Increased compliance also leads to greater credibility and attractiveness of marketed products.

The confidence of the community in the safety of therapeutic goods is of great importance. The observance of Australia’s regulatory requirements for therapeutic goods by suppliers and manufacturers enhances the reputation of Australian industry. The provisions in the bill represent appropriate measures to protect the interests of both the community and industry.
I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Gavan O’Connor) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.inline: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Member for Calare from moving that this House:

item.para: condemns the Government for agreeing to the full sale of Telstra in the face of overwhelming public opposition;
notes the inability of the Government and Telstra to provide any credible figures on the amount needed to bring parity of price and parity of service to rural and regional Australia;

further notes the totally inadequate universal service obligation funding and the Government’s continued ignoring of the Productivity Commission’s 2001 inquiry into telecommunications regulation that supported the then Australian Communications Authority’s belief that half a billion dollars per annum was needed to maintain and enhance the network;

calls on the Government to implement an immediate reinvestment strategy from existing income streams to ensure adequate telecommunications infrastructure and affordable services for all Australians wherever they live; and
calls on all country representatives to oppose the Telstra sale legislation.

speech.para: This is the beginning of the end for the quisling National Party—a betrayal, a sell-out—

motionnospeech.name: Mr PYNE
motionnospeech.role: —Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing)

motion.para: That the member be no longer heard.

debate.para: 10000 SPEAKER, TheThe SPEAKER—Is the motion seconded?

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, this indicates that the National Party is not only prepared—

motionnospeech.name: Mr PYNE
motionnospeech.role: —Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing)

motion.para: That the member be no longer heard.

debate.para: Original question put:

motion.para: That the motion (Mr Andren’s) be agreed to.

debateinfo.title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AMENDMENT (SMALL BUSINESS EMPLOYMENT PROTECTION) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 16 August, on motion by Mr Andrews:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: upon which Mr Stephen Smith moved by way of amendment:

para.inline: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading,

item.para: noting that the nation’s independent umpire in industrial relations matters, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC), has examined and heard submissions concerning the impact of redundancy payments on small business;
noting that the AIRC has found that the available evidence does not support the general proposition that small businesses across the board does not have the capacity to pay severance pay; but
recognising the circumstances of those individual small business which are incapable of making redundancy payments;

motion.para: calls on the Government to comply with the AIRC decision and to adopt mechanisms to address those individual businesses with a genuine incapacity to make redundancy payments”.

talk.start.para: —I continue my remarks from last night’s debate. The reason why the Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004 needs to be introduced into the parliament is the decision by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to overturn small business’s exemption from redundancy pay obligations. The Australian Labor Party’s blocking of unfair dismissal reform in the Senate on over 40 occasions demonstrates that the Labor members in the other house are certainly not friends of the small business community. It is unfortunate that their stance has been supported by the recent decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to impose redundancy pay obligations on the small business community. In this instance, it is not the ALP and their blind allegiance to the militant unions that is placing a noose on small business; it is the AIRC itself. That is a real shame. It is a disgrace.

speech.para: The AIRC’s decision highlights the deficiencies within the antiquated industrial relations system, which is not up to speed with the needs of modern small business in modern Australia. The fact that there is a need for this bill hammers home the piecemeal pace at which industrial relations reform has taken place in Australia. While many sectors in the economy have adapted and evolved with change, our current industrial relations system is restricted by the parameters of the past. The commission is a creature of initial post Federation Australia. Our economy and our business sector continually strive to adapt to the ever globalising environment. The Australian Industrial Relations Commission however, as a bastion of the traditional industrial club, has continued to stand out as a key example of how the system can stifle modern workplace agreements. The failure of the commission to provide sufficient protection for small businesses against often financially crippling redundancy payments highlights the commission’s disconnection from the needs of our small business community. It also highlights a strong need to reform the commission. I welcome the decision of the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations to introduce as part of the coming reforms a new Fair Pay Commission along the lines of that currently operating in the United Kingdom.

This important reform will help drag the industrial relations system into the 21st century and will create a real benefit for small business. A strong and sustainable economy is vital for the small business sector to prosper. They do not have the buffer zones within their budgets to absorb an economic downturn and, if things are going well, a small business should be able to put on extra staff. This productive improvement for small business will also enable the local community to share in the net benefit of the strong business climate.

We know that there should not be a ‘one size fits all’ approach to our industrial relations system. It is unfortunate, but the Labor Party’s opposition to this bill highlights that they are increasingly out of touch. They look at industrial relations as something that can so easily be implemented and imposed on businesses no matter what their size. In a strong economy small businesses create employment. The last thing that the small business sector needs is an impediment and a disincentive placed upon it by the AIRC through pressure from an ever irrelevant Australian Council of Trade Unions, which is suffering from underrepresentation in the Australian work force.

Historically the industrial relations system has adapted to contemporary requirements at a snail’s pace. More than ever before, it is evident that large centralised bodies such as the government and the commission have less of a role to play in efficient employment arrangements within small business. This bill is vitally important. Its purpose goes right to the heart of the small business liability. If not passed, the vast majority of small businesses covered by federal awards will eventually be subject to redundancy payments for their employees in accordance with the Industrial Relations Commission’s decision. With the commission’s decision pointing the IR system in a ‘one size fits all’ direction, there is a need for legislative change to guarantee protection for small business.

The bill underlines the current need for reform within this system. The commission’s decision will impose an unfair financial burden on small businesses. Every employee and their employer deserve the right to negotiate and reach an agreement on employment and salary packages. One must ask how far we have actually come in workplace relations given the fact that this piece of legislation is even needed. Small businesses were exempted by the commission’s predecessor, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, in 1984.

The decision to exempt small businesses from mandatory severance pay was an ironic step in the right direction by that commission during the time of the former Labor government. It is perplexing to understand why the current Labor opposition are against this bill, considering that those exemptions were put in place when they were in power. More importantly, it is also perplexing when one realises that state based industrial relations commissions around Australia—of course, all in Labor states—have created this exemption as well.

Two years prior to the coalition’s election in 1996, the New South Wales Industrial Commission reaffirmed the need for the small business exemption. Just recently, the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission continued the almost unanimous view that the exemption made plain commonsense. The question remains: why did the national commission go against this trend and why will federal Labor also go against this trend? It is a trend so readily accepted by their mates in Queensland and New South Wales. I ask that the Labor opposition rethink their view on this issue and realise that their position is contrary to the practices that are taking place in other states and also from when they were in power at a federal level.

talk.start.para: —From the viewpoint of the very many small business holders in my electorate of Hasluck, the Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004 is very welcome, removing as it does onerous and unacceptable burdens placed upon them by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The bill will amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to ensure that those small businesses covered by federal awards will continue to enjoy an exemption from the need to provide redundancy payments—an exemption, I might add, which they have enjoyed since 1984.

speech.para: If the AIRC’s decision imposing such a burdensome obligation of redundancy payments is allowed to stand without challenge, it will directly impact on the ability of many thousands of small businesses to continue to operate and provide, as they do, much needed employment opportunities for local people in the community of the electorate of Hasluck. Members may recall that in my maiden speech to this House in November 2004 I made a commitment to small business within the electorate of Hasluck to work on their behalf to reduce the excessive burden placed on them by bureaucracies such as the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. I am therefore delighted to be able to stand here today to provide those small businesses with a loud voice to protect their interests.

Local businesses stand at the heart of many local communities, including my own, adding vibrancy, and providing valuable services and, most importantly, employment to the many constituents of Hasluck. This sector of our economy is one that truly underpins our economic capacity and, indeed, our Australian way of life. The 1.1 million non-agricultural small businesses that are spread throughout Australia are responsible for employing over 3.3 million people, and the role they play in economic growth and job creation within this nation should not be underestimated or go unrecognised. Any measure that threatens the viability of small business is therefore unwelcome and will have many undesirable consequences.

The small business sector is filled with some of our nation’s most self-reliant, innovative and entrepreneurial people. Small businesses operate the length and breadth of our country, from the smallest country town to the largest of our capital cities. For me, and indeed for the majority of people within my electorate of Hasluck and within this country as a whole, the decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission overturning the exemption from severance pay for businesses employing fewer than 15 employees is very baffling and puzzling in the extreme.

The exemption was granted with good reason by its predecessor over 20 years ago. It is therefore truly mystifying why the Australian Industrial Relations Commission should introduce a requirement that has the very real potential to result in the insolvency of many small business holders. It is a flawed decision, and one that must be extinguished by this bill. The decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has caused alarm and consternation. We must not allow excessive regulation and compliance standards to stand in the way or crush the aspirations of those hard-working and committed people who run small businesses and contribute so much to the communities in which they operate.

For many years I was the Chief Executive Officer of the Master Plumbers and Gasfitters Association as well as the Master Painters, Decorators and Signwriters Association. They served the interests of many small business operators in the building and construction sector, so I know from personal experience the difficult environment that many small businesses have to work in. The decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to impose the requirement to take on the obligation for redundancy payments stifles free enterprise and has the potential to be the proverbial straw that broke the camel’s back for many small businesses.

It is interesting to note that both the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission and the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission have reaffirmed the need for small business exemptions in this regard. It is also interesting to note that none of the four state governments that participated in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission test case supported the removal of the exemption. Indeed, my own state of Western Australia actively opposed the measure—why?—because it just does not make economic sense.

The Australian Industrial Relations Commission imposes a ridiculous and unreasonable financial burden on businesses that operate in often difficult circumstances and with tight margins. Typically, a small retailer employing just six or seven people could potentially find itself having to put aside many thousands of dollars into a contingency fund to cover its liability for severance pay. It is a cost that few if any but the most prosperous of small businesses can afford to bear. Those affected by this decision are not the BHPs or the News Corps of this world, with their multimillion- or even multibillion-dollar turnovers; they are often family owned businesses that, while paying their way, are not in a position to take on redundancy liabilities that can run into the tens of thousands of dollars.

The coalition and indeed the majority of reasonably minded people within this country oppose any unnecessary restraints on small business operators that make it more difficult for them to employ people. This government has consistently made its support for small businesses known and has translated that support into action. This bill shows that we will continue to oppose absurd and unwarranted impediments that will make it much harder for small businesses to provide jobs and contribute to the health of local economies.

The opposition is opposing the bill—not because the bill doesn’t make good sense, but rather out of political dogma and, I suspect, a desire to be seen to support the ACTU’s opposition to the exemption. In reality, it is also about protecting the Labor Party’s bottom line and the $47 million that the union movement has donated to the opposition over the last 10 years. It seems that Labor is prepared to leave small business operators and the millions of people that they employ out on a limb in order to line its own pockets.

The Labor Party is proposing a system whereby small businesses will have to make individual applications to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission for exemption from redundancy payments. The proposal is unreasonable—indeed absurd. It imposes an extra and totally unnecessary burden on small businesses and a degree of uncertainty that at the end of the day is just unacceptable. The Labor Party’s expectation is that small business owners should jump through hoops to deal with the bureaucracy of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The reason for doing so is to restore an exemption that should never have been removed in the first place.

Small business owners have neither the time nor the money to devote to such a farcical system, a system which previous experience has shown just does not and will not work. Such a system has been in operation for larger businesses for around 20 years; in all of that time there does not appear to have been a single exemption granted. The Labor Party is once again failing small businesses in Australia in a deplorable and absolutely abysmal way. While at least the ACTU’s support for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission’s decision is understandable—it is after all a morally bankrupt institution—I find the Labor Party’s slavish following of the ACTU’s position repugnant.

It should be noted that this bill will not affect any redundancy pay provisions that were in awards prior to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission’s decision. Nor does the bill prevent small businesses from reaching an agreement with their employees on redundancy payments should they wish to and should they be able to afford to do so. Rather, the bill extinguishes an entitlement which previously did not exist and which small businesses were unable to plan for.

By introducing this bill, the coalition is going some way to deliver on its re-election promise to continue to pursue changes to take the unfair dismissal laws burden off the back of small businesses and protect small business from redundancy payments. In my view, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission seriously underestimated the adverse impact its decision would have on an important sector of the Australian economy. The Australian Industrial Relations Commission’s imposition of a ‘one size fits all’ regulation flies in the face of economic reality and small business imperatives. It also very seriously ignores the fact that small businesses simply cannot afford the financial burden it has imposed upon them. I wholeheartedly support this bill and recommend it to the House.

talk.start.para: —I would like to dedicate my speech on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004 to the memory of Clive Macness, who passed away in February this year. Small business people in my electorate of Dobell cannot afford an increase in the cost of running their businesses—nor can the Central Coast economy. That is why I am here today debating this important bill. The Workplace Relations Amendment (Protecting Small Business Employment) Bill 2004 proposes to amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to maintain the exemption for small business from redundancy pay by overturning a recent decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to impose redundancy pay obligations on small business.

speech.para: If this bill is not passed, hundreds of small businesses in my electorate will be required to make redundancy payments to their employees, which will result in the loss of many permanent jobs on the Central Coast. It will make the lives of small business people unnecessarily harder and will make them more reluctant to give new apprentices and disadvantaged groups like unemployed people the opportunity of full-time work.

The Australian Labor Party does not understand this. The Labor Party, which is beholden to union bosses, does not understand that small business is the biggest contributor to employment there is and needs to be supported for the future prosperity of our region. Small businesses need greater flexibility, because they do not have the same access to financial and human resources as larger businesses do. Unplanned expenses can threaten the viability of businesses and, importantly, the jobs of those working in those businesses. You can only pay people out of profit. The AIRC ruling is essentially a $190 million tax on the restructuring businesses need to undertake regularly just to survive. The Australian Labor Party simply cannot purport to support permanent jobs and then oppose this important legislation—and, in doing so, oppose much of the significant workplace relations reform that has taken place over the last decade.

Strangely enough, the Labor Party’s own policy concedes that many small businesses should be exempted from redundancy pay. It has proposed an ‘exemption’ system, in which affected small businesses can apply to the AIRC to be exempt from redundancy payments. The times when small businesses are forced to retrench people are typically times when their financial resources are stretched. It is absurd to expect that small businesses in that situation will have the money and the time available to run a case before the AIRC to have them exempted. The Labor Party does not really care about the challenges facing small business. The truth is that, by opposing this bill as well as our reforms to right of entry laws, unfair dismissal and compulsory union membership, the ALP is showing Australia that it is indifferent to non-union businesses and job creation.

I will take this opportunity to read a letter from a man named Phil Dulhunty, who wrote to me about the turmoil union bosses put his company through, eventually forcing him to sell his hard-earned business to a foreign company. I worked for this company in the late 1970s and early 1980s, so I experienced first-hand the havoc caused by bullying union bosses. The letter states:

quote.para: My consideration for Unions was totally destroyed when my company in Wyong was ‘invaded’ by the Storemen and Packers Union under the leadership of a fellow by the name of Simon Crean.

My company, Dulmison, was founded by 3 ex servicemen in 1947 at the end of the Pacific War, using their deferred pay as initial capital. Over some 40 years, through hard work and enthusiasm the company grew to a size where we employed some 350 people and had a turnover of $50m. We established a large export market for our products in the electric power transmission industry. We manufactured and supplied all the fittings and equipment for the major 500kv grids of Victoria and NSW. We had established factories overseas in NZ, Thailand, UK, USA and South Africa and became the largest international supplier of these products.

Because we had a factory in South Africa we came into the spotlight of the union movement who decided eventually to apply secondary boycott so that we could not ship any goods nor receive any from overseas.

Mr Crean became incensed when he learned that none of our employees in Wyong were members of neither his union nor any other union. We were a decentralized manufacturer and most of our employees were local residents, country people, conscientious and hard working. There was a great esprit de corps amongst us all, managers, owners and workers.

We invited Mr Crean and his men to visit and address the company employees and to recruit them into his union. Not one person was interested or prepared to join and the union representatives were invited to leave.
This is what then led to the secondary boycott and the smashing of headlights of our employees’ cars in the company car park!
Our company, all our employees, the Wyong district and the nation as a whole suffered immensely from this action.
The union leaders had absolutely no concern for anything but themselves.
As a result of Mr Crean’s action the Dulmison company, proudly Australian owned, had to be sold, eventually to an overseas company and is now owned 100% by Tyco of USA.
If any political party is beholden in any way to support the union movement at the expense of the broader national interest, it will be to their doom along with Australia as a Nation.
If the Labor Party is ever to get my vote again, they must reorganize the union movement or disassociate themselves entirely from it.

speech.para: Mr Dulhunty is perfectly right. As it stands, 71 per cent of Labor members of parliament have union links, which is scandalous when you consider that average union membership in private industry is only 17 per cent. If the Australian Labor Party are serious about wanting to govern Australia, they need to understand what small Australian businesses need. What they need are laws that support them. Labor must support this legislation and put jobs in my electorate first, particularly permanent jobs. They can no longer support legislation that hinders non-union businesses and, in so doing, impedes jobs.

The AIRC’s decision is severely flawed. It is significant to note that none of the four state governments that participated in the AIRC test case supported the removal of the exemption. The Queensland and Western Australian governments opposed the removal, while the New South Wales and Victorian governments neither supported nor opposed it.

With a background in small business I understand what the AIRC ruling means for small businesses in the electorate of Dobell. A typical retail small business with seven employees, each with six years of continuous employment, would, under this ruling, face a contingent liability for redundancy pay of nearly $30,000. I know that there are business operators in my electorate who have taken a risk to provide some wealth for their families and are struggling, with their homes and their assets on the line. Forcing small businesses to make redundancy payments will serve only to push these businesses into insolvency. It is vital that opportunities for continued growth and job creation for the 1.4 million small businesses in Australia be maximised. It is even more essential for the 3.3 million people employed by these businesses.

The Howard government is the only government that is consistent and strong in its support for small business. It recognises that the biggest threat to jobs growth in Australia is the unnecessary impediments which make it harder for small businesses to employ people. I encourage members to dissociate themselves from the union movement and instead put small business and jobs in my electorate and across Australia first and foremost. I commend this bill to the House.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: —I thank all members for their valuable contribution to this debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004. While I understand some of the concerns raised, I sincerely hope that the opposition will finally join with the government and stand up for small businesses and their employees by supporting the key measures that are proposed in this bill.

speech.para: This bill will ensure that small businesses with fewer than 15 employees that are covered by federal awards are not burdened by redundancy pay obligations. It will amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to maintain the exemption that has been in place for small businesses from redundancy pay and it will legislate to address the Australian Industrial Relations Commission decision of 26 March last year.

As honourable members know, the government introduced this bill to parliament on 8 December last year. Since then there have been a number of key developments that have further strengthened the case for this bill. These developments have made it increasingly obvious that the Industrial Relations Commission’s decision to impose redundancy pay on small business was a mistake that must be addressed. I am of course referring to the fact that, since the bill was first introduced, two state industrial relations tribunals have issued rulings rejecting union claims to adopt the AIRC’s decision and remove the small business exemptions in their states.

In December last year the full bench of the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission rejected for a second time a claim by the Queensland Council of Unions to remove the small business exemption. It first rejected the claim in October 2003. In its most recent decision the full bench declined to adopt the AIRC’s decision and instead reinforced its original decision. It stated:

quote.para: There are substantial reasons for a small business exemption and we again adopt those reasons referred to in our previous decision.

speech.para: The Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission also refused to adopt the Australian Industrial Relations Commission decision in April this year, rejecting a claim by the Trades and Labour Council of Western Australia to impose redundancy pay provisions on the small business sector in that state. Rejecting the union’s claim, the Western Australian commission stated that they were ‘required to evaluate the evidence according to its weight and not merely adopt the conclusion of the AIRC’. The decision particularly relied on witness evidence that small business as a whole is inherently riskier than larger business and that small businesses have more difficulty in obtaining finance when required.

Two industrial relations tribunals were strongly urged by unions to accept the reasoning of the AIRC decision. Both refused to impose redundancy pay provisions on small business. The cumulative effect of these decisions has produced an untenable situation across Australia. Employees of small businesses located side by side can now have widely different redundancy entitlements, depending on whether they are covered by a state or federal award—in fact, employees of the same small business that is covered by a federal award and a state award can have significantly different entitlements. This situation is totally unsatisfactory and we believe it demands legislative action from this parliament now; yet our Labor colleagues would have this uncertainty and confusion for small business continue indefinitely. This is an irresponsible stance to take for both employees and employers. As well as protecting jobs, this bill will provide small businesses and their employees with consistency and certainty.

During the debate on this bill, we have heard from several Labor members about the incapacity of some small businesses to make redundancy payments. We now know that Labor accepts that the AIRC’s decision does not adequately protect small businesses that cannot afford redundancy pay. The Labor Party also accepts that many small businesses need to be exempted from redundancy pay. The Labor Party acknowledges that the AIRC’s decision as it stands will not achieve this. The only real difference between the government and Labor on this is how to go about protecting small businesses that cannot afford redundancy pay.

The government’s answer is clear and simple, and it will work. Our bill will exempt small businesses from new redundancy pay obligations and will enable employers and their employees to negotiate redundancy pay through workplace bargaining where a small business can afford it and it is a priority for employees. In contrast, the solution proposed by the member for Perth in his second reading amendment is for the government to ‘adopt mechanisms to address those individual businesses with a genuine incapacity to make redundancy payments’. The member for Perth elaborated that the government should ‘find mechanisms to assist those small businesses which genuinely cannot afford to make redundancy payments’. He said that the ‘process for small business employers to demonstrate an incapacity to pay should be readily accessible and simple’ and that they should not have to go through ‘expensive, time-consuming processes’ to prove incapacity.

This is the same alternative that Labor put forward over 12 months ago, except that, at that time, Labor wanted a Senate inquiry to find the mechanisms, not the government, and they suggested that electronic lodgment of applications might be the way to go. At least our Labor colleagues have learned since then that electronic lodgment already exists, has been tested and has been proven to be a complete failure in overcoming the notorious ineffectiveness of the incapacity to pay processes. I would have thought that, in the intervening 12 months, Labor might have been able to develop some specific proposals of their own, other than a wish for a simple and inexpensive process. It goes without saying that we all want all processes to be simple and inexpensive.

The incapacity to pay mechanism envisaged by Labor will not work. The incapacity to pay process is not capable of protecting small businesses from redundancy payments. I am surprised that Labor again put forward incapacity to pay processes as some kind of bandaid solution. It is particularly surprising given the recent developments in Queensland and Western Australia that I have just outlined. Both the Queensland and Western Australian industrial relations commissions had the option of using incapacity to pay processes to address the very real financial burden which small businesses would face if redundancy pay obligations were imposed on them. In fact, the unions argued before both commissions that this would be the appropriate way to deal with small businesses which could not afford redundancy payments.

So why did both the Queensland and Western Australian commissions reject these arguments and refuse to remove the small business exemption? It was because the evidence resoundingly shows that incapacity to pay processes do not work. The evidence also shows that the lack of financial resilience found in small businesses means that the only real option for this important sector of our economy is to retain the exemption for small businesses from redundancy pay obligations. Our Labor colleagues know this, yet they persist along the same worn track. One can only wonder why.

I note that some members believe that this bill undermines the authority and independence of the Industrial Relations Commission. I reiterate that legislation is the only possible option available to government to overturn this decision of the commission. On 3 April 2004, the Prime Minister publicly announced that the government would legislate to overturn the commission’s decision to impose redundancy pay obligations on small businesses under federal awards. The government sought and obtained a mandate on this issue at the subsequent October election. By delivering the Howard government a majority in both houses of parliament, the Australian people have made it clear where they stand on this issue. Australians realise the importance of protecting the job-generating capacity of small businesses and they have chosen to re-elect a government that will not only protect existing jobs but encourage and support new jobs growth.

Labor members have also argued that the bill goes further than just overturning the decision of the Industrial Relations Commission and that the government is bulldozing its way into state industrial relations systems. That is simply not true. Test case decisions of the AIRC hold enormous weight within the various state industrial relations systems. The Western Australian commission confirmed this when it handed down its redundancy decision earlier this year. While the commission rejected the general removal of the small business exemption, it left the way open for unions to mount cases to remove the exemption from individual awards. In doing so, the commission noted that ‘the decision of the AIRC will, in our view, be of considerable weight in such claims’. This is a very real possibility in other state jurisdictions as well. To properly stop any further adverse consequences as a result of the decision, it must be prevented from flowing to state jurisdictions. The bill will achieve this—no more and no less.

Throughout the debate on the bill, Labor members have tended to focus on the supplementary decision of the Industrial Relations Commission, seemingly believing that the decision is some kind of magic cure-all for small businesses—but of course it is not. The member for Perth is correct that the supplementary decision reduces the immediate burden for small businesses, but that is all it does. In the longer term, the decision changes nothing. After four years, small businesses would suffer exactly the same cost burden as they would if redundancy pay were introduced in full immediately. If small businesses were to spend the next four years accumulating the massive reserves necessary to fund potential redundancy payments, as suggested by Labor, instead of using the funds to employ people and expand their businesses, the impact on employment and the economy would be devastating.

To summarise the government’s position, this bill underlines the government’s strong commitment to the small business sector, which it recognises as the job-generating engine of the economy. I call on the opposition to show the same level of commitment by supporting this important legislative amendment.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—The original question was that the bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Perth has moved as an amendment that all words after ‘That’ be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

speech.para: Question agreed to.
Original question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: —I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum to the Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004 and I move the government amendment as circulated:

amendment.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 9, page 7 (lines 9 to 20), omit the item, substitute:
9 Transitional—eligible instruments

speech.para: Item applies to eligible instruments with small business redundancy pay requirements just before commencement

(1) This item applies if, just before the commencement of this Schedule, an eligible instrument contained provisions requiring some or all (the affected employers) relevant employers that employ fewer than 15 employees to pay redundancy pay.
Eligible instruments that began to provide for small business redundancy pay between 26 March 2004 and commencement

amendment.para: (a) the eligible instrument was made before 26 March 2004 and just before 26 March 2004 the eligible instrument did not contain provisions requiring the affected employers to pay redundancy pay; or
(b) the eligible instrument was made on or after 26 March 2004;
then, from the commencement of this Schedule, the provisions do not have the effect of requiring any affected employers to pay redundancy pay.

speech.para: Eligible instruments where Federal award suppressed a small business redundancy pay requirement that was present just before 26 March 2004

amendment.para: (a) just before 26 March 2004, the eligible instrument contained provisions requiring the affected employers to pay redundancy pay; and
(b) only because of a Federal award, the provisions did not, just before the commencement of this Schedule, have the effect of requiring a particular affected employer to pay redundancy pay;
then the provisions do not, at or at any time after the commencement of this Schedule, have that effect in relation to the particular affected employer.

speech.para: Eligible instruments where certified agreement or AWA suppressed a small business redundancy pay requirement that was present just before 26 March 2004, and a Federal award would also have had that effect

amendment.para: (a) just before 26 March 2004, the eligible instrument contained provisions requiring the affected employers to pay redundancy pay; and
(b) just before the commencement of this Schedule:
(i) only because of a certified agreement or an AWA, the provisions did not have the effect of requiring a particular affected employer to pay redundancy pay; and
(ii) disregarding the certified agreement or the AWA, the provisions would still not have had that effect, and this would have been so only because of a Federal award;
then the provisions do not, at or at any time after the commencement of this Schedule, have that effect in relation to the particular affected employer.

speech.para: Eligible instruments where small business redundancy pay requirement was present just before 26 March 2004 and a future Federal award starts to apply

amendment.para: (a) just before 26 March 2004, the eligible instrument contained provisions requiring the affected employers to pay redundancy pay; and
(b) neither subitem (3) nor subitem (4) applies; and

(c) the eligible instrument contains the provisions from the commencement of this Schedule until a later time (the award time) when a particular affected employer becomes bound by a Federal award; and
(d) the Federal award applies in relation to some or all (the affected employees) of the particular affected employer’s employees to whom the requirement to pay redundancy pay relates;
then, from the award time, the provisions do not have the effect of requiring the particular affected employer to pay redundancy pay in respect of the affected employees.

speech.para: Definitions
(6) In this item:

amendment.para: eligible instrument has the meaning given by subsection 167(1) of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 as inserted by item 5 of this Schedule.
Federal award means an award under the Workplace Relations Act 1996.
relevant employer has the meaning given by subsection 167(4) of that Act as inserted by item 5 of this Schedule.

speech.para: A key aim of this bill is to maintain an exemption for small businesses from the obligation to make redundancy payments by overturning the Australian Industrial Relations Commission decision of 26 March 2004. The bill, as introduced, will amend the Workplace Relations Act to, firstly, prevent the Industrial Relations Commission from including new small business redundancy pay provisions in federal awards and, secondly, prevent the flow-on of the commission’s decision by precluding the imposition of new small business redundancy pay obligations by state laws, state awards and state authority orders in respect of small businesses that are corporations and by territory laws in respect of all small business.

The bill, as introduced, also contains transitional provisions cancelling small business redundancy pay obligations contained in federal awards and state and territory industrial instruments that were made on or after 26 March 2004 and before the commencement of the bill. However, the bill, as introduced, does not prevent a state law, a state award, a state authority order or a territory law made before 26 March 2004 which contains a small business redundancy pay obligation that was previously suppressed by a federal award from springing up to fill the gap when a federal award no longer provides for small business redundancy pay. The proposed government amendment to the bill addresses the lacuna in the bill, as introduced, by substituting a new item 9. This amendment will simply ensure that, to the maximum extent of Commonwealth power, small businesses respondent to a federal award that previously exempted small business from redundancy pay are not subject to new redundancy pay obligations as a result of other changes proposed in the bill. I commend the amendment to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

motionnospeech.name: Mr ANDREWS
motionnospeech.role: —Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service)

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

debateinfo.title: MINISTER FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT, TERRITORIES AND ROADS

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads from coming into the House and responding to today’s confirmation of interference in the departmental assessment of the Primary Energy Regional Partnerships grant application and undertaking to table the following documents before Question Time today:

(1) the letter or record of other communication from the senior advisor to the former Deputy Prime Minister directing the Minister’s department to approve funding for Primary Energy and provide that funding as soon as possible;

(2) the brief prepared by the Minister’s department that recommended against the approval of the $1.2 million grant to Primary Energy that was subsequently intercepted by the acting departmental secretary in July 2004; and

(3) the final departmental brief presented to the Minister that had been altered to address issues raised in the letter from the former Deputy Prime Minister’s senior advisor and formed the basis of the Minister’s decision to approve the grant.

speech.para: This is a scandal of political preference and crass cronyism. The minister has an obligation—

motionnospeech.name: Mr ANDREWS
motionnospeech.role: —Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service)

motion.para: That the member be no longer heard.

debate.para: 10000 Jenkins, Harry (The DEPUTY SPEAKER)The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?

talk.start.para: —I second the motion. One million dollars and not a litre of ethanol—and you thought petrol was expensive!

motionnospeech.name: Mr ANDREWS
motionnospeech.role: —Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service)

motion.para: That the member be no longer heard.

debate.para: Original question put:

motion.para: That the motion (Mr Crean’s) be agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 June, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Health Insurance Amendment (Medical Specialists) Bill 2005 implements changes to the prerequisites for the recognition of certain medical specialists and consultant physicians. The changes will remove separate processes that these medical practitioners must undertake currently to access Medicare.

speech.para: Currently there are three ways in which medical practitioners can apply to the Health Insurance Commission to provide Medicare services. The processes vary depending on the circumstances. If a medical practitioner is domiciled in Australia, if they are a fellow or if they have a relevant qualification from a specialist medical college, they are able to seek automatic recognition. This recognition occurs after the Health Insurance Commission receives confirmation from the medical college that these qualifications have been satisfied.

Consultant physicians and other medical practitioners that do not meet these criteria must seek recognition through the Specialist Recognition Advisory Committee. These committees are established in every state and territory and meet every two months to perform this task. They are appointed by the minister. All other medical practitioners not domiciled in Australia must seek recognition through a ministerial determination. The government sees these committees as redundant because they rely on the advice of the specialist medical college. They have the effect of delaying recognition for the purpose of Medicare because the committees meet only every two months. This bill proposes that, in their place, this recognition will come from a delegate of the minister in the Health Insurance Commission.

This bill tidies up an administrative process associated with the recognition of medical practitioners for the purposes of Medicare, and Labor supports this. However, the bill demonstrates that the government is happy to fiddle with extraneous elements of our medical work force policy but the government is not happy to look at the big picture and focus on the larger and longer term issues facing the sector.

It is no mystery that the minister with carriage of this bill in this place is Minister Abbott. As we know, the government is happy for Minister Abbott to fiddle around the edges of health policy. But the truth is that today the core of health policy in this country is being driven by the Treasurer entirely through the premise of what health costs and what savings can be made. Minister Abbott has counted himself out of the health debate and out of any substantial role in driving health policy in this country because he has positioned himself absurdly by saying that there should be no reform at all in health.

This might strike people as a remarkable position, given that everybody knows that this nation, along with all other Western developed nations, will experience huge cost pressures in health over the coming few decades. Part of those cost pressures is attributable to changes in demographics with the ageing of our population. That means that there will be more people in the older age ranges needing a significant draw-down on health services. Then there is the challenge of the financing, as the dependency ratio changes and there are fewer taxpayers engaged in the work force to generate taxation revenue to meet the needs of the ageing population. The cost pressures in health do not end there. We know that our society, along with all other Western developed countries, is facing a significant increase in the burden of chronic and complex diseases, which has huge implications for health expenditure. In addition, we know that there are significant cost pressures from innovative pharmaceuticals and new technologies.

All of that adds up to a substantial challenge that the government needs to manage with a reform agenda. The purpose of that reform agenda must be to ensure that we are constantly improving health, from the point of view of those of us who receive health services and preventive health messages and of those we are relying on to manage our health. We want to improve the system for those who rely on it, but we also want to improve its productivity and efficiency. We want to relegate to the dustbin of history the big proportion of waste that is in the system now. That degree of waste has been estimated by experts to be in the vicinity of $1 billion to $2 billion annually. We know that having frail aged people accommodated inappropriately in public hospital beds—because there are no aged care places, respite care places or rehabilitation places for them to go to—wastes around half a billion dollars a year. So there are big reform challenges facing this country, as we look at our current health system and seek to eradicate waste and to drive productivity and efficiency and as we look to the future to manage the challenges and the cost pressures that this nation will undoubtedly face.

In the face of that complex debate and the complex set of choices about what Australia should do next to make sure that our health system serves us better today and continues to serve us well 10, 20, 30 to 40 years down the track, Minister Abbott has decided just to step out of the way. It is too hard and he does not want to know. He is wandering around saying—and this was published last week in the newspapers—that there is no need for reform. He has, in fact, shrugged his shoulders and said, ‘What does it matter if health expenditure moves from around nine per cent of our national income, nine per cent of GDP’—which it is now—‘to around 15 per cent?’ ‘What does that matter?’ Minister Abbott says, with a shrug of the shoulders.

To give the House an idea of how much that matters, in today’s dollars the difference between nine per cent of GDP going on health and 15 per cent of GDP going on health is $51 billion. If in Minister Abbott’s version that $51 billion is to be taxpayer dollars, it will increase the tax burden on every Australian taxpayer by around $4,500 per year. So, when Minister Abbott with a shrug of his shoulders says, ‘Who cares? It does not matter if it goes up to 15 per cent of GDP,’ he is contemplating a system where this government would need to increase the tax burden on Australians, on average, by $4,500 a year. This government, which already runs the highest taxing government in Australia’s history—a big, bloated government—would increase the tax burden of every Australian taxpayer by $4,500 a year.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall that in question time last week we had some interplay about this. When asked about Minister Abbott’s speech about this new fiscal burden and about the weight it would put on taxpayers’ shoulders, Treasurer Costello frankly conceded that he had not read the speech. The day afterwards, when the matter came up by way of interjection, as I recall, he said that he had tried to read the speech but had fallen asleep at the second paragraph. I guess there is no mystery why Treasurer Costello would fall asleep trying to read Minister Abbott’s speeches. It might be because they are boring—and I am sure that is part of the explanation—but, beyond that, Treasurer Costello knows that he does not have to trouble himself with what Minister Abbott says. What Minister Abbott says does not matter because Treasurer Costello is actually in control.

But sooner or later Treasurer Costello will have to say to Minister Abbott that he does care if the amount spent on health floats from nine per cent of GDP to 15 per cent of GDP. In fact, concern about those sorts of questions led to the Treasurer publishing with the budget papers two years ago the Intergenerational report. One of these days Treasurer Costello will have to explain to Minister Abbott that it probably is not on the Howard government’s agenda to put taxes up by $4,500 per taxpayer just so Minister Abbott can stand by watching the passing parade of health generate increased health expenditure.

I think it was at the point of that byplay in question time last week that Minister Abbott was shrugging his shoulders and saying, ‘Well, it doesn’t have to be taxpayers’ dollars.’ But, if that is right, Minister Abbott’s solution to increased cost pressures in health will be to say, ‘Well, health expenditure will float from nine per cent of GDP to 15 per cent of GDP,’ and then presumably he will say, ‘But we won’t be putting up government expenditure; we’ll hold government expenditure around where it is.’ So presumably that difference of $4,500 will fall on Australians as private expenditure.

Either way you cut Minister Abbott’s speech, it is a pretty dark view of the future: where you stand by, engage in no health reform and do absolutely nothing—except fiddle around and watch health expenditure go up as a percentage of our national income—and then somehow Australians pay the bill. There are only two choices: they will pay the bill through their taxes or they will pay the bill through their private expenditure—there is nowhere else the money can come from. That is Minister Abbott’s view of the future. It is an absurd view. One should not get paid for being health minister for taking such a lackadaisical approach. If in truth the Howard government now views Minister Abbott as so incompetent that the only thing he can do is fiddle around the edges and bring bills like this into the parliament—but do nothing else—then really it is time that he was replaced, rather than have him sit in this House masquerading as the health minister while Treasurer Costello is really doing it all and doing it all through the prism of cost cutting.

One of the biggest issues that need reform—and obviously it is squarely raised by this bill—is the crisis we have in Australia’s medical work force. I use the language of ‘crisis’ advisedly, because any Australian who lives in an outer metropolitan or rural and regional area—and I am sure Minister Kelly at the table has probably had some experience with this—will tell you about the problems of getting access to the right medical practitioner when they need to. They will tell you about the shortage of GPs and the shortage of specialists. That means that people are waiting for care because there are simply not enough people in the medical work force or—perhaps more disturbingly still—they are not getting care at all. Particularly in the GP primary-care end of the spectrum, it is very likely that people are putting off going and getting the preventative health checks they know they really should have. But, if accessing a GP is problematic and expensive and so people are not having those preventative health checks, that is going to show up in the future as an increased burden of disease.

We know from the statistics that over the 30 years to 2001 the rate of growth in the number of medical practitioners was faster than the rate of growth of the population generally, but in the 1980s and 1990s this rate of growth slowed. At the end of 2002 there were nearly 22,000 primary-care practitioners employed in Australia, of which 64 per cent were male and 34 per cent were female. The majority of the group—about 87 per cent—are vocationally registered GPs, who are essentially Medicare-licensed GPs. We need to remember that amongst the first actions of the Howard government was a cut in the number of GP training places, so where we are with the work force balance now has in part been driven by Howard government cutbacks.

Apart from the cutbacks another thing that has put a great burden on our primary-care system and has hugely exacerbated the shortage of primary-care practitioners is the changing nature of the medical work force, particularly the changing nature of the number of hours that GPs now work. Deputy Speaker Lindsay, I am sure that you are aware that the historic image of the GP was of a man who could work almost an endless number of hours, relying on a non-working wife to attend to all matters associated with the family. We know, of course, that that historic image of the GP does not accord with modern day reality, where many GPs are women and where many men who are GPs want to work fewer hours than their historic counterparts, because they have working wives and they have a view about work-family balance. This means that out of the raw number of GPs that we train we actually get fewer full-time equivalent GPs because each GP on average is working fewer hours. So an important measure of the medical work force is full-time equivalents. Measured in full-time equivalents, there are 101 full-time equivalent primary-care practitioners per 100,000 people in Australia, based on a 45-hour standard week, which is a decrease from 108, which was the statistic as recently as 1997.

Apart from there being fewer GPs as a whole and apart from the changing nature of the medical work force compounding there being fewer full-time equivalent GPs, we also know that our health work force is ageing. About 39 per cent of people employed in health are aged 45 years or more, up from 31 per cent in 1996. The proportion of workers aged 45-plus increased faster for females than for males, which reflects the fact that our nursing work force is rapidly ageing. We know that there is a global shortage of GPs and, coming back to Australia’s situation, we know that there is a national shortage of GPs. We also know that this national shortage is compounded in outer metropolitan and rural and regional areas by problems of maldistribution. We are short of work force numbers overall and the work force we have tends to be clustered closer to the centre of our bigger capital cities rather than being in outer metropolitan and rural and regional locations.

This is very important—and I am sure Minister Kelly at the table would agree with me in this—because we know that one-third of Australians live in rural and regional areas and that generally these Australians have a higher mortality rate and higher health risk levels than their counterparts in the city. This is due to a greater tendency to develop chronic illness, which is due to the likelihood that people will be working in physical employment, in occupations such as farming, mining and forestry, which can be more hazardous—not to mention the fact, of course, that our Indigenous communities are also concentrated in many rural and regional areas.

In 2002 the AMA commissioned Access Economics to investigate the extent of the shortage of GPs that we will face in the future. I have to say that their results are startling. They found that there is a declining participation rate by GPs. They found that female GPs, who form an increasing proportion of the work force, and younger GPs, both men and women, are only prepared to commit to a working life of well under the 50 to 60 hours per week traditionally worked by GPs. They found that Australian medical schools are not graduating enough doctors and they found that the GP work force shortage has been greatly exacerbated by the Howard government cutbacks to GP training places. In 2001 Access Economics estimated that the overall shortfall of GPs in Australia was between 1,200 and 2,000 full-time equivalent GPs. The rural shortage was estimated at 700 full-time equivalents and the urban shortage at 500 full-time equivalents.

Confronted with that knowledge, you would think that a responsible government that was competent rather than incompetent would be spurred to act, but we really have not seen anything profound being done in the medical work force area; we really have not seen anything except an increasing reliance on overseas trained doctors. We understand that in the current circumstances overseas trained doctors have an important role to play in our medical work force. There is no doubt about that. But it cannot be a strategy for the long term that we rely on importing doctors, nurses and other medical professionals. Why? The world is short of doctors, nurses and other medical professionals. Other developed countries have the same problems we have. They also have medical work forces which are ageing, and they too are looking to be net importers of staff for their medical work forces, so there will not be enough health and medical work force staff to go around.

It is a pretty unseemly vision of the future for us to say that, year in, year out, we will sit idly by, as the Howard government is incompetently doing now, and not train enough Australian doctors, Australian nurses, Australian dentists, Australian radiographers and so on and so forth and then we will go into the global market and see if we can poach them from somewhere, most likely a developing country that needs them. But that is the Howard government’s vision of our future medical work force, unless we do the right thing now—that is, provide a major package to increase the number of Australians we are training for our health and medical work force. It really is very simple. This should be about training and skilling Australians who want to be in our health and medical work force, rather than importing skills—and we will not be able to import them in the longer term, because of global competition.

There is a fashionable view, in particular in the nursing area, that we end up importing because no-one wants to be a nurse anymore. That is not true. Every year thousands of appropriately qualified Australians who want to be doctors, nurses, dentists or radiographers—indeed many of them throughout their whole school life have aspired to work in our health and medical work force—are turned away because there are not enough training places. And then, further down the track, what do the Howard government do? They say: ‘Too bad. We’ll turn those Australians away, and now we’ll desperately fossick around the world and import people.’

We have brought here many highly skilled overseas trained doctors who have made a major contribution to our health system, and I do not want to be seen to be saying anything other than that. But we also know that we have had some big problems in terms of the recognition and quality of skills amongst some overseas trained doctors—the most spectacular example of this, of course, having been in Bundaberg in Queensland. We would be better off on a whole series of levels if we were training Australians and training them now, so that we could be nationally self-sufficient in our medical work force. That does not mean no-one will ever migrate, because human life is partly about people travelling overseas, getting overseas working experiences and perhaps falling in love with someone overseas. Australians will migrate overseas for those reasons and overseas doctors will come here for those reasons. But we should not be in a position where we are out in the international market, desperate to recruit doctors because we simply do not have enough.

There is another major issue on which this government, Minister Abbott style, shrugs its shoulders, wanders around and never gets anything done. It is an issue this government needs to address. It talks a fair bit about it but never translates that talk into policy action. That issue is the question of regulation of specialists by specialist colleges—in particular their ability to restrict the supply and distribution of specialists. It might strike some as a grand irony that, in an environment where this Howard government is contemplating—and, indeed, is undoubtedly going to put into this parliament—a package of extreme industrial relations changes, all of which are about breaking down workers’ rights and the trade union movement, it can take a different stance when it comes to looking at questions relating to our medical work force. It has struck me that way. The Howard government can take that stance in relation to the work force overall—when it comes to shop assistants, cleaners, factory workers, farmhands and all the people who make up our work force—but, when it comes to looking at questions relating to our medical work force and, particularly, to the way specialist colleges control the supply and distribution of specialists, it does not want to know. If a craft union restricted supply and training places, the Howard government would raise the issue in question time and it would think it was a big scandal. But it sits around doing very little—indeed, precious little at all—when it comes to the fact that we have a major problem—not having enough specialists—and part of that problem has been driven by work force restrictions on supply and distribution from specialist training colleges.

That might strike you as a controversial statement, Mr Deputy Speaker Lindsay, but the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission came to the same view when it looked at this area. It is an area that needs to be addressed. If we can train the right number of specialists and provide specialist training places in regional hospitals, then the specialists trained in those hospitals are more likely to locate there over the longer term than to cluster around our central business districts. Consequently, it is an important part of government policy to ensure that we are training the right number of specialists and that those training places are distributed in an appropriate pattern across Australia to meet our needs.
