Minister, isn’t it a fact that the CEO of Telstra told the Telstra board that Australia lags behind its international peers in terms of investment, the take-up of broadband services, pricing and capacity, and that Australia is in the bottom quartile of developed countries in terms of its telecommunications services? Isn’t it also a fact that the Telstra CEO told the government that fixing the communications problems in the city and the bush in their initial phase would cost $5.7 billion? With a task so vast, isn’t the only way to future proof Telstra’s services to keep Telstra in public ownership?

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGAURAN

talk.start.para: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. The answer is no.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer outline to the House recent information on wage costs? What are the implications of this data for the inflation outlook? Are there any measures that can be taken to further improve labour market outcomes?

—I thank the honourable member for Corangamite for his question. I can inform him that the labour price index for the June quarter of this year showed a slight acceleration of wage costs, rising four per cent through the year to the June quarter of 2005, which was marginally up from the 3.9 per cent through the year to the March quarter of 2005. These wage costs show that there are real wage increases going on in the community but they are restrained and consistent with low inflation, provided the economy maintains productivity growth. Indeed, the Reserve Bank governor, in his testimony last Friday, noting that the wage cost index was 3.9 per cent, described it as ‘remarkably well behaved’.

answer.para: The member for Corangamite also asked about measures to improve labour market outcomes. I know that this is of real interest to him because he asked the Governor of the Reserve Bank questions to this effect in Melbourne on Friday. The governor was asked why Europe was showing slow economic growth compared to Australia. The Governor of the Reserve Bank said:

quote.para: I think the biggest single explanation is that they have very old-fashioned, heavily overregulated economies.

One of the forms of heavy regulation in Europe is labour market regulation. It is extraordinarily heavy labour market regulation, most of which has the effect—as a lot of regulations do—of protecting the insiders at the expense of the outsiders. So the people in the jobs are very heavily protected, while people trying to get in find it very difficult. That is why they are all running 10 per cent unemployment.

answer.para: The Reserve Bank governor’s view that heavy labour market regulation leads to higher unemployment is not his alone; it is also the view of the IMF, the OECD and this government. It is not the view of the Australian Labor Party, who believe that they know more than the OECD, the IMF or the Reserve Bank governor. The Australian Labor Party believe that ‘the lemon has been squeezed dry’, to use the phrase of the Leader of the Opposition, and that you cannot do any more with labour market improvement. They have given up on creating more jobs and they have given up on having a stronger economy here in Australia. If you want to get outcomes, you have to engage in reform. It is not enough to sit there and prattle on, as the Leader of the Opposition does, and give the game away. Labour market reform in this country will create more jobs, more opportunities and better wages for Australia.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister. Will the Deputy Prime Minister guarantee parity of services for country people following the full sale of Telstra? Will the Deputy Prime Minister insert a legal requirement into the Telstra sale legislation for parity of services across metropolitan, regional and country Australia, or will the Deputy Prime Minister continue to be ‘a lion in Taree and a lamb in Canberra’?

—I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. What I can guarantee is that the government will continue, as we have done over the last nine years, to deliver good services to Australia. We have already delivered over $1 billion in telecommunications infrastructure in Australia. What the government have announced today is a plan to continue to invest billions and billions of dollars in telecommunications services in Australia—in particular, regional Australia—so that we can structure a mechanism that will give certainty and security, not just on the funding of services but also on competition and consumer protection into the future. The package announced today strengthens some of the fundamentals that we, not the Labor Party, put in place. The Labor Party did not put in place the universal service obligation. The Labor Party did not put in place the customer service guarantee. We are going to strengthen those things as part of this package to ensure that telecommunications services are delivered equitably across Australia.

—My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade. Would the minister inform the House of Australian farmers’ contribution to our record trade performance? How is the government helping farmers to export their products?

—I thank the member for O’Connor for his question. He represents a large part of Western Australia, and a lot of rural exports go out of his electorate. The most important thing we can do is to continue to maintain the competitive edge of Australia’s producers and exporters right across the nation, whether they be in the cities or in regional Australia. In regional Australia, which is where the member for O’Connor comes from, despite ongoing drought in some areas, our farmers have been making an enormous contribution to Australia’s export effort. Remember that over the last 12 months Australia has exported $162.3 billion worth of goods and services. That is a record as far as Australia is concerned. In 1995-96, it was $99 billion, and it has gone up to $162.3 billion. Out of interest, the Australian beef industry has contributed $4.8 billion in exports, thanks to the 70,000 Aussie beef farmers, some of them in the member for O’Connor’s electorate. The Australian lamb industry has contributed $1.2 billion to that effort, thanks to the 38,400 lamb producers across Australia, a lot of them from Western Australia. That is a very important contribution.

answer.para: The government are working on a number of fronts to help Australian farmers to export their products and to improve their competitive edge. Obviously, we need to maintain our focus on opening up markets across the world. We also need to maintain our focus on a competitive and efficient environment in Australia, and that includes the telecommunications system across regional Australia. The government’s investment in telecommunications in the past, and what we have proposed today for the future, will continue to help Australia’s exporters to remain globally competitive. A critically important element of this debate is that, under the announcements made by the government today, services will be delivered and guaranteed into the future. Fundamental reforms are needed, and will be delivered, to fund new infrastructure, encourage competition and safeguard services—all important elements of the package.

We are not resting on our laurels. We are not in a policy vacuum, unlike those on the other side of politics. All the ideas for reform and improvement are coming from this side of the House. We will continue to deliver good policy, sound economic management and strategic investment in essential infrastructure so that we can maintain the competitive edge for Australian industry and Australian exporters.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Is the minister aware that $2 million in proceeds from the sale of the first part of Telstra went to Norlink in northern New South Wales? Is the minister aware that, on May 26, Norlink went into voluntary administration? Is the minister also aware that, as of last Thursday morning, online documents still bore the logos of groups which have since sought to distance themselves from Norlink, including the New South Wales Farmers Association and the Northern Rivers Regional Development Board?

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGAURAN

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am not aware of the matters raised. I will take advice and provide information to the shadow minister in due course.
—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer explain how the government uses the proceeds of privatisation? Are there alternative practices?

—I thank the honourable member for Dobell for his question. I can inform the honourable member for Dobell that the proceeds of privatisation which have been received under the administration of this government have been used to retire Labor Party debt—that is, the capital sum has been offset by a reduction in capital liability. When this government was elected the Commonwealth debt was $96 billion. By the end of the financial year just past, this government had reduced Commonwealth debt in net terms by $80 billion.

answer.para: There is no difference between the government and the opposition on privatisation policy. Just to prove the point, I will table the Canberra Times of 25 August 1994, which has this headline: ‘Privatisation vital: Beazley’ The article says:

quote.para: The Minister for Finance, Kim Beazley, made a spirited defence of privatisation in his address to the National Press Club yesterday.

answer.para: The Labor Party do not actually oppose privatisation. In fact, they used to give spirited defences of the practice. But there is a big difference between the privatisation practised by the Labor Party and that practised by this government. When the Labor Party engaged in privatisation—and I was reminded of this by the member for Melbourne yesterday—they spent the entire proceeds in the year of receipt.

Let me give you an example. In October 1993, under Labor the first tranche of the Commonwealth Bank was sold off for $1.7 billion. The Australian Labor Party government spent the full $1.7 billion in October 1993 and then, after they had spent the full $1.7 billion, borrowed another $15 billion to actually finance their budget. Let me give you another example. In July 1995 the Australian Labor Party government privatised Qantas and received $1.5 billion. In the year of receipt, which was 1995-96, they spent the lot so that by the end of the financial year they had no shares and no proceeds and, after spending the lot, borrowed another $12.3 billion to finance their budget.

In relation to all of the privatisation conducted by the Australian Labor Party, they sold the shares, spent the money, ran the budget in deficit and borrowed to fund it as a consequence. There is not one dollar in either asset or reduced debt to show for Labor Party privatisation. In fact, during those privatisations net debt ran up to $96 billion. This government has a very different view. This government has always applied the proceeds of privatisation to the reduction of debt. Net debt, as I said, has been reduced under this government by $80 billion. With the proceeds of the privatisation of Telstra, this Commonwealth government will become debt free in net terms. What a legacy that will be for future generations—not paying back Labor’s debt but building a financial position.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer explain why any hardworking taxi driver would have an interest in buying shares in T3? Is it the case that if the same cab driver bought 2,000 shares in the last round at $7.40 a share he would, after dividends, be nursing a loss of $2,440? Treasurer, hasn’t this government been the worst friend that Telstra shareholders have ever had?

—The first point I would make is that nobody is obliged to buy shares in a privatisation. It is a voluntary activity. If you are making a financial decision, I would say to people to make their own decisions accordingly. The second point I would make is that if you had bought in the first tranche of Telstra you would have not only a capital appreciation but also dividends—in fact, franked dividends.
Ms Gillard interjecting—

—What he did not take into account is that it was not only a high dividend stock, because he did not actually disclose that, but a franked dividend stock—that is, you do not have to pay tax on the franking credits that you receive in relation to your dividends. I would say to people that when the prospectus is issued—and I will not be giving financial information when the prospectus is issued—they should consider their financial position and get advice. If it is a good, long-term investment, I have no doubt that millions of Australians will participate, as they did in the past.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Would the minister explain to the House how the current unfair dismissal laws are costing jobs? Minister, are there any alternative views?

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for McMillan for his question and note his ongoing interest in the role of small businesses in the Latrobe Valley in towns like Warragul and Drouin in creating jobs. Just this week, Australian Business Ltd released a survey of 900 employers which revealed that one-third of the respondents had paid go-away money to get rid of an unfair dismissal claim or knew someone who had.
Mr Fitzgibbon interjecting—

—There have been over 90,000 unfair dismissal applications filed since the system was introduced in 1994, and that does not include those cases where employers have paid go-away money to get rid of the claim. I heard the member for Hunter interjecting earlier. I was interested to read in the Australian yesterday that the member for Hunter said that he was not surprised by this finding from the Australian Business Ltd survey. Of course, we are reminded of what the member for Hunter said in 1998. In 1998 the member for Hunter said on the Small Business Show that unfair dismissal laws cost jobs. He said:

quote.para: Well my wife consistently tells me she could afford to put on one more person or would like to put on one more person, but is fearful of unfair dismissals, she is fearful of going through the barrier to another level of red tape and regulation.

answer.para: That is from the member for Hunter, whose wife has been telling him what a problem these unfair dismissal laws are. The ALP knows this, because just recently the Leader of the Opposition said:

quote.para: The problem that they confront, is when you get a bloke, or a person who is an employee, who’s a con artist, a rorter, who knows that if you can get the small businessman to shut his shop for a couple of days, drag him down to the IRC, put him through the mill it’ll be worth ten grand for him to send you away.

answer.para: Those are the words of the Leader of the Opposition saying that this is a rort and that, if you can get a small businessman to shut up his shop and go down to the IRC, he will pay 10 grand to get rid of the problem.

What these comments from the member for Hunter and the Leader of the Opposition demonstrate is that the Australian Labor Party know that this is bad policy. Yet, knowing that this is bad policy, the Australian Labor Party have voted against this on 41 separate occasions. On one hand they purport to be concerned for small business but, when given the opportunity to actually do something for small business, they will not do it. We will do it. We will do it because this will enable small businesses to employ more Australians.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Treasurer. I refer to the Treasurer’s comment on yesterday’s 7.30 Report in relation to Telstra that the government is ‘not a distressed seller’. Will the Treasurer now make a commitment that the government will not flog Telstra for less than the $5.25 per share assumed in the budget?

—Of course the government is not a distressed seller. The government does not sell Telstra because it needs money. It is not like the Australian Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party sold assets, spent the money and still had to borrow to cover a budget deficit. This is a government—and this is a very important point—that has the budget in surplus. It has net debt which will be totally eliminated and therefore it is not a distressed seller. So that puts the government, on behalf of the Australian taxpayer, in a strong position. It puts the government in a position where it can choose to offer the Telstra shares at a time which will maximise benefits for taxpayers and give a decent investment for private investors. These are matters which will be the subject of commercial judgment. They will be made at an appropriate time, and they will be done in a way in which the government can do it without being rushed into a particular timetable. That is what happens when you have a strong balance sheet. That is what happens when you have good economic management.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister inform the House how the government is assisting with the development of democracy in Iraq? Are there any alternative views?

—I thank the honourable member for Mackellar. I know that she, for one, is a very strong supporter of the evolution of democracy in Iraq, even if not every member of this House is. I think it is well understood by the House that the people of Iraq are working on putting together a constitution which reflects the general wishes of the people of that country. They have made good progress, although I note that the National Assembly of Iraq, which is a democratically elected body, voted on Monday to give a week’s extension to these negotiations.

answer.para: There has been a constructive outreach process which has been supported by the United Nations in putting a constitution together. Indeed, honourable members might be interested to know that a quarter of a million Iraqis have joined in meetings to help draft the constitution, so it has been a very open and inclusive process. There are now around 550 voter registration centres enrolling voters for a constitutional referendum which is scheduled to be on 15 October. If that takes place, that will be another act of democracy which will come on top of the 8½ million people who went out to vote on 30 January.

I know the situation in Iraq is still difficult—no-one has any illusions about that—but I also know one thing about our approach to this, and that is that we are champions of democracy. We are on the side of democracy and we want to see the evolution of democratic institutions in Iraq. That is what we want to see. I think that slowly but surely Iraq is heading in that direction.

Let me just say in conclusion that some people, such as the Leader of the Opposition—and I was asked about alternative views—think that the international community should set a timetable for withdrawal from Iraq of military forces. I think that is the wrong policy. I think that is a policy which is wrong-headed. I think the right policy is to set benchmarks to make sure that we achieve certain objectives and, when those objectives have been achieved, we should, of course, be able to withdraw. That is what many people have said. We hope that the time when those benchmarks, such as the training of the Iraqi defence forces, will all have been achieved will be sooner rather than later, but we will wait to see.

talk.start.para: Mr Beazley interjecting—

—The Leader of the Opposition constantly interjects. On this issue, he is profoundly—and I say there is one word that sums up his approach—weak. That is what you are—weak. There are 20 million people out there who know it. The member for Griffith, by the way, I think has some sympathy for our view, and that was revealed in Bernard Lagan’s book. That book has not had much of a run but it is a good book. On 25 May 2004 the member for Griffith said: ‘When we took the decision about troop withdrawal by the end of the year, we took it because we felt it was the right thing to do.’ The member for Griffith said that they took the decision because it was ‘the right thing to do’. That is what he told the Australian public. But Bernard Lagan revealed that Rudd ‘desperately wanted to persuade the Labor leader not to set a Christmas deadline,’ and, when he did, ‘Rudd was infuriated.’ The member for Griffith said one thing to the Australian public, but behind the scenes he was pursuing a completely different policy. What are we left with? We are left with the shambles of a policy on Iraq by a Leader of the Opposition whose greatest pretence is that he knows something about international security. When it comes to international security, he is a phoney and he is weak.
—Before I call the member for Perth, I remind the Minister for Foreign Affairs that he should desist from using the word ‘you’.

—My question is to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and it relates to the government’s proposed industrial relations legislation. Is it not the case that on Monday the minister said:

quote.para: I’m sure there will be a Senate inquiry ... I’m the one who’s making the suggestion we have a Senate inquiry. So we’ll have one and it will be something of the government’s doing.

question.para: Has the minister seen comments by Senator George Brandis—who has labelled the minister’s proposal as ‘stupid’—that:

quote.para: There’s nothing in this for us ...
It won’t have any public purpose.

question.para: Minister, will there or won’t there be a Senate inquiry?

talk.start.para: —In calling the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, I inform him that he is not required to respond to a colleague’s comments.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: —As the Prime Minister pointed out in answer to a similar question, we on this side of the House have great respect for the Senate. It is a very worthy institution and a very important part of this parliament—and far be it from me to tell the Senate what to do.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Would the minister inform the House of the economic benefits of a national system of workplace relations? Are there any alternative views?

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: —It is nice to get a question of substance from this side of the House. I thank the member for Mitchell for his question. It was a delight to be in his electorate a couple of weeks ago and to meet with many of his supporters and the small business people in the electorate of Mitchell.

answer.para: In reply to the member for Mitchell, I inform the House that currently there are six state and federal IR systems that operate in Australia. That means that we have more than 4,000 awards operating in this country, which means that there are an estimated 40,000 different wage rates in Australia. In fact, it was recently estimated that there is around one award wage classification for every 27 employees in Australia. This is a system that is strangled by red tape. Imagine for a moment that Australia had six different income tax systems with 40,000 different tax rates. We would say that that was a system which was absolutely absurd—and that is true of this system of workplace relations.
Figures in the labour movement recognise this problem. This week the Premier of Victoria, Mr Bracks, argued:

quote.para: ... let’s fix the duplication, let’s fix the different systems. In doing that you can take about a quarter off regulation, and that’s pretty useful for our productivity.

answer.para: So here is the Premier of Victoria saying, ‘Let’s fix this sort of duplication.’ Unfortunately and disappointingly, we have the Premier of Victoria, on the other hand, out there supporting the other states to retain their duplicated workplace relations systems. But Premier Bracks is not the only person from the labour movement who recognises the problem. In 2002 at the National Press Club, Mr Bill Shorten, who is the Secretary of the Australian Workers Union and the putative member for Maribyrnong—

talk.start.para: —The putative something else too, I think.
—Yes, the putative something else too, Prime Minister. At the National Press Club, Mr Shorten said:

quote.para: Variations in state laws are also time-consuming and frustrating for employers. It is ridiculous there are more than 130 pieces of state and federal legislation pertaining to industrial law.

answer.para: That is what the Secretary of the Australian Workers Union was complaining about in a speech to the National Press Club a couple of years ago. Just recently we saw the Leader of the Opposition on the same platform with Mr Shorten saying, ‘We’ve got many union leaders in parliament and there are going to be many more.’ One of them wants his job, I know. But if the Leader of the Opposition is going to listen to the likes of Mr Shorten about the absurd confusion and duplication of legislation that we have now, then he ought to listen to us on the subject. Having a single system of industrial relations in Australia is something whose time has come, and it is something on which we will act, in the national interest, to seek to achieve.

talk.start.para: —Order! I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon members of a congressional delegation from Argentina, led by Senator Escudero. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

speech.para: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. It follows the previous question to him, which asked for his attitude to alternative approaches to those of the government on industrial relations policy. Has the minister seen comments by Western Australian state National Party President, Wendy Duncan, that the extreme policy changes he proposes could create instability for businesses, particularly the plan to exempt businesses employing fewer than 100 people from unfair dismissal laws, and that:

quote.para: If the dismissal is unfair then workers should have some redress.

question.para: Minister, if the President of the Western Australian National Party does not support the government’s extreme industrial relations changes, why should the Australian people?

talk.start.para: —Order! In calling the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, let me say that he is not obliged to reflect on comments by a person in another state.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker—
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The question referred to comments from the Western Australian state National Party president, Wendy Duncan:

quote.para: If the dismissal is unfair then workers should have some redress.

answer.para: Why is that not in order?

talk.start.para: —The question is allowed with regard to the substance of the question. The minister is not required to comment on another person’s particular comments.

—The reality is that these are not extreme laws. What the government is proposing is the further, incremental improvement of workplace relations in Australia. When these proposals are passed through the parliament, Australia will still have a more regulated system of industrial relations than countries such as the United Kingdom and New Zealand. That is the reality. Those countries which have adopted a more flexible system of workplace relations—and the United Kingdom is an example of this—have lower levels of unemployment and have more of their people in work. That is the reality.

answer.para: The UK has lower levels of unemployment. Tony Blair, the modern Labour leader in the UK, told the first meeting of the Trades Union Congress when he became the Labour leader that he was not going to make changes to what Margaret Thatcher had put in place. He said he was not going to make those changes, because it had led to a better outcome for the working men and women of Great Britain. That is what we are on about as well. The contrast to that are those countries that still retain inflexible and rigid workplace relations systems. Look at Germany, France and Spain, which have unemployment—
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —They do not want to hear this.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The question asked about the Western Australian state National Party president—
—Is the member for Grayndler asking on relevance?
—Yes. You ruled that that was inappropriate at the same time as you have ruled that it is okay for them to ask about alternative views—
—The member for Grayndler will resume his seat! The minister was answering the question and the minister is in order.

—What I was pointing out to the House is that those countries that retain inflexible and rigid systems of workplace relations—and the examples are Germany, France and Spain—have unemployment rates today of over 10 per cent. Conversely, those countries that have moved to a more flexible workplace relations system have lower levels of unemployment. At the end of these changes we will still have a more regulated system than, for example, Great Britain. These changes—
Mr Beazley interjecting—

—Talk about displaying his ignorance. The Leader of the Opposition says, ‘No, we won’t.’ No we won’t have a more regulated system than Great Britain? Collective bargaining is not something that you have as of right in Great Britain, but it is something that we have in our system. That interjection shows once again that the Leader of the Opposition is simply ignorant on these matters. He does not know what he is talking about—weak, incompetent, ignorant.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Minister, how is the government helping older Australians through Strengthening Medicare?
—The Minister for Health and Ageing.
—Minister, are there any alternative policies?
—Order! In order to assist the chair, could the member repeat his question? There was so much noise that I could not hear the question.
—Mr Speaker, it is an important principle that any member in the House should be allowed to ask their question without being forced by a minister to add to or detract from it.
—In response to the Chief Opposition Whip, I say that the chair had great difficulty in hearing the question.

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I accept you may not have heard and that the minister may not have heard. I heard and I have got no objection to the question being restated in identical terms, but certainly I would have an objection to it being changed. So if it is identically repeated that will not be a problem.
—I am pleased that the Manager of Opposition Business has very good hearing, but, in order to assist some other members in this chamber, I would ask the member for Wakefield to restate his question.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Ageing. How is the government helping older Australians through Strengthening Medicare, and are there any alternative policies?
—Order! The member for Wakefield has not completed his question. Member for Grayndler, do you have a point of order?
—I do, Mr Speaker. The member for Wakefield has repeated his question and he added one word: ‘and’. What we cannot have, Mr Speaker—
—There is no point of order.

—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: we cannot have a situation whereby members can ask a question, the minister being asked the question can suggest a change to that member and then the member is allowed to add to the question. That is unacceptable.
—If the member for Grayndler would just show a little bit of patience, we might actually hear the question. I am still waiting to hear it.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. My question is to the Minister for Health and Ageing, who I am sure has very good hearing. Minister, how is the government helping older Australians through Strengthening Medicare, and are there any alternative policies?

—I do appreciate the member for Wakefield’s question, Mr Speaker. My lip-reading skills were required at times! As this House knows, this is a government which does not just talk about Medicare; this government put in place the sensible improvements necessary to make a good system even better. Thanks to the government’s bulk-billing incentives, I can inform the member for Wakefield that almost 85 per cent of GP consultations with people over 65 are now bulk-billed, thanks to the policies of the Howard government. And, thanks to the Howard government’s higher private health insurance rebate for seniors, fewer older people need hard-pressed beds in public hospitals.

answer.para: I have been asked about alternative policies. The member for Lalor’s only policy remains something called Medicare Gold. She told Meet the Press recently that everyone in Labor—

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am always happy to debate health policy with the minister, but the original form of the question—and this is the debate we were having before—just asked him about what the government was doing; it did not ask him to canvass alternatives. It is not our fault they cannot read.
—The minister is in order.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. You ruled out a previous question because it asked for a comment on a statement by somebody outside the parliament. How is it that you are now going to allow the minister, in response to a question artificially confected, as we know—but that point of order has been dealt with; incorrectly, I think, but dealt with—
—Member for Fraser, is this a point of order?

—I am raising a different point of order. I am saying that it cannot be in order to ask the minister to comment on statements by people who are explicitly ruled out in House of Representatives Practice as people about whom questions cannot be asked, by the artificial—

—The member for Fraser will resume his seat, and I will rule on the point of order. The minister has been asked a question. At no stage in the question did it ask him to respond to any particular person’s comments. So the minister is in order.

—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: the answer cannot be relevant to the question if the question was not allowed to refer to comments by specific people, as you have now ruled people are not entitled to do.
—The member for Fraser is well aware—
—You cannot have it both ways, Mr Speaker.
—The member for Fraser will resume his seat. He is well aware that there is only one standing order that applies to answers. The minister is in order.
—I have been asked about alternative policies.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I certainly have been asked about alternative policies, and that is well and truly in accordance with the practice of this House. The only policy of the member for Lalor is something called Medicare Gold. She told Meet the Press recently that everyone in Labor believes in the principles of Medicare Gold. That is quite odd, because the former chief of staff for the Leader of the Opposition called Medicare Gold ‘a strategic disaster’. The Labor intellectual Peter Botsman said of Medicare Gold that it was a policy with the head of a donkey and the body of a wombat. The President of the Labor Party himself, Barry Jones, said that Medicare Gold was a ‘turkey’, and even the Leader of the Opposition said about Medicare Gold that it ‘disappeared with Mark’. So everyone, according to the member for Lalor, believes in it, except unimportant people like the party president and the party leader—

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is a point of order that has been raised with you by the Manager of Opposition Business and me outside this chamber—that is, the use of ‘and are there any alternative views’. In this case, the member for Wakefield may well have had it in his draft. He certainly did not ask it when he originally asked the question, and this is leading to—
—The member for Grayndler will resume his seat. The member for Grayndler would be well aware that the member for Wakefield has asked a question, and it did include that. The minister is in order.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. With respect, it is very clear that the person who asked the question, the member for Wakefield, did not ask the second part of the question, and I would ask you to have a look at the videotape of the question. You will see the minister turning around, prompting the member for Wakefield to ask the second part of the question.

—I will respond to the member for Melbourne Ports. The member for Melbourne Ports raises a point about the question. As he would be well aware, the member for Wakefield did take two attempts to ask a question, but he was the only member who had the call and he therefore completed his question. So the minister is in order.
—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: the member for Wakefield asked his question and you called—
—There is no point of order.

—After the member for Wakefield asked his question, he resumed his seat and you called the Minister for Health and Ageing. You gave him the call. He then turned to the member for Wakefield to try and change the question—
—Order! The member for Grayndler will resume his seat! The minister is in order. Has the minister completed his answer?
—Almost, Mr Speaker. I know members opposite are very touchy about their lack of a health policy—

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I think I was the one to take the initial point of order on the question, drawing your attention to the fact that all honourable members should be allowed to ask their question without being pressured by the minister. You have now, in your last ruling, conceded that, in repeating the question, the member for Wakefield has added to the original question by asking for alternative views. I do not believe it follows the spirit of your invitation for people to add to the answer when you invite them to repeat the question. They must, and can only, repeat the original question. That is what is causing so much concern on this side of the House—the principle that ministers should not harass members.
—The Chief Opposition Whip will resume his seat. He has made his point of order. I believe the minister has completed his answer.

—My question is to the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads. I refer to the minister’s claim in today’s Age newspaper that there was no record of correspondence from the former Deputy Prime Minister’s senior adviser interfering in the departmental assessment of the $1.2 million Primary Energy grant. Does the minister stand by that claim? If so, can the minister explain why just last Friday in the Senate, under oath, two senior officers from the minister’s own department could remember the correspondence and revealed he imparted a sense of urgency about the grant approval? Minister, did you mislead the press, or did your department mislead the Senate?

talker.name: Lloyd, Jim, MP
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads
talker.name: Mr LLOYD

talk.start.para: —Here we go again. Once again, the member for Hotham has trotted out these unsubstantiated old allegations. I think it is more about him trying to prop up his preselection than worrying about good government policy. I am advised that my department has carefully checked its records, and there is no record or evidence of any such letter from Mr Langhorne to Ms Riggs regarding the Primary—
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The question specifically asked for correspondence—not specifically a letter, Minister. Now, be careful about this—
—The member for Hotham will resume his seat. The minister is in order.

—I will again state that I am advised by my department that it has carefully checked its records, and there is no record or evidence of any such letter from Mr Langhorne to Ms Riggs regarding the Primary Energy application, on 27 July or on any other date.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. What is the government doing to give ASIO the powers it needs to collect information about terrorist activity in Australia? Could the Attorney further advise what safeguards are in place to ensure that these powers are used appropriately?

—I thank the member for Casey for his question. Obviously, ASIO’s questioning and detention powers were developed with an awareness of the need to protect our community from the threat of terrorism without unfairly encroaching on the rights of individuals. Questioning warrants are particularly useful where the threat of terrorism is immediate and other methods of intelligence collection will be either too slow or ineffective at obtaining information about suspicious activity. The questioning and detention process is subject to quite strict legislative requirements, which include clear time limits as well as the following safeguards. Strict criteria must be satisfied before a warrant can be issued. A warrant is issued by an independent issuing authority who is a federal judge or a magistrate. Strict time limits on the period of questioning apply—up to 24 hours, or 48 hours if an interpreter is required. The length of detention, to ensure that people remain available for questioning, can be for up to seven days—the period in which questioning in that 24- or 48-hour period can proceed. There is a right to seek a remedy in the Federal Court at any time. Supervision of questioning by an independent prescribed authority occurs, and that is a person who has had judicial experience. Criminal offences for officials who breach safeguards are included in the act. The ability of the subject of a warrant to contact the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security or the Commonwealth Ombudsman at any time to make a complaint about ASIO or the Australian Federal Police is also available as a remedy.

answer.para: Unfortunately, there is a good deal of misinformation and, some might say, misunderstanding about the way the powers operate. If people perpetuate these myths, it could lead to unjustified concern in the community. For example, the suggestion that the laws allow the authorities to ‘disappear’ somebody is completely without foundation. Warrants authorising detention must permit the person to contact others, including a lawyer of the person’s choice. ASIO is a very professional organisation. It uses its powers to protect the Australian community judiciously and effectively, and only as a last resort.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads. How does evidence of direct interference in the departmental assessment of the Primary Energy grant by the former Deputy Prime Minister’s senior staffer stack up against the minister’s previous claim that he alone acted as the decision maker?

talker.name: Lloyd, Jim, MP
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads
talker.name: Mr LLOYD

talk.start.para: —I acted with integrity and honesty in coming to a ministerial decision to sign off on the funding for Primary Energy.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —They do not want to listen to the answer, do they! I made that decision based entirely on the material that was provided to me by the department in a minute that I studied and I signed off on 2 August 2004. This is just continual muckraking from the Labor Party. I would like to point out what the community thinks about this muckraking and this politically motivated Senate inquiry.
—Table the minute.
—Order! The minister has the call.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This material has absolutely nothing to do with the question he was asked, which he has evaded.
—There is no point of order. The minister has the call.
—On Friday, 12 August 2005, in the well-respected Central Coast Express Advocate, the editorial was about the Senate inquiry into Regional Partnerships. It said:

quote.para: The whole inquiry is a political witch hunt staged by the Labor Party because it is still smarting over its poor performance at the last election.

talk.start.para: Mr Beazley interjecting—
—The Leader of the Opposition does not have the call.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: could you ask the minister to table the document from which he quoted?
—Was the minister quoting from a confidential document?
Mr Lloyd interjecting—
—Mr Speaker, I heard the minister’s response. I am not talking about the newspaper clipping. I am obviously talking about the quote in relation to the minute.
—Was the minister quoting from a confidential document?
Mr Lloyd interjecting—

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Science and Training. Would the minister update the House on the government’s plans to ensure that parents receive plain language report cards on their child’s progress at school?

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Kingston for his question. He is working hard for Reynella East and Hackham West primary schools in his electorate. The Prime Minister and I announced early last year the conditions that would be placed on Australian government funding for schooling over the next four years: firstly, national consistency in Australian schooling from starting age to common testing throughout the milestones of school education; secondly, that the performance of Australian schools will be published and made available for the communities within which those schools are based; thirdly, that there would be plain language reporting to parents about the progress of their children so that parents have a very clear idea about how their children are performing at school.

answer.para: Something seems to have happened over the last generation in that the educational bureaucrats and ideologues have grabbed control of the school bus and forced parents to sit in the back seat with commonsense, so much so that today in Australian schools many parents are receiving language neutered, politically correct, meaningless reports that tell them absolutely nothing about the progress of their children. The Australian government’s legislation, which was passed late last year, requires plain language reporting to parents. That means that parents will receive reports next year that tell them that their child will be rated A, B, C, D or E in specific subjects. Further to that, Australian parents in any school that receives funding from the Australian government will be told how their children are performing compared to other children in the class and across Australia.

It was rather interesting that I read yesterday in the Sydney Morning Herald about the announcement of the recently installed Premier of New South Wales, Mr Iemma, in response to the Australian government’s initiative that the New South Wales government will require A, B, C, D and E reporting for primary schools. I should inform the New South Wales government that they are ‘moving in the right direction’, to use their terminology. However, they will also need to do it for the compulsory years of schooling, which means up to and including year 10. The Premier said this at his announcement:

quote.para: “My daughter got a school report a couple of months ago, and on first reading, we saw all As and we thought ‘Terrific’...

answer.para: The Sydney Morning Herald article continued:

quote.para: However, on closer reading, “and it took quite some reading”, the Iemmas were far less sure what they were looking at.

answer.para: It continued:

quote.para: “Where is our daughter in maths and English in relation to her schoolmates in her class?” Mr Iemma said

answer.para: When looking at a New South Wales school report today, the Premier would be forgiven for having that attitude. Kids are ranked ‘working towards’, ‘almost achieving’ and ‘achieved’. An ‘A’ in modern education speak is ‘achieved’. Imagine the Prime Minister ringing Bob Jane during the Bathurst 1000 and asking, ‘How’s Skaifey going?’ He does not want to be told he is ‘almost achieving’. What does that mean? Is he off the starting line or can he see the chequered flag? If the foreign minister rings Richie Benaud and asks, ‘How’s Ricky Ponting going?’ he does not want to be told that he is ‘consolidating’. In response to these conditions of funding, New South Wales, Western Australia and Tasmania have basically signed up for these conditions. Unless they have these plain language reports by New Years Eve this year, they will not receive a dollar of Commonwealth funding for schooling next year.

I notice that the Tasmanian Essential Learnings report card—I do not know why they cannot just say ‘subjects’, by the way—says ‘being literate’. The average parent would say, ‘What does being literate mean? Does that mean reading and writing? Why can’t they say it?’ There is also ‘reflective thinking’—something that perhaps the member for Franklin is doing at the moment. The reality is that Mr Mark Latham had many faults, but when he delivered his assessment of his Labor colleagues, he did so in plain language—A-grade something or other—because he knew that everyday Australians trying to feed their kids and pay their car loans knew exactly what that meant.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

talker.name: Mr McGAURAN,MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGAURAN

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I wish add to an answer. Earlier in question time, the member for Wills, as part of the Labor Party’s scintillating attack of the government on Telstra issues, asked me a question about Norlink Communications. I am now in a position to be able to provide a comprehensive answer to his inquiry.

speech.para: The history and background of this is that Norlink Ltd was formed by the Lismore City Council, together with other councils in the region, the Southern Cross University and several other community bodies from the Northern Rivers district. It in turn formed Norlink Communications Ltd as the operating company for the telecommunications business. The project received seed funding of $1½ million, announced in July 2001, from the Networking the Nation program to improve telecommunications in this region. Importantly—the member for Wills may not know this, or he omitted to include it as part of his answer—the New South Wales state government also contributed towards funding of the project. The purpose of the project was to provide high bandwidth data and voice services over wireless local loop to three towns in the region, Kyogle, Maclean and Mullumbimby.

The member for Wills will be interested to know, as part of the background and make-up of the issue, that difficult terrain between Lismore and Kyogle delayed construction of the Kyogle base station. Equipment to achieve this connection was purchased early in 2005. Norlink provides enhanced telecommunications services to 17 towns, well in excess of the target of three towns. Telstra’s early provision of ADSL to Maclean enabled Norlink to give priority to other communities.

Norlink chose to call in administrators to take over management of the company, I am advised, because of the concerns it had about a long-term dispute with one of its suppliers, Soul Pattinson Telecommunications, regarding payment for its services and issues that Norlink Communications Ltd had in terms of those services. I am advised that yesterday, 16 August, creditors signed a deed of arrangement in regard to Norlink Communications Ltd, so it is now under administration. Norlink’s fixed line service based on the resale of Telstra services has been sold as part of the restructure. This was an additional business activity beyond the purposes for which Norlink was granted Networking the Nation funds.

In conclusion, I am advised that it is the intention of the administrators to continue to run and further develop the high bandwidth data and voice services over wireless local loop for which Norlink received Networking the Nation funding.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Pathetically and grievously and on two occasions.
—Please proceed.

—The first occasion was by the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations when he suggested that a quote from me showed support on my part for the government’s policy on unfair dismissals. That was completely erroneous. What that quote supported was a set of Labor propositions to ensure that unfair dismissal legislation worked both in favour of employers and employees.

speech.para: The second piece of misrepresentation was from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, who suggested it was weak that we held a position which said that the government should have the same sort of exit strategy for Iraq that it has got for Afghanistan. What is weak is having some other country give you an exit strategy for your troops, and that is the position of the government.

talk.start.para: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition has made his personal explanation.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a matter of privilege. I have today received an email and fax from Mike Berwick, Mayor of Port Douglas Shire Council, threatening legal action should I raise certain matters in this House relating to allegations I put before the Crime and Misconduct Commission. By way of background, on 3 August I met with Peter Jones, principal complaints officer, and Russell Pearce, acting director of the Queensland Crime and Misconduct Commission, in their Brisbane office. At that meeting I presented a 19-page submission containing 16 serious allegations and supporting documentary evidence outlining corruption, abuse of power, misappropriation of federal funds and conflicts of interest involving council matters and federal funding.
—This would be a Regional Partnerships program.
—These matters are only some of those that have been brought to my attention over the past few months—
—This is one of Jim Lloyd’s grants.
—Order! The member for Melbourne is warned!

—by a number of members of the community, including concerned people from my area in the Hunter Valley. Last night I submitted the matter to Peter McGauran, the federal Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, to investigate the allegations of misappropriation of federal funds. I consider that the Crime and Misconduct Commission and the minister’s office are at this stage the best avenues through which to conduct the investigations. However, it is my duty, both as a member of this parliament and in my capacity as Chair of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, to refer this matter to both the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit and the Auditor-General for further investigation.

speech.para: The threats from Mr Berwick are clearly intended to intimidate me in my right to freedom of speech in carrying out my role as a member in this House, a right confirmed in section 49 of the Constitution, adopted from the ninth article of the Bill of Rights of 1688, as outlined on page 711 of the House of Representatives Practice and as reinforced on page 731.

I table the threatening letter and email from Mike Berwick and the submission put to the Crime and Misconduct Commission and to the federal minister, Peter McGauran. Mr Speaker, I would submit to you that a prima facie case exists for investigation of this matter and, after your analysis, I ask that it be referred to the Privileges Committee of this parliament. As you would be aware, Mr Speaker, I am a member of the Privileges Committee and, as such, I will now suspend myself as a committee member from any matter pertaining to this so as to avoid any possible conflict of interest arising.

talk.start.para: —The member for Paterson raises a very serious issue of privilege. I will consider that matter carefully and report back to the House.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the member claim to have been misrepresented?
—On two occasions.
—Please proceed.
—On both occasions by the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Yesterday in the Australian I said this:

quote.para: Labor has long acknowledged the issue of go-away money and has for some time been advocating procedural changes to rid the economy of the problem ...
Unfortunately, the Government wants to take the lazy and unfair option of totally denying those with a genuine grievance any protection at all.

talk.start.para: —The member will get to where he has been misrepresented.
—‘This option is likely to be worse for small business operators’—
—No, the member will get to where he has been misrepresented.

—‘because many of the vexatious claimants will take the ‘unlawful dismissal’ path, which will prove more complex and expensive for small firms.’ By selectively and mischievously quoting from a single part of the article, the minister misrepresented me.

speech.para: On the other occasion, in answer to the same dorothy dixer from the other side, the minister purported to deliver a quote from me—words I supposedly said five years ago on a small business show that does not exist any more. The interesting thing about this is that every time a minister in this place—

talk.start.para: —The member will come to where he has been misrepresented.
—shares this quote with the House it seems to change. The minister should be forced to authenticate the complete quote or apologise to me and the House.

—Mr Speaker, could I ask you to reflect on a number of the rulings that you made in question time today. Could I put to you the very simple point that it cannot be in order for questions to invite a minister to speculate on the alternate views of persons unnamed if it is out of order for a question to ask a minister about the alternate view of persons named. Either both are in order or both are out of order. We have got to the absurd situation where the government’s formulation—and, Mr Speaker, you are familiar with it, as am I—asks ministers to canvass alternate views whereas, on your present rulings, it is impossible for the opposition to ask ministers about the views even of people within their own parties. That cannot be a consistent interpretation of the standing orders. I am not asking you to rule on it now. I think it is a matter which requires reflection. I would ask you to do that, and we might be able to discuss it further later today.

—I thank the Manager of Opposition Business for her question. I would first make the observation that the practice of asking for alternate views is something that has been the practice in this parliament since the days of the Keating government. On the other point, I will look at the matter further and report back as appropriate.

—Mr Speaker, just on that point, can I say this to you: in the days of the Keating government, and even in the early days of this government, I would be able to take you to a number of questions, which were allowed and ruled in order, which asked ministers about the views of people within their own party or the views of people outside. Indeed, I am carrying one with me now from 1996.
—The member has made her point. I responded accordingly.

subdebateinfo.title: Availability of Statements by Mr Speaker

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I know that when you make a statement to the House it is available the next day in Hansard, but for those who are interested in the statement that you make it can be very difficult to obtain a copy. Can I ask that, when you do make statements to the House, copies of those statements be available for interested members rather than them having to look for the greens or waiting until the next day.
—I thank the Chief Opposition Whip. I will ensure that he gets a copy shortly.

motionnospeech.name: Mr ABBOTT
motionnospeech.inline: —Documents are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the documents will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Wills proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The Government’s plans to sell Telstra and its squandering of the proceeds of the partial sale of Telstra.

subdebate.1.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —Today we have heard that the government is getting set to sell Telstra and that the National Party is all set to fall into line, in particular Queensland National Party senator Barnaby Joyce—Backdown Barnaby. This must be a world record for the shortest time ever spent as a maverick in the Senate. They should put it on that Sunday night TV show Australia’s Guinness world records. Barnaby Joyce arrives in Canberra last week. He gets shirt fronted by Senator Heffernan and the member for O’Connor, old Ironbar. Five minutes later, what remains? Barnaby Rubble. Five minutes of political sunshine, Barnaby. Hope you enjoyed it.

speech.para: The National Party is always ready to sell out its constituency provided the price is right. We on this side of the House always knew they would sell out, because that is the nature of the National Party. Now they are led by a former auctioneer. Some people might think this is highly appropriate—a political party that will sell anything provided the price is right being led by an auctioneer. But he is a strange kind of auctioneer: Telstra offered $5 billion and he sold for $3 billion. I don’t know about you, but I would not want him selling my house. The pity and the tragedy of it is that the Leader of the National Party is selling off something of far more value—an asset Australians have built up over the course of a century and something which, once it is lost, can never be regained.

The members of the National Party will be out there trying to claim that this is a win. At least Backdown Barnaby has the grace to still maintain that Telstra should not be sold, that the best interests of Australians would be served by Telstra continuing to remain in majority public ownership. But the rest of The Nationals will be out there claiming that there is now $3 billion available to compensate country people for the loss of the publicly owned Telstra—$1 billion for capital investment and $2 billion for a fund to pay for upgrades to the rural telecommunications network.

The first point that ought to be observed here is that telecommunications is not just an issue for rural and regional Australia. The sale of Telstra is not just bad for country Australia; it is bad for all of Australia. There is no suggestion that the outer metropolitan areas, for example, are going to get anything out of this. All they will get is poorer services and higher charges. But the National Party will be out there spruiking this $3 billion in a ‘never mind the quality, feel the whip’ selling job. But wait, haven’t we heard this before? What became of the money that they got from the first sales of Telstra, which brought in $17 billion and $16 billion respectively? Back then they set up the Natural Heritage Trust to enlist the support of the green groups for the sale. The green groups fell for it and were duly conned—as you always are when you deal with this government.

Firstly, the government slashed spending from the environmental part of the budget on the basis that it was no longer needed on account of Telstra and the Natural Heritage Trust money. Secondly, they turned it into a government slush fund, with the vast majority going to Liberal and National Party held electorates. Thirdly, they wasted the money and failed to deliver real improvements for the Australian environment, which has continued to deteriorate on all the objective measurements during their time in office.

The Auditor-General found it impossible to work out what benefits, if any, Australians got from the Natural Heritage Trust because the government—oops—forgot to monitor the projects and collect any genuine data about the outcomes. They simply handed the money over and walked away—no monitoring, no evaluation.

I have talked about that before. Today, I want to talk about Networking the Nation. As the Howard government prepares to sell the remainder of Telstra, the House needs to ask: what do we have to show for the $3 billion distributed to groups in regional Australia following the T1 and T2 Telstra sales under the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund? Very little of it in fact resulted in infrastructure. Instead, the government handed out large numbers of grants to groups in regional Australia for services rather than for infrastructure. Many of the groups had little expertise or track records. Most were unable to establish viable projects. The opportunity to build regional infrastructure was blown away with a host of grants that have been of little lasting value to regional Australia.

Networking the Nation was one subprogram of the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund, funded with around $500 million of Telstra sale money. In one scathing audit report—and there were several—the Auditor-General found that the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts did not have an appropriate management framework in place to monitor the efficiency and effectiveness of Networking the Nation programs and that it had inadequate needs assessment and risk assessment, a lack of measurable targets and significant numbers of outstanding project reports and acquittals. That was in Audit Report No. 12 2003-04.

Investigations show that much of the money from the first two Telstra sales was wasted. For example, there were 130 taxpayer grants to New South Wales rural projects after the first Telstra sale, but one in four of those grants did not add a single telephone or internet service to the bush. Instead, 27 per cent of the grants funded studies, strategies, needs assessments and training programs. More than $95 million of the telecommunications funding promised to the bush was later withdrawn by the government and counted as savings or spent on other projects.

An audit report into the programs was highly critical of the lack of accountability imposed on those who received the grants. It found that administration costs soaked up 27 per cent of one program to set up 500 rural transaction centres. Yesterday, the well-respected Byron Shire Echo gave a detailed report of what had happened on the North Coast of New South Wales:

quote.para: The Nats made Networking The Nation, in part set up as a ‘social bonus’ of earlier Telstra sales, a very useful pork barrel from 1997 to 2004. The north coast was awash with NTN funds in its heyday. It was probably no hindrance that the chairman of NTN was Doug Anthony, father of then Richmond MP Larry Anthony.

speech.para: It was no hindrance at all. The article then asks the question:

quote.para: But have the NTN funds done anything much to improve telco services on the north coast?

speech.para: The paper asks a very good question. The article continues:

quote.para: Over $2 million in public funds went into Norlink, the internet provider originally supported by local business and community organisations. On May 26 this year Norlink went into voluntary administration ...

Its vision of a series of ‘E-towns’ supported by local councils was not realised and its presence did not make it as far as Kyogle, one of the intended towns. It operated online from MAP, the Mullumbimby ISP it acquired, and offers a wireless service. As of last Thursday morning online documents still bore the logos of groups which have since sought to distance themselves from Norlink. The NSW Farmers Association says it has had no association with Norlink for a number of years and the Northern Rivers Regional Development Board abandoned administrative support to the company in 2000.

speech.para: As the paper also says:

quote.para: What Norlink had achieved is little different to that done by local businesses such as Linknet. No over-arching plan has emerged from NTN to give the bush a wealth of high speed connections.

speech.para: The article also mentions the case of Bangalow businessman Christopher Sanderson, who received $894,000:

quote.para: ... for an online produce marketing service called variously TAFTCO and Grower Direct. An earlier incarnation of Mr Sanderson’s project was the Regional Internet Marketing Cooperative which was involved with the Northern Rivers Agricultural Development Corporation (NORADA), actively promoted by Doug Anthony.
Its efforts to find Asian markets for Australian growers were found wanting by some members of the NSW Farmers Association.

speech.para: The article continues:

quote.para: The ghost of the Grower Direct company still exists online ... Brisbane produce software company Freshcomp Computer Systems, which is linked to the Grower Direct site, told the The Echo it never had an association with the Bangalow company.

speech.para: There was another north coast telco service to benefit from NTN funding, the Southern Cross University’s CoastCall business initiative. It received over $385,000 and ran for a couple of years, with most of the money being spent on administration. Its 2000 report admitted that CoastCall had no success in attracting advertising and that it was not worth hiring reps to go after it. The Echo says:

quote.para: For the most part, NTN funds seem to have disappeared or been—

speech.para: ‘hosed up’; they actually used more robust language—

quote.para: against the e-wall. If the Nats are successful in getting another slush fund, will it all happen again?

speech.para: That is a very good question. As far back as September 1998, the New South Wales Farmers Association’s Coffs Harbour regional branch was using Networking the Nation as an example of its concerns that ‘often grants earmarked to assist the community never reach those they are intended for’. A letter from the association says:

quote.para: After more than 12 months of operating, benefits from over $200,000 of funding are yet to flow on to the farmers. Northern Rivers Agricultural Development Corporation and the Regional Internet Marketing Cooperative continue along their chosen path without any involvement of the farming community.

speech.para: In relation to this failed $894,000 project, there are plenty of questions to be answered by the government. The businessman associated with this grant, Mr Christopher Sanderson, will now not field questions from journalists about the project. When the government is asked to account for this expenditure, it simply emails a link to the Grower Direct web site, which itself has links to other company sites. Those companies have told various media outlets that they never had any association with the company. So the question is: just how was that $894,000 grant money spent? Has any of it found its way into Jindi-Net, a wireless broadband network run from Jindibah—an ‘intentional community’, whatever that means—by none other than Mr Christopher Sanderson, the recipient of the grant money?

Labor will be taking up the fight on this issue. We will require that this and many other Networking the Nation acquittals lodged with the department are produced. It seems that the only thing the community has to show for almost $1 million to improve regional telecommunications is the digital ghost of the Grower Direct web site. It is a shameful legacy that does not augur well for other regional projects meant to compensate the bush for the ghost of Telstra public ownership. Australians throughout country Australia need to be warned. They have been sold a dummy on regional telecommunications infrastructure before and it will happen again.

One of the things that you can be absolutely guaranteed of is that Telstra money will be used to fund a government advertising campaign—money from the sale of a national asset paying for Liberal and National Party propaganda. Last year, the campaign Working to Keep the Country Connected—don’t you love those Orwellian titles?—hit rural and regional airwaves from May to July. Of course it was entirely coincidental that this was in the lead-up to the federal election. That campaign swamped rural and regional TV and radio stations, as well as newspapers, with advertisements to inform people about their telecommunications rights. I am asked about the costs. The total advertising campaign cost in 2003-04 was $5 million. In 2004-05 it was $953,000. So nearly $6 million was spent in total, yet only $73,000 of this amount was spent on printing the booklet—Your Phone Service. Your Rights—that this advertising campaign was supposed to promote.

As it happens, an answer to a question from Senator Faulkner indicates that, despite over $3½ million of taxpayers’ money being spent on TV, radio and newspaper advertising placements, as of 1 June 2004 only 971 calls had been logged at the tel:info helpline. This means that between 9 May and 1 June on average only 40 people per day right across Australia—that is two people per hour—called the helpline at the peak of the advertising campaign. That it is a pathetically low response for a campaign that cost almost $6 million. Since the 2004 election, it has all melted away and is no longer available online—so much for keeping the country connected.

The partial sale of Telstra was a mistake; the complete sale will be a bigger mistake. It is being proposed by people who ought to know better. Networking the Nation simply turned into a National Party pork barrel and millions of taxpayers’ dollars were wasted. If the Howard government privatises the rest of Telstra, the National Party will again turn as much of the proceeds as it can into a National Party slush fund. It will be another massive waste of public money. (Time expired)

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration
talker.name: Dr STONE

talk.start.para: —I am absolutely staggered that Labor would invite the public to hear what they did in their 13 years in government for telecommunications across this great country and what the John Howard led government has willingly undertaken since 1996 to bring back a more equitable system of telecommunications, one that is competitive and one that delivers world-class opportunities to those who have to communicate to survive.

speech.para: I was amused that the member for Wills spent a lot of time in his remarks on the spending of some of the first partial sale of Telstra funds, saying what an appalling thing it was to spend these funds on the biggest environmental program Australia has ever seen. I was parliamentary secretary to the environment minister while the member for Wills was the opposition spokesman for the environment. I remember that he said again and again—it is the only contribution he ever made to environmental debate—that the problem with the Natural Heritage Trust was that Labor seats were not getting enough of it and that there should have been more spending on that magnificent program in Labor held seats. As various reviews showed, the relationship of the allocation of funds matched almost exactly where the seats were in the landscape. It is a simple case that rural and regional voters do not vote for the Labor Party. The seats which have the environmental issues tend to be in the hands of the coalition.

I suppose that is why we were not so surprised that in 1996, when the Labor Party’s telecommunications policy was revealed for all to scrutinise, the word ‘regional’ appeared but once. Not a cent of the Labor Party’s telecommunications policy was committed to telecommunications for rural or regional people—not a cent. Was that because Labor had built up, in the previous 13 years, a magnificent system that served rural, regional and metropolitan Australia? Let us remind ourselves of what telecommunications in Australia was all about under Labor.

talk.start.para: —Shame!

—Indeed. If you had just built a new home or started a new business, and you wanted the phone connected—probably the most important thing you can do in a new business is to have the phone connected—under Labor it took up to 27 months. That is over two years. Can you imagine it?
Mr Hartsuyker interjecting—
(Hon. IR Causley)—The member for Cowper may wish to speak in this debate in a moment.

—Businesses went broke. People gave up and walked away. There were domestic tragedies. There were people who could not cope because, under Labor, they could not get the phone connected at their new home for over two years. That is disgusting. Under a Liberal led coalition, today only 20 days are required to get a new service hooked up to your new home or business. And we are expecting to see that number come down even further. That 27 months compared to 20 days is just one example—and a pretty interesting example—of what happened with telecommunications under Labor. They presided over a Telstra-Optus duopoly that was uncompetitive. The money made went back into those outfits rather than into new technology. There was no universal service obligation in place to make sure that country or suburban people got a fair go; hence, there was a two-year waiting time for a new phone. It was absolutely disgraceful. Let me remind those on the other side of the House what we on this side know—and, because you do not represent rural and regional people, you probably did not realise—that, under Labor, mobile service coverage actually contracted in rural and regional Australia.
—Shame! That was Labor policy.
—I don’t know that it was Labor policy—
—The member for Cowper is warned!

—I suspect it was just that they did not understand what it meant not to be able to use telecommunications in rural and regional areas. So, in a deal done in 1993 with Vodafone, Labor said: ‘We’ll let you do a certain sort of business. We’ll make it viable for you by withdrawing the analog mobile service. It will have to close by the year 2000.’ When we came into government in 1996, we could not undo that contract; the cost to the taxpayer would have been too great. So, right across the country in 2000, analog services were shut down. Thank you, Labor. That was a most appalling decision you made back in 1993. We saw mobile services contract under your regime.

speech.para: The member for Wills was most excited when he listed project after project that had been funded through the partial sale of Telstra in addition to the magnificent environmental program.
