Let us look at what has been done by the Howard led coalition since 1996 by way of improvements in telecommunications. We tackled the problem that we inherited from Labor with three major strategies. The first strategy was to encourage competition to deliver innovation, cheaper prices and greater choice. As a result of our work, the price of phone calls in Australia has come down by 20 per cent since 1996. I will be reminding those opposite of that figure quite a few times.

talk.start.para: —What about line rental costs?
—If the member for Throsby wishes to speak, she can seek the call.

—Our second plank was to establish and maintain a tough regulatory consumer safeguard regime with price controls, a customer service guarantee and the universal service obligation. We do not believe you should simply leave it to the carriers to do as they will. We have put in very tough safeguards and they will continue to be there. That is why we have given a better go for rural, regional and outer-suburban people when it comes to their services. The third plank is targeted funding to improve services, particularly in areas that are not served, or not well served, by the market because, for example, they are very remote or have a very low population density.

speech.para: What have we achieved through the three main planks of our policy? Firstly—and I have already mentioned this—the price of services has fallen by 20 per cent. Customers have greater choice of service provider than ever before. This continues to drive competition, which brings down prices and stimulates innovation, leading to new services being rolled out all the time. We have had some independent evaluation—not in house as the member for Wills suggests—from the Allen Consulting Group. The evaluation was authorised by the Australian Communications Authority and it looked at what the telecommunications reforms have delivered to Australia since 1996. It found the telecommunications reforms have increased the size of the Australian economy by $12 billion. It found we have created approximately 4,000 new jobs with the new competition and the expansion of services, and we have delivered benefits to small business of $1.8 billion. We have not denied them a phone for two years; we have actually delivered benefits to small business of at least $1.8 billion. On average, each Australian household is $759 better off as a result of our telecommunications strategy since 1996.

talk.start.para: —You’ve gotta be joking!
—The member for Throsby is warned!

—That is a very significant saving for households, indeed. There are now more than 100 telecommunications carriers operating in Australia and I am sure there are going to be more. Of course, they compete and help with innovations. There are more than 16 million mobile phones in operation in Australia. People can now choose whether they even install a landline phone in their house or apartment: they can just rely on mobile phones. The number of broadband subscribers in Australia is now well over one million.
Ms George interjecting—
—The member for Throsby will remove herself from the House under standing order 94(a).

speech.para: The member for Throsby then left the chamber.

talk.start.para: —This is an example of the competitive environment we now have: almost half of Telstra’s ADSL subscriptions are wholesale services that are being resold to competitors. Since 1997 the Howard government has committed more than $1 billion to improving telecommunications infrastructure and services in Australia. As I have just shown with that independent evaluation, the $1 billion investment has delivered in manifold ways, in terms of added value and choice, to our great Australian nation.

speech.para: This expenditure has covered programs including Networking the Nation and the social bonus, which came about as a result of our very intensive Besley and Estens inquiries. We always listen hard and we will continue to review. The most recent commitment was for more than $180 million in response to the Estens inquiry. So we have delivered, in the way that I have just described. And what an extraordinary achievement, given what we had to deal with—the neglect of telecommunications under Labor, particularly for rural and regional people who were in despair when it came to trying to do business and run social lives and communities when they simply could not connect.

Today there has been an announcement. It is probably one of the most significant announcements for telecommunications since our initial policy launches in 1996. It is a continuation of the magnificent work that has been ongoing since 1996. It is called Connect Australia. I want to applaud our Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Helen Coonan, who has done a magnificent job, and all of the committees, the Liberal and National Party backbenchers, the middle benchers and the ministers who have worked to make this new policy one of the most significant announcements that we have ever seen in telecommunications services in Australia.

We have reannounced our commitment to first-class communications services for Australia. We will continue to deliver on that promise, with a $1.1 billion roll-out of broadband, new regional clever networks, mobile services and special telecommunications services for Indigenous communities, who are often in the most remote parts of our great country. As well as that $1.1 billion, there will be $2 billion dedicated to a communications fund. This will be established, and the earnings from the fund will be used to provide new communications services for rural Australia.

The government will also provide a more robust regulatory framework for the telecommunications industry. We will not do what Labor did: simply hope and pray that something good will happen. Quite simply, you need a watchdog in this world and we will maintain the strongest of safeguards to protect our consumers. (Quorum formed) Let me say in these last few seconds that you will have to do better than that to shut down the fact that telecommunications in this country were a disgrace before 1996. They were appalling. Now Australia has some equity, some good cost products and some innovative technology. I want to commend our government and particularly Senator Helen Coonan for the magnificent job that she has done. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I simply have to ask, after having listened to the government speaker at the table: if Telstra is so good, why sell it? It is interesting to look through the public media reports of recent weeks. First of all we saw Prime Minister Howard—

speech.para: Government members—Get over it.

talk.start.para: —If you want to come in and join the debate, do so. It is interesting, having looked through the media reports, to have seen of late Prime Minister Howard bullying poor old Sol. We saw Senator Heffernan bullying ‘Backdown Barnaby’, who obviously heard his master’s voice, and we have seen the Nats today again take 30 pieces of silver.
(Hon. IR Causley)—The member for Cowan will refer to members by their title.

—It is interesting indeed that the National Party have obviously plucked, trussed, stuffed and cooked the Telstra goose, and now they simply sit waiting to carve it up. Christmas may be coming early to the bush, but it is the rest of Australia that will be putting the presents under the tree. There is no doubt that Telstra will be sold. Australia will be sold out, and Australian mums and dads will be paying more for poorer services.

speech.para: The interesting thing during most of this debate, one which you would think the National Party would have some real interest in, is that the National Party has been outnumbered in this chamber by the Independents—and there are only two of them. What an absolute disgrace! The sale of Telstra is bad for the bush, bad for the budget and bad for Australia. I pose this question to the government members: if the sale of Telstra is not in the interests of Australian families, how can it possibly be in the national interest? I also want to put this to the government members: if the partial sale of Telstra has been good for Australia, let us see the tangible benefits of the proceeds of that partial sale. Where are they? I challenge the government to tell and show not just the residents of my electorate in the northern suburbs of Perth but all the Australians who live in the fringes of our cities where the benefits of the partial sale have gone.

The government cannot or will not answer that question, but I will. The proceeds of the partial sale have been squandered. They have been squandered on buying votes in the bush and through the bulbous pockets of the government’s spendthrifts, who have wasted countless opportunities for proper and prudent investment in our infrastructure, our services and our future. The proceeds have been squandered by the biggest pork-barrelling government in the history of Australia—squandered and wasted, not invested. The government have not invested in infrastructure, in growth, in their loyal clientele, in the future of our nation, in Telstra’s employees or in the growth of Telstra. Indeed, Telstra has been downgraded and its services have been downgraded by the government in their rush to sell the asset and get their hands on the money.

I had a look at some figures that I used in an earlier debate, which showed that capital expenditure in Telstra had fallen from a peak of $4.75 million in 1999-2000 to an estimated $3.25 million in 2002-03. Where did the investment go? We also know that, during those same years, staff were shed at a rate of some 4,000 full-time employees per year. Is it any wonder that the government benches are almost bare? They certainly do not like to be reminded of these facts.

I recently made some inquiries in Western Australia, because we are constantly, daily, getting complaints from small business people who work from home, from small business people in the industrial areas in the northern suburbs of Perth and from mums that their telephone services are not up to scratch. I was told that there is a department within Telstra called the CNI, which stands for customer network improvement. This department is for the more major faults, not for average repairs. I am told that if a technician attends a fault complaint they often find that the problem is more serious than just fixing the line at one person’s home. If this type of fault is located, the attending technician tries to temporarily fix the problem with the line and then reports the fault to the CNI, the customer network improvement department, and this department fixes the major faults.

There are currently 8,000 to 9,000 outstanding CNI fault reports in the Perth metropolitan area. That is incredible. Where is the investment? Where has the money from the previous, partial sale of Telstra gone? Where is the growth of Telstra? What we have seen is not a growth but a decline. Infrastructure and investment have not kept pace with technology and growth, and not just in urban parts of our cities. They have certainly lost ground when you compare the growth with small business, which relies on Telstra and its services to enable it to compete. It is a bit hard trying to get more specific figures out of Telstra because, quite frankly, Telstra is embarrassed at its lack of infrastructure investment, its lack of services, the number of faults that it has to deal with and the amount of time it takes to deal with those faults.

About 18 months or so ago the government ran a Telstra seminar in the northern suburbs of Perth. The then minister, Daryl Williams—since retired—told that meeting that Telstra is not responsible for supplying broadband services. That was the view of the minister who had responsibility for Telstra—that Telstra is not responsible for supplying broadband services.
An opposition member—What does it do?

talk.start.para: —The question is asked: what does it do? Whatever it does, the minister of the day, whether then or now, does not seem to know, because one of Telstra’s employees had to rush out and put out a press release through the northern suburbs saying that Telstra was committed to rolling out ADSL where there was sufficient demand. There is sufficient demand. That demand is in our cities and it is in the bush—it is right across Australia. It is a great pity, a great shame, that this government has chosen not to invest in the future of Telstra and chosen not to invest in the future of Australia. It has turned its back on Telstra and it has turned its back on Australia. (Time expired)

—I am delighted to have the opportunity to speak today on this matter of public importance. In my discussion I want to touch on three points: firstly, the government’s record in delivering telecommunications improvements to the people of Australia; secondly, the announcements made today on the $1.1 billion Connect Australia program and the $2 billion Communications Fund for the future; and, thirdly, the track record of the ALP on both telecommunications and privatisation.

speech.para: On the first point, the government’s track record since coming to power in 1996, the coalition has delivered unprecedented benefits to Australian consumers and businesses through the development of a highly competitive telecommunications regime. We as a government have been focused on equity and access to high-quality telecommunications services across Australia, no matter where you live. There have been three planks in the government’s approach to achieving those objectives: firstly, to encourage competition, to deliver innovation, to deliver cheaper prices and to deliver greater choice; secondly, to maintain tough regulatory and consumer safeguards such as price controls, customer service guarantees and universal service obligations; and, thirdly, to provide targeted funding to provide services in areas which would not normally be catered for in a commercial market.

The government’s approach has delivered real benefits to consumers: prices have fallen, customers have been offered a choice of providers and new services such as broadband are being rolled out across the country. Since the introduction of competition in 1997, consumers have seen a decrease in prices of some 20 per cent in real terms for telecommunications services. Now Australians can choose between different service providers and different telecommunications products. Australians have the option of dealing with 100 carriers across Australia, and there are now more than 16 million mobile phones in operation. Broadband subscribers now number well over a million, with half of them being serviced by operators other than Telstra.

Regional Australia has benefited in particular from the improvements under this government, with over a billion dollars being spent to date on a range of programs, such as Networking the Nation and improvements under the Besley and Estens reviews, including the highly successful HiBIS program which delivers broadband to small communities right round the country. There is also the $50 million metropolitan black spot program. This government has invested over $140 million to support the extension of mobile phone coverage to 98 per cent of Australians. Under the coalition, 40,000 customers living in remote Australia have access to untimed local calls for the first time, and they have been given the opportunity to take up subsidised two-way high-speed satellite internet services.

I would now like to turn to the announcement made today. This additional commitment will build on what has gone before under this government. The $1.1 billion Connect Australia program will provide a huge boost to our national infrastructure, with $878 million for the Broadband Connect program to provide more Australians with affordable broadband services; $113 million for the Clever Networks program, which will roll out new broadband networks to provide innovative applications to improve delivery of health, education and other essential services; $30 million for the Mobile Connect program to further extend terrestrial mobile coverage to areas not adequately catered for and to build on the subsidy for handheld satellite phones; and $90 million for a comprehensive package to provide telecommunications services to our Indigenous communities, which are so lacking in telecommunications services.

The government believes that good telecommunications services need to be assured not only now but into the future, and that is why there will be a system of regular reviews of services. There will be a requirement for Telstra to produce a local presence plan to ensure that Telstra services are available in regional and rural Australia and that there will be access to Telstra representatives at the local level. A $2 billion fund will be established, the revenue from which will be invested to ensure that we will be able to roll out improved technologies in telecommunications as they occur. That is a vitally important factor: future-proofing regional and rural areas to ensure that they have the adequate services they need not only now but into the future.

We believe that better competition is the key to better services and lower costs. As part of this proposal, the government will require the operational separation of Telstra’s wholesale and retail business units. If we are going to have proper competition other carriers will need to have a level playing field and, through operational separation, the National Party and the Liberal Party believe we will be able to achieve that. The government seeks to ensure transparency in pricing for wholesale customers. There will also be price controls: the 22c untimed local call will be maintained, there will be no large increases in line rental, there will be restrictions on the cost of new connections and there will be measures to protect low-income earners. This government is encouraging a reduction in telecommunications costs to the Australian community.

I would now like to turn from the bright future to the dark past of Labor’s history, to Labor’s appalling record on telecommunications, particularly in regional and rural areas. It is difficult to recount their strategy on regional services because I do not think they really had one. The word ‘regional’ barely appeared in their policy. Not one cent was committed to improving services in rural and regional areas. As I said, ‘regional’ was mentioned only once in their policy. Labor’s record on mobile phones was a disgrace, switching off the analog service and putting nothing in its place.

As the member for Murray said previously, services were actually reduced under Labor, not increased. That amounts to vandalism of the community’s telecommunications services. It took this coalition government to roll out the replacement CDMA network. When Labor was in government it placed no requirements on Telstra to fix or install services within time limits. Waiting for over two years for a landline connection is deplorable but it was part of the day under Labor. People were waiting for two years for a phone connection. These days there is a 20 working days maximum.

Labor did not encourage competition in telecommunication markets as there was a duopoly between Telstra and Optus. This did not see substantial reductions in prices, as we have seen in the recent past. It was a coalition government that delivered price competition. Some try to argue that quality of services can be delivered through the control of Telstra. Actually, Telstra is controlled by regulation, not through ownership.

Labor’s plan for Telstra, as far as we can see, would see a return to the bad old days of having a monopoly. Labor do not seem to have a forward vision for telecommunications. Their only response to the telecommunications argument is that of public ownership. They think public ownership is the key—back to the days of the PMG. This government is looking forward. Labor have no vision for telecommunications. Labor have no vision to take this country forward with telecommunications infrastructure. Their only policy initiative is to look backwards, to try and retard the government in its efforts to provide improved services—to try and replace its forward vision with an idea that takes us back to the past.

If you ask people around my electorate, perhaps in South West Rocks or Wooli, whether they like the roll-out of mobile phone towers, I am sure they would say they do. I am sure the people of Bonville are pleased to have the broadband that has been delivered under the broadband rollout. It is a ridiculous notion that this government is not delivering. The National Party and the Liberal Party are absolutely committed to delivering quality telecommunications services. Labor have squandered the proceeds that they received through the privatisation of Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank. They privatised those companies and still could not run a balanced budget. This government has been able to invest the proceeds of the sale of Telstra into improved telecommunications services.

The member for New England is in the chamber. He obviously does not have a vision for telecommunications in his electorate. He wants the bad old days of full public ownership. He wants to provide steam powered internet services for his electorate! He does not see the benefits of improved telecommunications services, as this government do. We want to take this country forward. We do not want to see steam powered internet services, as is the vision of the member for New England. We want to see high-quality, high-speed broadband rolled out across the country as quickly as possible. We want to see a competitive regime for the provision of telecommunications services, providing access to a range of carriers and providing cheaper prices and better services. We want to see the introduction of new technologies, when they become available, right across this country. The proposed programs announced today are going to go a long way to seeing that happen. We, as a government, are very much focused on delivering the very best telecommunication services for the people of Australia.

talk.start.para: —I think we have just heard a speech in favour of the retention of part-government ownership in Telstra! Contrary to what some of the Labor speakers have said, I believe that the government, as a partial owner of Telstra, has introduced some good initiatives. I think that has been driven by the political imperative—the capacity and the ability of members of parliament to drive some of the issues, particularly in regional Australia, to some degree of fruition and to create some political pressure. Regrettably, given the decision of today, that pressure will be taken off. If you listened to the Treasurer and the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry yesterday—and others from the government side—you would have heard them say that they recognise that, for a fully privatised operation to exist, there has to be a profit imperative, not a service imperative, for those in remote and rural areas.

speech.para: I think it is a very sad day for country Australia and a very sad day for this parliament. Although members of the government, particularly the National Party, are very excited about this initiative, there is not one member of the National Party in this chamber—other than you, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, and you are here in an official capacity. So quite obviously those members are fully aware that they have been run over by the Liberal bus on this decision. They are in disgrace in their electorates. They are in disgrace in Australia generally, with over 70 per cent of people not wanting this to happen.

This is the ‘no excuses’ parliament. There is no excuse for poor regional policy any more. You cannot blame the Greens or the Democrats for poor policy in the Senate. If the Senate takes this decision to alienate rural and regional Australia from the most important piece of infrastructure that exists—a piece of infrastructure that has the capacity to negate distances being a disadvantage for people living in Australia—it will be on the heads of the National Party.

I noticed that the messiah of the nation last week, Senator Barnaby Joyce, has suddenly turned into the Judas goat of Queensland. He has come into the parliament and made wild claims about opposing the sale. He received my admiration for doing that because I thought: ‘Maybe for once there is a member of this party who will actually stand up for what the constituents in rural Australia are saying. Maybe for once there is a person who is prepared to stand up.’ He did stand up for a little while, but he sat down again today. I think that is a real shame for the people of Queensland. It is a real shame, probably, for the individual. It is a great shame for this nation that he has not stayed firm on this issue. I encourage him to rethink his position. But, Senator Joyce, do not go around this parliament saying, ‘I don’t agree with the sale of Telstra but I had to accept something because Senator Murray from the Democrats or Senator Fielding from the Family First Party would vote for it.’ Do not discredit those individuals to try and garner some sort of impression that you have done a good deal. This is a disgraceful deal.

One thing that we have found out today is what is up to scratch. This term ‘up to scratch’ has fascinated me for years. Senator Joyce and others have said that they will relate to experts in terms of what is required. The expert was down here last week: the new CEO of Telstra. He made a point that there had been a $5 billion underinvestment. There had been far too much of a focus on sale rather than service. He made the point that $5 billion is required. The minister has brushed that aside, the government has brushed that aside, Barnaby Joyce has brushed that aside and the National Party has brushed that aside. They have said, ‘You can have $1 billion now or over the next few years to look after the underinvestment that has been in place in current infrastructure and you can have the interest off this $2 billion fund.’ In the Leader of the National Party’s words, the interest is about $100 million a year, which is $25 million a year less than what they have spent over the last eight, so it is a reduction in government spending in terms of ongoing future proofing of the instrumentality.

If we assume that the CEO knows something about telecommunications, he believes that $5 billion would need to be invested immediately to bring it up to scratch. If we look at how that is going to come about now, it will take 40 years to get Telstra up to scratch in 2005. There is the $1 billion that they are giving now and the other $4 billion will come over 40 years at $100 million a year. That is what this parliament is looking at doing. That is what the National Party and other country members in this parliament are prepared to do to their constituency. We will be up to scratch in 40 years time. That is assuming that the $5 billion underinvestment is true. But the CEO is the closest expert and should be the closest expert in terms of the decision-making process. So all of those who have stood up in here and said, ‘We won’t do anything until it’s up to scratch,’ should come back in 40 years time—and the line in the sand is 2005. I think that is the disgraceful act that is being perpetrated on the people of Australia and regional Australia today.

No wonder there is not a member of the National Party in this room. No wonder they are not boasting about it, because they have been done over like a dinner. I have been speaking to the Liberals and they are laughing at this. This is a far better deal than they ever contemplated. They have got the sale.

talk.start.para: Mr Wilkie interjecting—
(Hon. IR Causley)—The member for Swan may wish to speak in a minute.

—They are going to spend $25 million less a year in terms of the Future Fund and this mythical billion that is going to bring things up to scratch. I am proud to vote against this and I am proud to speak against it, because the people of Australia do not want it to happen and it should not happen. The National Party have proven to me today that they are not only prepared to offer bribes; they are prepared to accept bribes and that is an absolute disgrace.
—The member for New England will withdraw that inference.
—The member for New England will not withdraw that inference, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I name the member for New England.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order.
—There is no point of order. I name the member for New England.

—I am entitled to rise on a point of order. Mr Deputy Speaker, as I am sure you are well aware, comments that may be unparliamentary when referring to an individual are not unparliamentary when referring—
—The member for Brisbane would be well aware that when a member is asked to withdraw the comment they will withdraw it. The member for Brisbane will resume his seat.
—Are you going to rule on the point of order?
—I said the member for Brisbane will resume his seat immediately. I will deal with the member for New England and then I will deal with the member for Brisbane. I name the member for New England.

motionnospeech.name: Ms LEY

motion.para: That the member for New England be suspended from the service of the House.

motionnospeech.para: A division having been called and the bells being rung—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raised a point of order and I have not heard any determination.
—The member for Brisbane is well aware that when a member is asked to withdraw a comment they will withdraw the comment without any debate.
—What is the ruling on my point of order?
—I have just told the member for Brisbane, when a member is asked by the chair to withdraw a comment the member will withdraw the comment without debate.
—I understand the standing order—
—This is not a debate. The member for Brisbane has the point of order.
—But I do not have a ruling on it, Mr Deputy Speaker. That is the point I am seeking.
—If the member for Brisbane wants to be dealt with after this, I will deal with him.
—I seek your guidance as to at what point I get an answer to my—
—The member for Brisbane has the answer, and it is not a debate.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I seek clarification of the ruling you have just made on the member for Brisbane’s intervention. Can I suggest to you that the implication of that ruling is that—
—The member for Hunter will come to his point of order.
—Can I suggest, Mr Deputy Speaker, the implication of that ruling is that you have now set a new precedent and that members of this parliament can now offend the collective.
—The member for Hunter cannot debate the issue.
—But we can’t get a ruling.

motion.para: That the member for New England be suspended from the service of the House.

subdebate.1.para: 10000 Causley, Ian (The DEPUTY SPEAKER)The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. IR Causley)—The honourable member for New England is suspended from the service of the House for 24 hours.

para.inline: The member for New England then left the chamber.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That so much of standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving a motion of censure against the Deputy Speaker.

speech.para: Government members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —That was a piece of biased ruling, a massively biased ruling, upheld by government numbers in the most outrageous way—

motion.para: That the member be no longer heard.

debate.para: 10000 Causley, Ian (The DEPUTY SPEAKER)The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. IR Causley)—Is the motion seconded?

talk.start.para: —I second the motion. This is about a National Party mate protecting a National Party mate. It is a National Party disgrace—an absolute disgrace.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGAURAN

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the member be no longer heard.

debate.para: Original question put:

motion.para: That the motion (Mr Beazley’s) be agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Speaker do resume the chair.

speech.para: Moving the procedural motion that the Speaker resume the chair is something that at any point of time this parliament can do. We are unsatisfied—

motion.para: That the member be no longer heard.

debate.para: 10000 Causley, Ian (The DEPUTY SPEAKER)The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. IR Causley)—Is the motion seconded?

talk.start.para: —I second the motion. This is a National Party disgrace and we want the Speaker back in the chair.

motion.para: That the member be no longer heard.

debate.para: Original question put:

motion.para: That the motion (Mr Beazley’s) be agreed to.

debate.para: 83L Gillard, Julia, MPMs Gillard—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It is looking at confirmation and clarification of your last ruling. I will take you to House of Representatives Practice, page 502.

10000 Causley, Ian (The DEPUTY SPEAKER)The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. IR Causley)—If the member for Lalor wishes me to explain where I rely on my ruling, I will give her the ruling. I rely on standing order 90, which is about improper imputations. If she wants the precedent, it is the precedent of Speaker Snedden, who ruled on whether it could be the individual or the collective.
83L Gillard, Julia, MPMs Gillard—Precisely. I was taking you to the ruling of Speaker—
10000 DEPUTY SPEAKER, TheThe DEPUTY SPEAKER—The member for Lalor cannot debate a point of order.

83L Gillard, Julia, MPMs Gillard—If I could be allowed to state it, I think it would clarify the matter. My point of order is as follows: the ruling of Speaker Snedden on page 502 does not seem to me to extend as far as you have used it today.
10000 DEPUTY SPEAKER, TheThe DEPUTY SPEAKER—If the member for Lalor wishes to take it up with the Speaker—
83L Gillard, Julia, MPMs Gillard—May I clarify my point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, so this exchange can be useful?
10000 DEPUTY SPEAKER, TheThe DEPUTY SPEAKER—If the member for Lalor wishes to take it up with the Speaker, she may.

83L Gillard, Julia, MPMs Gillard—I am taking it up with you, Mr Deputy Speaker, because it is your ruling. Is it your ruling that you have enlarged Speaker Snedden’s ruling to apply to words not contained in that ruling? If so, can you explain to me why it was that the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education was not named yesterday for using terms inappropriately? How is that consistent?

10000 DEPUTY SPEAKER, TheThe DEPUTY SPEAKER—I explained to the member for Lalor that I relied upon standing order 90 and, as a precedent, I relied upon Speaker Snedden’s ruling. If she disagrees with that, she can take it up with the Speaker and the Speaker will give a definition.
83L Gillard, Julia, MPMs Gillard—Mr Deputy Speaker, can I suggest—
10000 DEPUTY SPEAKER, TheThe DEPUTY SPEAKER—Is this a point of order?
83L Gillard, Julia, MPMs Gillard—Yes, it is a point of order.
10000 DEPUTY SPEAKER, TheThe DEPUTY SPEAKER—What is the point of order?

83L Gillard, Julia, MPMs Gillard—Given that you have just said that this matter ought to be taken up with the Speaker, can I suggest that you voluntarily remove yourself from the chair so the Speaker can take it?

10000 DEPUTY SPEAKER, TheThe DEPUTY SPEAKER—The member for Lalor will resume her seat. I will now present the report of the Selection Committee relating to consideration of committee and delegation reports and private members’ business.
Opposition members interjecting—
10000 DEPUTY SPEAKER, TheThe DEPUTY SPEAKER—Order! I dealt with the point of order of the member for Lalor, and the member for Brisbane was exactly the same.

talk.start.para: —I present the report of the Selection Committee relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private members’ business on Monday, 5 September 2005. The report will be printed in today’s Hansard and the items accorded priority for debate will be published in the Notice Paper for the next sitting.

speech.para: The report read as follows—

para.inline: Report relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private Members’ business on Monday, 5 September 2005

Pursuant to standing order 222, the Selection Committee has determined the order of precedence and times to be allotted for consideration of committee and delegation reports and private Members’ business on Monday, 5 September 2005.
The order of precedence and the allotments of time determined by the Committee are as follows:
1 AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION AND THE ITALIAN REPUBLIC
Report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the Russian Federation and the Italian Republic, 17 April to 1 May 2005
The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made — all statements to conclude by 12.35 p.m.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 1 x 5 mins]
Report of the inspections of Baxter Immigration Detention Facility and Port Augusta Residential Housing Project, April 2005
The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made — all statements to conclude by 12.50 p.m.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 3 x 5 mins]
JOINT PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE ON CORPORATIONS AND FINANCIAL SERVICES
The Committee determined that statements on these two reports may be made — all statements to conclude by 1.05 p.m.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 3 x 5 mins]
PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CRIME COMMISSION
The trafficking of women for sexual servitude — Supplementary report
The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made — all statements to conclude by 1.10 p.m.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 1 x 5 mins]
PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE ON ASIO, ASIS AND DSD
Review of the listing of four terrorist organisations
The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made — all statements to conclude by 1.20 p.m.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 2 x 5 mins]
JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CAPITAL AND EXTERNAL TERRITORIES
to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Fuel Quality Standards Act 2000. (Fuel Quality Standards (Renewable Content of Motor Vehicle Fuel) Amendment Bill 2005) (Notice given 2 June 2005.)
Presenter may speak for a period not exceeding 5 minutes — pursuant to standing order 41.
to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Act 1999. (Avoiding Dangerous Climate Change (Climate Change Trigger) Bill 2005) (Notice given 10 August 2005.)
Presenter may speak for a period not exceeding 5 minutes — pursuant to standing order 41.
to present a Bill for an Act to establish the Parliamentary (Judicial Behaviour or Incapacity) Commission. (
Parliamentary (Judicial Behaviour or Incapacity) Commission Bill 2005
Presenter may speak for a period not exceeding 5 minutes — pursuant to standing order 41.

to present a Bill for an Act to regulate government advertising, and for related purposes. (Government Advertising (Prohibiting use of taxpayers’ money on party political advertising) Bill 2005) (Notice given 16 August 2005.)
Presenter may speak for a period not exceeding 5 minutes — pursuant to standing order 41.

item.para: recognises:

item.label: (a)
item.para: the extent and gravity of world poverty and the urgency of tackling this situation; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: that the most impoverished countries cannot escape the cycle of poverty without assistance;
acknowledges recent efforts by the Australian Government including increases in the Australian aid budget;
supports the Millenium Development Goals and world efforts to halve world poverty by 2015; and
urges the Australian Government to continue to work towards the achievement of those goals.

para.inline: [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 6 x 5 mins]
The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.

item.para: expresses its opposition to major retail chains such as Woolworths and Coles being able to open pharmacies in supermarkets; and
reaffirms its support for community pharmacies and in doing so recognises that the extension of pharmacies to major retail supermarkets will:

item.label: (a)
item.para: lead to the closure of many community pharmacies, the majority of whom are hard working small businesses;

item.label: (b)
item.para: lead to the loss of jobs amongst the 30,000 assistants currently employed in community pharmacies;

item.label: (c)
item.para: put at risk the 80 million free services provided by community pharmacies to the Australian community, many of whom cannot afford the cost of going to the doctor due to the decline in bulk billing, and

item.label: (d)
item.para: lead to the reduction in training and career opportunities for people who have chosen pharmacy as their career. (Notice given 9 August 2005.)

para.inline: Time allotted — remaining private Members’ business time.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 6 x 5 mins]
The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the 11th, 12th, 13th, 14th and 15th reports for 2005 of the committee relating to: Holsworthy program—special operations working accommodation and base redevelopment stage 1; proposed CSIRO entomology bioscience laboratory at Black Mountain, Canberra; operational upgrade of Darwin detention facility, Berrimah, Northern Territory; upgrade of patrol boat facilities, HMAS Coonawarra, Darwin; and redevelopment of Kokoda Barracks, Canungra, Queensland.

speech.para: Ordered that the reports be made parliamentary papers.

talk.start.para: —by leave—The committee’s 11th report of 2005 addresses the construction of working accommodation for special operations forces and stage 1 of the redevelopment of Holsworthy Barracks, New South Wales. The proposed works will facilitate the establishment of the Army’s full-time commando capability, based upon the 4th Battalion, the Royal Australian Regiment (Commando); the Tactical Assault Group (East) becoming an organic element of the 4th Battalion, the Royal Australian Regiment (Commando); the Incident Response Regiment; Special Operations Combat Services Support Company; and the first stage of the redevelopment of Holsworthy Barracks. Having investigated the proposal, the committee is satisfied that the works will improve amenity for and operational efficiency of the important Army units accommodated at Holsworthy. The committee therefore recommends that the works proceed at the estimated cost of $207.7 million.

speech.para: The committee’s 12th report of 2005 examines the proposed construction of a new entomology bioscience laboratory at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation’s (CSIRO’s) Black Mountain campus in the ACT. The CSIRO reported that the Division of Entomology currently conducts scientific research in buildings that range in age from 32 to 76 years old. These buildings: do not meet contemporary research standards; have, in some instances, structural constraints which prevent them being refurbished to a level commensurate with current and evolving laboratory standards; do not meet current OH&S standards; and cannot accommodate anticipated division growth. To redress these deficiencies, the CSIRO proposes to: construct a new two-storey, 2,313 square metre entomology bioscience laboratory; refurbish two existing buildings; construct covered walkways to link the new and existing buildings; and carry out associated site works and landscaping, including demolition of redundant buildings and sheds.

Noting that some of the redundant buildings contain asbestos, the committee recommends that the CSIRO take all necessary steps to identify and ensure the safe removal and disposal of hazardous materials from the site. The committee also recommends that the CSIRO continues discussion with the National Capital Authority to resolve any outstanding design issues. Having considered the proposal in detail, members are satisfied that the works should proceed at the estimated cost of $12.7 million.

The committee’s 13th report of 2005 deals with a proposal by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, DIMIA, to carry out an operational upgrade of the detention facility at Berrimah, Northern Territory, at an estimated cost of $8.21 million.

The primary purpose of the proposed works is to establish a safe and secure land based detention facility for illegal foreign fishers apprehended in Australia’s northern waters. The department reported that illegal foreign fishing in Australia’s northern waters has been increasing in recent years and that current boat based detention arrangements have proven unmanageable. It is envisaged that, in addition to illegal foreign fishers, the facility will accommodate Northern Territory immigration compliance cases and unauthorised air arrivals, some of whom the department told us would be women and children.

The committee notes that the department’s proposal contains a significant number of undetermined factors which may be expected to impact upon the project cost. Whilst cognisant of the difficulties associated with estimating project budgets under modern procurement arrangements, the committee requests that agencies supply the most robust and comprehensive costs available in order that the committee can fulfil its statutory role as a scrutineer of public expenditure. The committee therefore recommends that DIMIA supply regular updates on expenditure throughout the course of the project.

Having viewed both the existing facilities at the Berrimah detention centre and the plans for the upgrade, the committee remains unconvinced that the proposed family area represents the best use of available space or provides a reasonable level of amenity or security for detainees. Despite the recent changes to the government’s policy in relation to the detention of families with children, the department explained that it may be necessary to hold people for a very short period of time for initial assessment. Given the inadequacy and inappropriateness of the proposed family area, the committee recommends that families including women and children are not detained at the facility.

In the event that there is a demonstrated need for the short-term detention of families at the facility, the committee recommends that, in order to ensure appropriate provision of security—particularly separation from the large number of fishers that may be held at the centre—amenity and space for families, women and children, the department should better utilise the space available. The family area should be enlarged and should provide appropriate separation of all facilities, which is a major security issue, adequate indoor recreation space and a secure outdoor area of a suitable size to accommodate play equipment relocated from the existing large, grassed recreation area. The committee hopes that there will not be an occasion to keep families with children in this particular facility.

The committee also wishes to ensure the reliability of DIMIA’s project delivery strategy and recommends that the department supply the committee with an update on the chosen delivery methodology and the application of Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines to this process, when this information becomes available.

Further, in the interest of transparency and good community relations, the committee recommends that DIMIA consult with the local community and with relevant Northern Territory government agencies in respect of the proposed works. In particular, the committee wishes DIMIA to consult with the office of the Northern Territory Chief Minister to find an appropriate name for the facility. Having given careful consideration to the proposal, the committee recommends that the works proceed at the estimated cost of $8.21 million.

A further referral from the Department of Defence, namely the upgrade of patrol boat facilities at HMAS Coonawarra, Darwin, forms the subject of the committee’s 14th report of 2005. The upgraded facilities, estimated to cost $19.17 million, will facilitate the introduction into service of the Armidale class patrol boat and will also provide a new facility for the Darwin Port Services Organisation.

The committee notes Defence’s efforts to minimise the environmental impacts of the proposed works and, in respect of any future dredging activities, recommends that the department maintain close consultation with the Northern Territory Department of Lands, Planning and Environment to ensure minimisation of damage to the marine environment.

In view of the importance of fire protection and evacuation measures, the committee recommends that Defence supply it with details of the fire protection system proposed for the standby crew and port services organisation building, including any departures from the requirements of the Building Code of Australia, when these have been determined. The committee is satisfied with the evidence supplied by Defence and is happy for the works to proceed at the estimated cost of $19.17 million.

The 15th report of 2005 presents the committee’s findings in relation to the proposed redevelopment of Kokoda Barracks at Canungra, Queensland, for the Department of Defence. The purpose of the proposed work is to provide the working and domestic accommodation, and engineering services infrastructure required, for the ongoing delivery of effective training at the Canungra Military Training Area.

The redevelopment entails: correction of working and training accommodation deficiencies; rationalisation of messing facilities; improvements to living-in accommodation for trainees; upgrade of the engineering services infrastructure; and disposal of redundant, high-maintenance facilities.

During its inquiry, the committee investigated a range of barracks services; the design of the proposed new facilities; the removal of asbestos; heritage issues; and traffic management. The committee recommends that the works proceed at the estimated cost of $86.7 million and requests that Defence continue consultation with the Department of the Environment and Heritage regarding any heritage issues that may arise from the redevelopment project.

These reports examine works representing some $336.28 million worth of Commonwealth expenditure. It has been a very heavy workload for the committee secretariat. I would like to take this opportunity to thank my committee colleagues and to thank Hansard and our committee secretariat for helping to facilitate this work in a timely manner. I commend the reports to the House.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! Just before proceeding and giving the call to the member for Gorton, the chair indicates to the minister at the table, the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads—I know that he might not have been directly involved—that for a period that might have been described as lengthy by some there was no member of the executive at the table. Whilst I do not think that this afternoon would have been exactly the time to have directly and immediately acted upon that, the chair notes that. I ask the minister, especially with his experience as the Chief Government Whip, if he could assist the House by ensuring that others that are on the roster are in the chamber.

—by leave—I want to supplement the comments made by the member for Pearce in relation to these public works—namely, the Holsworthy program special operations working accommodation and base redevelopment stage 1; the proposed CSIRO entomology bioscience laboratory at Black Mountain, Canberra; the operational upgrade at Darwin detention facility, Berrimah; the upgrade of patrol boat facilities at HMAS Coonawarra, Darwin; and the redevelopment of Kokoda Barracks, Canungra, Queensland.

speech.para: As the chair of the committee has indicated, the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works has an enormous workload. The committee members share the workload well. Indeed, the work is made that much easier as a result of the diligence and professionalism of the secretariat of the committee. I would like to express particular appreciation for their work.

I support the comments made by the member for Pearce in relation to these five works. In particular, I would like to emphasise in relation to the operational upgrade of the Darwin Detention Facility Berrimah the need for DIMIA to take the committee’s concerns on board in relation to what we are to do for children and families if we find them in a position to be enclosed behind fences—given, as I understand it, the shift in government policy in that regard. We have made it clear that we do not consider it appropriate for families and children to be placed in that situation. We hope that there is a capacity for that never to happen. The department has raised the point that there may be occasions on which emergencies require such detention, but we think that should be unnecessary. Indeed, we ask the department and the minister to look at that matter with a view to ensuring that that is avoided at all costs.

Finally, in relation to that project, I again ask the department to make contact with the Northern Territory government. They have raised a concern that they do not want the detention centre in Darwin to be entitled ‘Darwin Detention Centre’. There are good reasons for the name change, we accept, without going through the reasons now. We understand why there is the need to change the name. However, committee members accepted the view that there is no need to call a detention centre ‘Darwin Detention Centre’. The Chief Minister and the Northern Territory government believed it was not in the interests of people residing in Darwin, in the Northern Territory. Other than the Perth detention centre, I think it is true to say that all other centres in capital cities—Villawood, Maribyrnong—are not named after the city in which they reside. Therefore we hope that the department are able to consider the recommendations of the Public Works Committee in light of the request made by the Northern Territory government to ensure that that centre is not named the ‘Darwin Detention Centre’.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties I present the committee’s report, incorporating a dissenting report, entitled: Report 66—Treaties tabled on 7 December 2004 (4), 15 March and 11 May 2005, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

talk.start.para: —by leave—Report 66 contains the findings and recommendations of the review conducted by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties of nine treaty actions tabled in parliament on 7 December 2004, 15 March 2005 and 11 May 2005. The treaty actions relate to the matters identified in the title of the report. I will comment on a selection of the treaty actions considered.

speech.para: The United Nations Convention against Corruption is a multilateral agreement designed to enhance international efforts to combat corruption. Although no changes to Commonwealth legislation are required to implement Australia’s obligations under UNCAC, the committee raised two issues with this treaty. One issue, relating to whether a provision of the treaty is mandatory, discretionary or optional, changes the extent of the Commonwealth’s power to legislate for it. The major issue the committee considered was the degree to which this treaty confers additional jurisdiction on the Commonwealth through the use of the external affairs power under section 51(xxix) of the Constitution.

The committee considers that the external affairs power is not always an ideal head of power from which to legislate, particularly where the treaty has the potential to significantly impact on the states and territories. Evidence to the committee suggested that the use of the external affairs power is limited to some extent by the Melbourne Corporation doctrine—that is, it is unlikely that the Commonwealth could enact legislation which relates to corrupt conduct of members of state parliaments, state executives and state courts in the discharge of their functions as state officials. Even so, the committee has made two recommendations asking the Attorney-General to advise the committee that there is no intention to use the external affairs power and UNCAC to pass legislation not foreshadowed in the NIA.

The amendments to the Singapore-Australia Free Trade Agreement add a further two universities—Murdoch University and the University of Tasmania—to the list of Australian universities whose graduates are recognised for admission as qualified lawyers in Singapore. As a South Australian, I am pleased to see Flinders University on the list of 10 and I look forward to the day that the University of Adelaide is added.

Since 1995, Singapore armed forces have used the Shoalwater Bay training area. The committee supports the agreement between Australia and Singapore, which will allow the continued use of the Shoalwater Bay training area by the Singapore armed forces for five years from 31 December 2004. Report 66 also recommends the entry into force of a treaty between Australia and New Zealand that defines maritime boundaries between our two countries. This treaty serves as a model for bilateral cooperation on maritime boundaries. Lastly, the committee has recommended that a treaty which establishes a permanent and independent secretariat to administer the Antarctic Treaty consultation meeting enter into force. Australia has a large territorial claim and an extensive research program in Antarctica. The secretariat will be in Buenos Aires, Argentina.
In conclusion, the committee believes it is in Australia’s national interest for the nine treaties considered in report 66 to be ratified. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —by leave—The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties’ review included treaty actions from a diverse range of subject areas. Similarly to previous reviews, the committee’s findings were based on an examination of the benefits to Australia of each treaty action. This included examining each of the nine treaty actions with regard to their impact on the political, diplomatic, security, economic and social ties between Australia and the treaty parties. Of particular interest in this batch of treaties is the United Nations Convention against Corruption. I will not talk about each of the treaty actions, because I thought I would complement the comments that the chair has already made.

speech.para: The United Nations Convention against Corruption will provide for a number of measures relating to corruption prevention and criminalisation, international cooperation in combating corruption, asset recovery, training and technical assistance and the establishment of a conference of the parties to the convention. In addition to recommending that binding treaty action be taken, the committee made two other recommendations. These recommendations relate to issues surrounding the Australian government’s potential use of its external powers to override the will of the states and territories where implementation of this treaty is concerned. These recommendations are particularly important as the committee has encountered a similar situation with other treaties.

Another treaty of interest is one that will establish and define the exclusive economic zone and continental shelf boundaries between Australia and New Zealand in the Tasman Sea and adjacent areas of the south-western Pacific Ocean. There are currently no agreed maritime boundaries between the countries, and I welcome this treaty, which will sort this matter out. I am particularly disappointed, though, that it would appear that many of the criteria used to determine these particular boundaries were not used in the case of East Timor. It was put to us by the department that we had to look at each case on its merit. I believe that some of the criteria that were used in determining the boundaries between Australia and New Zealand could in fact have been used when we were looking at the East Timor-Australia delineation.

The Agreement on Cooperation in the Fields of Energy and Mineral Resources with the Republic of Korea will provide a framework to pursue areas of mutual benefit and interest in relation to energy and mineral products. The agreement includes provisions on the exchange of energy and mineral resources information; the promotion and facilitation of technical cooperation in the fields of energy and mineral resources; cooperation and facilitation of bilateral trade and investment in energy and mineral resources, including value added products and services; and the development and implementation of greenhouse gas mitigation projects in the context of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.

The final treaty I would like to make mention of is the Mutual Recognition Agreement on Conformity Assessment in relation to Medicines Goods Manufacturing Practice Inspection and Certification with Canada. The treaty will provide for reciprocal recognition of goods manufacturing practice certificates of medicines between Australia and Canada. Under the current pharmaceutical inspection scheme, countries are not legally bound to supply information nor to do so in any specified time period. The treaty would afford certainty to Australian exporters of medicinal products and eliminate uncertainty and any delays or costs associated with retesting batches of medicines on import into Canada.

I would like to comment on the agreement between Australia and Singapore on the use of the Shoalwater Bay training facility. I commend this particular move, having been to Shoalwater Bay and seen what is on offer there and the sorts of facilities that are being built by our partners. I think they are great facilities and it is a great treaty. I commend that to the House also. I would also like to send thanks to those who put forward submissions in relation to these matters and to the committee secretariat who have, once again, done a fantastic job.

motionnospeech.name: Dr SOUTHCOTT

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

motionnospeech.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

subdebateinfo.title: Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation Committee

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation I present the committee’s report, incorporating a dissenting report, entitled Making it work: inquiry into independent contracting and labour hire arrangements, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I am pleased to present this report on independent contracting and labour hire arrangements. This inquiry was conducted at a time of increasing debate on the conditions of Australian workers, with possible changes to federal workplace relations legislation affecting the coverage of state legislation, including proposals to develop legislation to support independent contractors. In a highly competitive global market, flexibility and response times are crucial. As a result, demand from companies for labour hire and contractor services has increased over the last 20 years. Currently, over 10 per cent of the work force identify themselves as being independent contractors and nearly four per cent identify themselves as labour hire workers. These types of working arrangements are found across a wide variety of industries.

speech.para: Supporting labour hire and contracting arrangements is essential for a number of reasons. These include: meeting shortages of labour or fluctuating demands across industries and occupations; providing avenues for mature age workers to remain in the work force and transition employment opportunities for those seeking to enter the workforce; achieving efficiencies that enable us to compete in the global marketplace; and offering a range of working arrangements that may provide different lifestyle and remuneration benefits from those offered through direct employment options.

It has been a challenging task for the committee to examine current state and federal workplace relations systems to identify strategies that provide a balance of freedoms and protections—and to do so with greater consistency across Australia. There are 16 recommendations included in the report, and they are: to address the occupational health and safety of labour hire workers and independent contractors; to improve access to skill development and training for labour hire workers; to establish a voluntary code of practice for the labour hire industry; to create greater consistency across federal, state and territory legislation in differentiating between independent contractors and employees; to improve access to information to outline the rights and responsibilities of independent contractors; to regulate independent contractors under commercial law; and to improve access to different dispute resolution procedures for independent contractors.

The committee investigated whether labour hire and contracting arrangements are, in some instances, being used to evade responsibilities, particularly in the areas of occupational health and safety and employee entitlements. The committee does not condone the creation of artificial structures to avoid regulatory compliance by host businesses, labour hire agencies or contractors and it does not condone the creation of artificial independent contracting arrangements to avoid the incumbent responsibilities of an employee-employer relationship.

Key to curbing possible sham arrangements is the national need for greater clarity and consistency in distinguishing between an employee and an independent contractor. The committee has opted for a pragmatic strategy—one that combines existing national approaches to achieve an Australia-wide national outcome. Essentially the strategies recommended are to provide assistance for establishing genuine arrangements and to reduce opportunities for establishing artificial arrangements that seek to avoid responsibilities. Considering independent contractors within commercial relationships provides the appropriate framework for supporting and developing independent contractors as businesses. It is important that these legitimate business relationships and choices are honoured and are not subject to excessive protectionist regulation.

Improved access to relevant information on rights and responsibilities is key to ensuring there is informed choice in selecting working arrangements. Additionally, when a dispute arises regarding a contract for services, more accessible, affordable resolution procedures are necessary, such as use of the Federal Magistrates Court. Labour hire and independent contracting arrangements are a vital element of the Australian work force. A balanced approach of flexibility and protections has been sought to recognise the needs of labour hire agencies, workers, employers, principal contractors and independent contractors.

Once again the members of the committee demonstrated considerable commitment to working together to report in a reasonably short time. I thank the deputy chair, the member for Gorton, and other members of the committee for their cooperation and dedication to the inquiry. While there has been dissent on party lines on some of the recommendations, overall there is unified support for the majority of the report. I also take this opportunity to thank the inquiry secretariat for their counsel, assistance and patience throughout the process—particularly Dr Anna Dacre, Alison Childs and their very hardworking team.

In conclusion, I would like to thank the many individuals and organisations who provided evidence to this inquiry through submissions or by appearing before the committee. The strategies outlined in this report are designed to make labour hire and independent contracting arrangements work for Australians and for Australian businesses. Together these strategies work to make a competitive Australia, offering a range of working arrangements to suit industry, occupation, employer and worker requirements. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I rise to add to the comments made by the member for Deakin. Firstly, I would like to say that there was indeed a very short time frame for the committee and great regard was given to the pressures of time. It is true to say that therefore the committee members and the secretariat worked expeditiously to arrive at this outcome.

speech.para: But this afternoon I have to emphasise the concerns raised in the dissenting report. It is true to say that good work was done, as has already been expressed by the member for Deakin, the chair of the committee. Indeed, there was goodwill shown by committee members. However, it is important to note that Making it work: inquiry into independent contracting and labour hire arrangements made a total of 16 recommendations, of which nine were agreed to unanimously. A dissenting report provided alternatives to seven of the recommendations and made seven additional recommendations for the government to consider.

It is the view of the dissenting members that, in some respects, the committee missed a golden opportunity to clear up the growing confusion as to who is an employee and who is a genuine contractor in the Australian work force. The committee’s report, tabled today, also failed to provide any real clarification regarding the rights and responsibilities of labour hire agencies, employees and host employers.

The report’s findings, we argue, were prejudiced by the interference of the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, who chose to release his own paper and set up his own closed inquiry on the same matter soon after referring it to the committee. In our view, the minister’s disregard for the parliamentary committee process had an adverse influence upon the findings of the committee. In our view, the minister treated the parliamentary process with contempt. Having referred the matter to the committee in the first place, the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations then chose to pre-empt the committee’s findings and prejudice its deliberations by releasing a paper with loaded assertions and opinions and by establishing his own closed inquiry on the same matter. This behaviour was another example of the government’s abuse of parliamentary process and, in the view of the dissenting members, may have adversely affected the committee’s recommendations. It was, in our view, an attempt to sideline the parliamentary committee and influence the views of, in particular, government members of the committee.

I now turn to the substantive matters raised in evidence given to the committee, starting with disguised forms of employment. Another way to expose workers to unfairness is to call them ‘contractors’ and take away their employee entitlements. The dissenting report sought to clarify the delineation between an employee and a genuine independent contractor. The committee heard comprehensive and compelling evidence of sham arrangements and forms of disguised employment but, unfortunately, failed to recommend any concrete solutions to the growing problems of confusion and exploitation. Evidence showed that many workers were being forced to work as so-called independent contractors in order to avoid taxation and traditional employer responsibilities such as the payment of superannuation contributions and workers compensation insurance premiums.

The evidence highlighted an absence of taxation laws to properly distinguish employees from independent contractors for the purpose of collecting the nation’s revenue. Some witnesses asserted that the amount of revenue lost as a result runs into billions of dollars each year. Evidence given by Treasury underlined the inability of the Commonwealth to determine the extent of tax avoidance by employees wrongfully described as ‘contractors’. Although the personal services income legislation sought to prevent tax avoidance, its effectiveness is unknown because, as confirmed by Treasury, well over 99.9 per cent of tax claims in this area are self-assessed. It is therefore not known whether these provisions, weak as they are, are being enforced properly. The extraordinarily high proportion of self-assessing PSI applicants fails to instil in the dissenting members any confidence that the current system is an effective means of distinguishing genuine independent contractors from employees.

The committee was concerned by the significant evidence highlighting the extraordinary growth of labour hire employment in the last 15 years. All committee members accepted the possible benefits of labour hire employment, but the report failed to recognise the intrinsic difficulties with labour hire arrangements. In particular, the committee failed to address the extremely high proportion of labour hire workers who are precariously employed. The rate of casualisation amongst labour hire employees exceeds 75 per cent, or more than three times the work force average. The committee received evidence of labour hire employees working for more than 10 years and still being described as casuals. The report failed to propose any relief from indefinitely being precariously employed.

Furthermore, the committee received evidence that the triangular relationship involving labour hire agencies, host companies and labour hire workers has led to a blurring of legal obligations and entitlements in a number of areas such as occupational health and safety and return to work policies. Although the committee did identify some areas of concern, in our view it failed to provide solutions to the problem of assigning responsibilities in this area of work.

Finally, I will describe in general terms the additional recommendations that the dissenting members felt the need to add as a result of a deficiency in the report. The dissenting members also recommended additional recommendations in order to fill the void left by the report. The recommendations include: proposals to prevent employees working for unreasonable periods as casuals, when they could appropriately be classified as permanents; shared occupational health and safety responsibilities for labour hire agencies and host employers; and the right for a contractor to choose their representative, whether that might be a trade union or not.

Today I had the good fortune to meet with officials and members of the New South Wales branch of the Transport Workers Union. I also had the good fortune to listen to some of the members talk about their plight at a seminar held today at Parliament House. That was particularly relevant to this matter. I therefore think it is very important that the government consider ensuring the right to be properly represented in the appropriate forums—which, the dissenting members would say, are the state and federal industrial commissions of this country—and that unions do not have limitations placed on their right to represent small businesses, which would be the case if the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005 were to be enacted to limit those rights of representation. No government should remove the right for small businesses to choose a union as their agent—their representative. Therefore, in the dissenting report we make specific reference to removing that restriction and ensuring that the trade unions have the right—as every other body would have—to represent contractors or small businesses, if they so wish it.

I thank the Transport Workers Union for waiting through many divisions and being here this afternoon to witness the tabling of the report. I thank them for their contribution as a union. They presented many witnesses—many workers, not just officials. I think all committee members were impressed by the organisation’s ability to provide evidence from people directly affected by the laws of this land, and we certainly wanted to respond to their concerns in the form of this report.

I will finish by saying that an effort was made by all members to find common ground. We can say that nine of the 17 recommendations in the body of the report were agreed to. There are certainly some good policies that could be adopted by government if those recommendations were agreed to. I guess where we differ is that we say that the seven alternative recommendations made by the dissenting members and a further seven additional recommendations that are to be found in the body of the dissenting report should be adopted by government to ensure that the contractors, employees, labour hire companies, principal contractors and the like know exactly where they stand in the law.

motionnospeech.name: Mr BARRESI

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

motionnospeech.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

debateinfo.title: CUSTOMS AMENDMENT (EXTENSION OF IMPORT CUT-OVER TIME) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.
Ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

talk.start.para: —Before being interrupted by question time, the MPI and subsequent interesting events, I was speaking to the Corporations Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005 and drawing on the extraordinary experience of a company known as Singleton Earthmoving Pty Ltd to make some important points which relate to the Corporations Law. I will briefly recap the story about this very viable company which was unnecessarily forced into administration by a person whom I would describe as a rogue liquidator. As a consequence, the main director of the company, Mr Bernard Wood, and all the unsecured creditors have lost their money. The only person who seems to have done well out of the decision to put the company into administration and consequently wind up the company is the liquidator himself, Mr Ariff.

speech.para: There is some good news at the end of all this. Mr Bernard Wood, a highly respectable character, has got back up on his feet and started a new company doing the same sort of work as he was doing previously. He has taken the resources of that company to attempt, at least, to pay back some of the money to the unsecured creditors. Of course, the original company is no longer a viable concern because, firstly, the liquidator seized all the plant and machinery of the company and, secondly, the liquidator is now owed up to $200,000 for his services.

I am delighted to say that a week or so ago the creditors called another meeting to challenge the original decision of the creditors’ meeting to pay this amount of remuneration to Mr Ariff and, indeed, to challenge the decision to wind up the company. Mr Bernard Wood and a number of creditors now claim that a Mr Gary Phillips, who apparently is the solicitor to Mr Ariff, was the person who either moved or seconded a number of these motions, including the motion to pay the remuneration to Mr Ariff, even though Mr Gary Phillips apparently had no status as a non-secured creditor and nor was he holding a proxy of an unsecured creditor.

talk.start.para: —Did he get part of the action?
