The problem that we therefore confront is the fact that these camels eat most plant material, including fresh grasses and shrubs. They also live up to 50 years and breed actively for about 30 years, so you can imagine the problem that is confronting our primary producers. It is also creating a huge challenge for us to protect our desert environment. The camels severely damage native trees such as the quandong native peach. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last month I attended the 98th annual general meeting of the North Bondi Surf Club—Australia’s largest surf club, with over 1,800 members. I was delighted to present 50-year Surf Life Saving Association awards to Ralph Clark, Michael Gray, Tony Rule, Terry Schofield and Keith Snell. I was especially delighted to see Jim Spencer receive his 75-year service award, his vigorous address-in-reply testifying to the preservative qualities of salt water.

speech.para: Although founded in 1906, North Bondi does not claim to be the oldest surf club. There is a contest for that title, between Bondi Surf Bathers’ Life Saving Club, a few hundred metres south along the promenade, and Bronte Surf Club, two beaches further south again, whose AGM I also attended recently. North Bondi was part of my life almost from the time I could walk, as my father was a member. It was where, too many years ago, I earned my bronze and instructor’s certificate.

Bondi Beach is Australia’s best-known and most popular beach. It is a world-famous tourist icon, a must-see and must-swim location for millions of visitors. The Australian surf, however, is often as treacherous as it is alluring, and without the surf lifesaving movement our great surfing beaches would have to be closed to the public. The cost of hiring full-time lifeguards to patrol Bondi on a busy summer’s weekend would be unaffordable. Our greatest tourist destinations, our greatest places of recreation, therefore depend entirely on the volunteer service of hundreds of lifesavers to keep them safe.

In 2005, the 410 proficient lifesavers of North Bondi performed 522 rescues, bringing the total number of rescues performed there since 1906 to 12,425. On Easter Sunday the dangers of the surf were demonstrated once more when 12 swimmers were caught in a sudden rip. Eleven were saved, but despite the best efforts of the lifesavers one was never found and is presumed drowned. Each of those rescues represents a life saved, and in many cases lives of swimmers are saved because lifesavers put their own lives on the line. The life lost on Easter Sunday could have been 12 lives lost were it not for the lifesavers of North Bondi. Indeed, they save lives not only in the surf, as they demonstrated only last weekend when they were called on to revive a person who had collapsed at the end of the City to Surf.

The surf lifesaving movement has an important role in promoting a healthy outdoor lifestyle for young Australians. There are over 5,000 Nippers in the Sydney branch area, and 650 of them are at North Bondi. Each surf club relies on a strong and enthusiastic committee to put in many hours of time in administration, in addition to the hours spent on patrol. North Bondi’s team is led by Grant McMah as president and kept in line by a superefficient club secretary, Michael Wright.

In my first speech last year I spoke about the very Australian egalitarianism of surf clubs. The surf clubs of Australia attract the broadest range of members: the wealthy and the battlers, judges and garbos, policemen and villains, teachers and truants. My own electorate is one of the most diverse in Australia, and that diversity and the easygoing, tolerant way in which we delight in it is epitomised by the surf clubs of Wentworth.

All surf clubs are always short of money. They always need new gear and new buildings, and for the most part they can rely on support from their community, local councils and state governments. I have written today to support North Bondi’s application for a $500,000 grant from the state government through the Surf Life Saving New South Wales Surf Club Development Program, to be spent on the refurbishment of the North Bondi surf club.

The federal government historically has made very few contributions to support surf clubs, other than some grants from the heritage budget. The federal government obviously cannot fund every good cause, but there are few that are more deserving than that of lifesaving. The surf clubs of Australia will always deserve our support and Australia’s support.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to raise a matter of concern in this House that should concern not only the members of this House but also parents from all walks of life, from all corners of this country. It relates to the capacity of children in our publicly funded libraries to access internet pornography.

speech.para: I attended a very important seminar last week that was sponsored by a gentleman called Warwick Marsh, who is doing great work on behalf of the Australian Fatherhood Foundation. At that function I heard very harrowing reports from an American academic about the effects of pornography, particularly on children.

Imagine my concern when I returned to my electorate to read an article in the Berwick Leader. It was written by a journalist called Dimity Barber, who is a very good and capable journalist from this particular paper. This article said:

quote.para: Libraries across Casey and Cardinia have been urged to install Internet filters to stop children viewing pornography.

speech.para: Effectively, their survey indicated that, in a number of these libraries—which are publicly funded libraries in an electorate in a growth-belt area with a large number of young families—children could actually access pornography via the library. This journalist questioned a person from the library corporation named Prue Menzies, who was the library spokesperson across Casey and Cardinia, and she said that the staff monitored computers and asked people to be considerate of others. However, when this journalist went into the libraries, the journalist was able to access pornography virtually unchecked for as long as they wanted.

I do not know about you, but as a responsible parent and a responsible legislator I think it is our task in this place and across the country to lay markers. I say as a parent and a politician that this is unacceptable. I notice that my friend and colleague the member for La Trobe has come into this place, and he is quoted as saying the same thing. So in this place tonight I am calling for any federal government funding that goes to public libraries, particularly in the Casey-Cardinia library corporation, to be tied with the proviso that there has to be an internet pornography filter installed.

Some may say that this is a draconian measure, a measure that goes too far, but this is a measure that has been successfully trialled in America. It has been tried by concerned parents who experienced similar difficulties in the United States. One may say: ‘Well, this is isolated just to, say, libraries in the Casey-Cardinia library corporation.’ But if you look at some statistics you will see that in late 2002 the Australian Library and Information Association conducted a survey of internet use in public libraries—91 library services, all of which were institutional members of this organisation. The findings indicated that most libraries are providing unfiltered access to the internet and found that public libraries are significant centres for internet access for children.

If that is the case—if a lot of Australian children are going to libraries across the country—surely it is our job as legislators to protect the children from exposure to something that we know will cause them harm. Anecdotally, I have heard stories of people going to those libraries in the Casey-Cardinia library corporation and watching others download pornography. It is not acceptable. Any responsible government—state, federal or local—will mandate that the appropriate internet pornography filters must be installed. They must be installed to protect our kids.

And I go further than just the call for internet pornography filters to be installed in public libraries. I call for them to be installed in child-care centres, because again there is no demand from governments that Internet pornography filters be installed there. That is completely inappropriate. Having spoken to some of my friends from the other side, I know that they will support this.

In closing, it is our job as legislators and as parents to set community standards. It is unacceptable for public libraries and child-care centres to not protect our children. I call in this place at this time for the appropriate filters to be installed and, if necessary, to have that mandated, particularly by the federal government. There are precedents in federal education funding of tying money to conditions being met. I call on all other forms of government to do the same thing to protect our most treasured asset in this place, our children.

talk.start.para: —Those of you who know the Sunshine Coast region of Australia will know of its attraction as a holiday destination. But the good things in my electorate, such as the lifestyle and the beaches, are also responsible for a very high population growth rate in the region. The weather is also attractive all year round, although we did have a cold snap late last week—and would you believe the temperature actually got down to 10 degrees in some spots. Figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that population growth in the Sunshine Coast between 1998 and 2003 was 3.53 per cent, which places it as the third highest growth rate in Australia, behind Mandurah, 74 kilometres south of Perth, with 4.02 per cent and the Gold Coast-Tweed area, with 3.67 per cent. High growth is nothing new in the south-east of Queensland. We have an influx of some 1,000 people per week from other parts of the country. The growth has brought extra cars to the Sunshine Coast, thereby putting extra pressure on the road networks.

speech.para: I am pleased today to announce that real progress is being made in the construction of a new road in the busiest business and shopping hub of the region, the Maroochydore Central Business District. Maroochy Boulevard will link the major arterial Sunshine Motorway to Plaza Parade. It is associated with a major interchange construction and the Maroochy Boulevard bridge, which was completed some time ago, has already been a medium-term white elephant in that it is totally ready but it needs a road constructed to it. Together these three roadwork components will help relieve the growing burden on Sugar Road and Maud Street to the south and Maroochydore Road to the north as well as Plaza Parade and Evans Street.

Mr Speaker, as you would expect, I have closely monitored the preliminary planning and lent my weight to help avoid stagnation of this joint private developer, local government and state government project. The Maroochy Boulevard project has been of particular interest to me because of the need to find a solution to the traffic problems in the region. I am particularly pleased that the project is now moving much closer towards completion.

Unfortunately, a Queensland Labor government project of widening the Sunshine Motorway from single lane to double lane between Buderim-Mooloolaba Road and Maroochydore Road has been delayed. Public consultation is well under way, with letters posted to landowners and business people whose properties may potentially be impacted upon by the new Maroochy Boulevard and associated projects. These landowners have been invited to speak with consultants in the state government to discuss their issues and concerns. In addition, neighbouring landowners whose properties may not be directly affected have also been sent letters by the state government. In the coming weeks, around early September, the preliminary designs for the project will be taken to the wider community in Maroochydore, located in my electorate of Fisher, and to the surrounding areas. It is expected that this will comprise newspaper advertisements and staffed public displays, which will give interested residents the chance to give feedback on this significant project.

I have campaigned for several years—in fact, since before 2001—for the urgent need for a link road from Sunshine Motorway to the Maroochydore Central Business District. It has been a long, hard slog but the residents of Fisher can now almost see light at the end of the tunnel. With this project now having been discussed in various forms for at least a decade, some locals have suggested that the past years of high population growth in the area have caught up with the need and that the proposed road as a single lane each way as suggested might already be inadequate. I have to say that that is my personal view. However, I would also comment that Maroochy Boulevard is better late than never. I call on the state government to take those sensible concerns on board and if funds can be released I suggest that the road be made at least two lanes each way. I am pleased to be able to support the Maroochy Boulevard project so far and look forward to the day when the road will open up access into the Maroochydore Central Business District.

Mr Speaker, I suggest that you on occasions have been to the Sunshine Coast. You know what a wonderful area it is, and you know how important this new infrastructure is for our local community. What we need of course is to make sure that roads keep up with the population. I want to urge the state government to put a much better proportion of their funds into road improvements on the Sunshine Coast. The Sunshine Coast is close to Brisbane. Eighty per cent of people travelling to the Sunshine Coast do so by road. But we do need better investment from the state government. I am, however, pleased that Maroochy Boulevard is under way. It is a major step forward and it will dramatically improve the congestion in the Maroochydore Central Business District. It will make our area an even more desirable place in which to live. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I will continue my remarks on the feral animal problem confronting rural Australia. As I said, camels endanger our desert environment not only by the destruction of native trees but also by degrading areas with drinkable water which provide a refuge for native animals and plants. For pastoralists they also have a serious impact on the operation of our cattle stations. They cause major damage to fences and infrastructure such as cattle watering points and, unfortunately, camels are also potential carriers of tuberculosis and brucellosis.

speech.para: The problem is that at the moment the current methods of control are largely ad hoc and have had little impact on overall camel populations. It is therefore the responsibility of the Commonwealth government, in association with state and territory governments, hopefully with the assistance of some well-focused recommendations of the report of the House Standing Committee on Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, to actually do something serious about reducing the number of feral camels that exist in Australia. Obviously control methods include shooting, trapping and fencing, but to date they have proven to be an absolute failure.

I therefore briefly refer in passing to the success of the donkey telemetry system for the control of feral donkeys in the east and west Pilbara, which was also brought before the committee during its trip to north-west Western Australia recently. This involves a ‘Judas animal’ being fitted with a radio transmitter. The collared animal seeks outs other donkeys in its home range. The collared animal is then tracked by helicopter and all donkeys found with a Judas animal are culled in the most humane and, dare I suggest, the only proper way to deal with this particular problem. Since the introduction of the Judas program in 1994, over 81,000 donkeys have been culled and 38 pastoral leases have been declared free of donkeys as a result of this program. The program has the advantage of enabling control and doing it properly.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 8.00 pm, the debate is interrupted.

debate.para: The following notices were given:
D r S tone to move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Holsworthy program—Special Operations working accommodation and base redevelopment stage 1, Holsworthy, NSW.
D r S tone to move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: CSIRO entomology bioscience laboratory at Black Mountain, Canberra, ACT.
D r S tone to move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Operational upgrade of the Darwin detention facility, NT.
D r S tone to move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Upgrade patrol boat facilities, Darwin Naval Base, NT.
D r S tone to move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Redevelopment of Kokoda Barracks, Canungra, Qld.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. IR Causley) took the chair at 9.33 am.

talk.start.para: —Last week the member for Greenway, who is in the chamber today, made a statement about how important transport issues are to the people of Western Sydney. She went on to praise the federal government’s spending on Westlink, the M7 project. The member for Greenway could not be more correct when she said the people of Western Sydney have transport at the forefront of their minds. In saying that, people are looking for action from this government on petrol prices. They are looking for more than praise of expenditure programs which are already under way. Efficient and effective infrastructure are part of the transport issues that the people of Western and south-western Sydney are concerned about, but that is not all they are concerned about.

speech.para: The transport issue that sticks most in the minds of people in Western Sydney at the moment is petrol prices. While the Westlink project represents welcome investment in transport and economic capacity in the greater Western Sydney area, constituents of my electorate are screaming for relief from high petrol prices. Monday’s Daily Telegraph reported that for people from south-west Sydney who work in the CBD it can cost up to $300 a week, not including parking, to get to and from work because of surging petrol prices. To most people it seems that this government does not have a clue about what to do about rising petrol prices. It does not seem to have a plan to provide any form of relief to motorists.

Labor have outlined a plan to provide relief to motorists. We know what the government can do to make things better. The opposition know that, in order to give motorists relief, action needs to be taken and taken now. The opposition have already released details of steps that would start addressing the problem of higher fuel costs. We know there is not one single solution to this problem, but we also know that something needs to be done. Australia needs to reduce its reliance on imported oil and develop its own liquid fuel market. We must provide a real future for biofuel industries and give consideration to the use of ethanol blended fuels. Competition should also be increased in the fuel industry, using it to achieve the lowest possible prices at petrol pumps. Instead of helping people in Western Sydney, the government is more interested in extending welfare to millionaires and pursuing its extreme industrial relations agenda. This government is out of touch. It needs to do something about high fuel prices now and not simply wait until the next election.

talk.start.para: —Today I rise to mark the 60th anniversary of victory in the Pacific, and I also want to pay tribute to the amazing World War II veterans of Riverstone. Victory in the Pacific Day was a chance to celebrate the courage of the Australians who fought to secure our freedom. It was a chance to celebrate everything we hold dear in our community and our country. I spent VP Day with the Riverstone-Schofields RSL sub-branch. There we unveiled a plaque funded by the federal government as part of the Saluting Their Service program. We also honoured six very brave World War II veterans, and I wish to name them today. Eric Martin, Joe Counter, Gordon Martin, George Drayton, John Hazell and Bernie Abbott fought for the ultimate cause: the freedom of millions of Australians and, indeed, millions of people around the world.

speech.para: Some of these veterans served in Papua New Guinea and one of them was held in a prisoner of war camp. These six gentlemen are unassuming—they do not seek praise or attention—and yet they are heroes to us all. John addressed a number of students during the ceremony. He spoke with honesty, integrity and a sense of humour. He spoke of his wish that a war like the one he witnessed never occur again. The many school students who were present responded with warmth and compassion to hearing stories that they had never heard before. It was indeed a very moving moment.

Between 1939 and 1945 nearly one million Australians like George, John, Eric, Gordon, Bernie and Joe served in uniform. To put it in perspective, that was one-fifth of Australia’s population at the time. Although Australians were stationed across the Middle East and throughout Europe, some of the most important work was done in the Pacific, notably in Papua New Guinea. The battle at Milne Bay saw the Australian Army achieve the first defeat on land of the Japanese Imperial Army. When Prime Minister Chifley announced the end of the war there was dancing in the streets of cities and towns all across Australia. Many of the women present at Monday’s meeting served in a munitions factory, having to leave their homes and travel interstate. They remember the celebration and dancing in the streets.

On Monday I encouraged the people of Riverstone and Schofields to give thanks to the service men and women who fought to protect our very unique nation. In this nation we value friendship, family and community. We believe that life is a mixture of hard work, conviction and laughter. In his words to the Harrow School in England in 1941, Winston Churchill said:

quote.para: Do not let us speak of darker days ... These are not dark days; these are great days—the greatest days our country has ever lived; and we must all thank God that we have been allowed, each of us according to our stations, to play a part in making these days memorable in the history of our race. ( Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last month I attended the AGM of Chelsea Red Cross—a great group of people doing some good work in Chelsea. At the AGM, awards were made to two members for long service. Gwen Walker was awarded a medal for 20 years service. Gwen is in her 80s and is still a very busy member of Chelsea Red Cross. She was Regional Chairman and Regional Secretary of area 8b, and she was Treasurer and Secretary of Rosebud Red Cross for some time. She is the Secretary of Chelsea Red Cross and has been for the last eight years. Gwen does emergency registration and emergency catering and does duty on the mobile blood bank when it visits Chelsea. George Brain was given a medal for 10 years service to the Red Cross. George sets up the tables for street stalls, sets up the tables and chairs for Red Cross functions and attends the fun auction. I am told that the Red Cross men do not like attending meetings but are always happy to support their wives. This is very true of George, who is generous with his time and muscle in support of his wife, Ann, and her work at the Red Cross. I congratulate and thank both Gwen and George for their contributions to our community.

speech.para: I have had a rash of school principals in my electorate leaving or resigning recently, and I want to thank each of them for their contribution not only to their schools but also to education generally. Jenny Stuart left Aspendale Primary School after 14 years as principal and 37 years in education. Jenny was the longest serving principal Aspendale has had. She has a very strong commitment to the link she sees between a student’s welfare and academic achievement. Jenny has left behind a school proud of itself and its 80-year history and it is looking forward with enthusiasm to the future. Jenny was one of the first principals to ring me in outrage when the Prime Minister made his notorious comments about government schools being value free.

Anthony Levett has left St Patrick’s School in Mentone after eight years as principal there. Anthony managed two building projects while he was there which have added enormously to the school. He refurbished the junior school, including a multipurpose room and a new resource centre including an IT room. Anthony got himself involved with all aspects of the school such as doing his bit at the school fete. Anthony has moved on to St Dominic’s in Camberwell. John Jackson has left Edithvale Primary School after four years as its principal. His colleagues describe John as a person who can and does do anything around the school and can cope with any emergency—with calmness. At the same time, John cares for his students, knows who they are and what they are up to. Finally, Lee Murnane has left Mordialloc Primary School after six years at the helm and is now at Brighton Beach Primary School. Lee is always aware of the importance of community and generous in his support by offering school facilities for community fund raising. Lee started an extensive building program at Mordialloc, which is due for completion later this year. I would like to put on record my thanks to each of these four principals for their work at their individual schools.

subdebateinfo.title: World War II and Vietnam War Commemoration

talker.name: Billson, Bruce, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary (Foreign Affairs) and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs)
talker.name: Mr BILLSON

talk.start.para: —Last Sunday was a magnificent day in Dunkley where the community took advantage of the opportunity to pay homage and respect and convey our thanks to the World War II and Vietnam veterans. My congratulations go to Brian Bensley and the team at the Seaford RSL and Ross Pulling and Len Streets at the Frankston RSL for their excellent arrangements on the day.

speech.para: The day was also an opportunity for Vietnam veterans to come together to mark the 39th anniversary of the Battle of Long Tan, which actually falls tomorrow on 18 August. On that day in 1966 D Company of 6RAR was engaged in a ferocious action in a rubber plantation against the main body of the Vietcong regiment. The Vietcong regiment numbered at least 1,500 soldiers. Our soldiers were severely outnumbered more than 10 to one and the enemy attacked with mortars, rifle and machine gun fire. In torrential rain the Australians fought back with support of artillery fired from the Nui Dat base. Air support was called for but was unable to identify targets due to the difficult conditions. D Company held firm and, as support arrived, the enemy retreated as darkness descended. Morning revealed 245 Vietcong soldiers and 18 Australians had lost their lives, with 24 Australian soldiers wounded.

This brings me to last Sunday at the Frankston ceremony commemorating the Battle of Long Tan. During the service Dave Sabben, a great man from my electorate, who served as a platoon leader during the Battle of Long Tan, provided marvellous insight into not only the battle but also Australia’s overall involvement in the Vietnam War. Please let me share some of Dave’s words with honourable members. He said:

quote.para: Please remember us with truth, honesty, accuracy.

Please don’t believe the lies, the half-truths, the deliberate slurs or the ignorant accusations. We weren’t superheroes. But nor were we scoundrels. (Well, most of us weren’t, anyway!) We were just men who did our job.
And please don’t believe that we didn’t do our job!
We did not go to Viet Nam to invade the North. We didn’t go to topple their government. We didn’t go to remove Ho Chi Minh from power. We went to stop the fighting in the South.

We achieved this in January 1973. The Allies forced the North to sign the Paris Peace Accord. The Accord agreed to halt all hostilities, the withdrawal of all non-Vietnamese forces, the exchange of POWs and, importantly, that the North would honour their border with the South.
It was over. We had achieved our aim. The fighting in the South was stopped. We came home.
In January 1973, our Governor General, Sir Paul Hasluck told the parliament and people of Australia:
Hostilities in Viet Nam have ceased.
How can it be said that we “lost the war”—that we had been “defeated”—that we “didn’t do the job”?

More than two years later—two years!—in March 1975—the North broke the peace treaty. They invaded the South in a deliberate act of a new war. They started the Third Indochina War. In two months they swept down a weak and recovering South Viet Nam to Saigon and took the city.
We were not at war with North Viet Nam. We had no troops in Viet Nam for two years. In fact, we had an embassy in Hanoi at the time and had diplomatic relations with North Viet Nam!
It is an act of cowardly deceit to mark the fall of Saigon as the end of Australia’s war in Viet Nam. And it is another act of cowardly deceit to connect Viet Vets with the fall of Saigon.
Please remember us with truth, honesty, accuracy.
They’re all heroes to me. They started our involvement before I was born and I admire them all. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Mr Michael and Mrs Sheila Cahill

talk.start.para: —Today I would like to raise a matter on behalf of my constituent Mrs Sheila Cahill of north Rockhampton. Tragically, Mrs Cahill’s husband, Michael Cahill, went missing in Malaysia seven years ago. This week marks the seventh anniversary of his disappearance. Michael has been registered as a missing person for that period of time but has not been declared dead, and no death certificate has been issued. Mrs Cahill is in contact with Interpol, who call from time to time to check if there has been any contact from her husband but, sadly, she has not heard from him since his disappearance and she believes him to be dead.

speech.para: After seven years it is quite understandable that Mrs Cahill would like some closure. Apart from ending the emotional anguish of living in limbo, she would like to be able to take the practical steps that would allow her to move on with her life. Right now, that is very difficult because her house, bank accounts, and numerous other personal affairs are in both her name and that of her missing husband. So Mrs Cahill is unable to do anything until her husband, missing now for seven years, is officially declared dead. What a run-around that process is proving to be for my constituent.

The department of foreign affairs advised Mrs Cahill that the processes involved in having a person declared deceased are the responsibility of the relevant state or territory authority, and to contact the state coroner, suggesting that he may order a death certificate to be issued. However, the Queensland State Coroner’s office has written back to say that his jurisdiction to investigate the disappearance of a person in Malaysia is questionable. The state coroner did, however, obtain a report from the Federal Police, which stated in part:

quote.para: Lengthy inquiries conducted by Interpol Canberra with the assistance of Interpol Kuala Lumpur and the Australian Federal Police overseas liaison officer attached to the Australian embassy in Kuala Lumpur have been unsuccessful in locating Mr Cahill. In February 1999 the AFP’s international liaison officer at Kuala Lumpur visited the Interpol Bureau in Malaysia and liaised directly with case officers in relation to the disappearance of Mr Cahill. They provided full access to their files and stated they had done everything possible to trace Mr Cahill.

speech.para: However, the state coroner’s advice to Mrs Cahill on this report was less than flattering to the procedures undertaken by the AFP. The state coroner states in his letter:

quote.para: I am of the view that it is inadequate.

speech.para: Mrs Cahill has had to live with this for seven years, and now finds that her life is yet again left on hold because it appears that the Federal Police have not been sufficiently thorough in either their investigations or their reporting of the conclusions reached in respect of Mr Cahill’s disappearance. Earlier this month I wrote to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Chris Ellison, as the minister responsible for the Federal Police, seeking an immediate and adequate investigation into Mrs Cahill’s missing husband. I trust that the minister will respond promptly to that request so that Mrs Cahill can finally put this matter to rest.

talk.start.para: —Every so often one is privileged to know a person who is an outstanding individual and a role model for his fellow citizens. In the parliament today I would like to recognise the outstanding service of Mr John Frank Rourke of the Sunshine Coast. Mr Rourke has been very much involved in the dairying, livestock and rural real estate industries between 1949 and 1985, and particularly since he has been on the Sunshine Coast but even earlier in Victoria he has worked very hard on behalf of veterans and their dependants.

speech.para: Mr Rourke’s service to the rural community began in 1946 after his discharge from operational service in the Royal Australian Air Force. He joined the RSL in 1949. His voluntary activities as an Agricultural Show Society arena and sheep shearing commentator at the Melbourne Royal Show, the Sydney Royal Show, the Royal Brisbane Show, the Royal Adelaide Show and in country towns has earned him honorary life membership of the Royal Agricultural Society Victoria and other agricultural societies.

I have got to know Mr Rourke very well, particularly since he has been on the Sunshine Coast working on behalf of the ex-service community. He was instrumental in establishing a regional office for Legacy in Maroochydore and held the position of secretary of the Sunshine Coast Legacy from 1990 to 1996. From 1994 to 1998 he was president of the Maroochydore RSL subbranch.

The RSL segment of a veteran’s funeral is a moving part of proceedings and Mr Rourke has delivered dedications on numerous occasions with honour and respect. Mr Rourke has taken part in local secondary school pre-Anzac Day celebrations and has been the representative of the Returned Services League at cadet services.

Mr Rourke has had a very interesting career in rural industry. When many people retire, that is exactly what they do. But, if anything, when Mr Rourke retired he became more and more active, and the list of recognitions that he has received is most impressive. The RSL has given him the RSL Meritorious Service Award for 25 years outstanding service, the RSL Service Award for 50 years service and RSL life membership for outstanding service. Mr Rourke is a remarkable individual. I greatly admire him. I am pleased to have this opportunity in the parliament to salute his service. If Australia had more Frank Rourkes then this wonderful country would be an even better place.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to say a few words about a recent visit I made to France. I want to speak particularly about a location I visited in northern France that holds a special place in the history of our country, and that is the town of Fromelles. Fromelles is a small village in northern France not far from Lille. It is a place where in 1916 the Australian forces were first engaged in a heavy sense on the Western Front in what was, frankly, a disastrous battle but a battle which outlined the bravery and courage of our troops on the Western Front at that time and through to the end of that war in 1918.

speech.para: The battle of Fromelles was a particularly devastating encounter. It went for just over a day. It involved very heavy casualties for the Australian troops and also for others. Places such as Fromelles still, so many years later, have memorial services. If you tell them you are an Australian you are always treated with a great deal of respect. The museum at Fromelles is a credit to those involved. It is an excellent little tribute to the war effort in that area and particularly to the diggers.

A range of people have been dedicated to celebrating that effort over the years. I would particularly like to note my appreciation to Monsieur Martial Delebarre, the president of the ASBF, the Friends of the 15th Brigade, who was very helpful to me during the time I was there; Monsieur Hubert Huchette, the Mayor of Fromelles; and Monsieur Francis Delattre, the president of the local veterans’ affairs organisation. They made me most welcome. I was able to present a wreath at the Australian memorial and to inspect VC corner in the cemetery there. It is an unusual cemetery. It is the only cemetery where there are no individual gravestones. It is an entirely Australian cemetery, and it is a very moving place to visit.

There are also a range of investigations going on in the area about the potential for finding some additional Australian graves there. The hope is that, with an investigation at a location called Pheasant Wood on the outskirts of Fromelles, which I visited, they may well be able to discover additional places where a large number of diggers have been interred and this will lead to a proper burial and a proper recognition of their sacrifice. To all those involved, thank you very much for the support you gave me while I was over there. I would particularly like to recognise Charlotte Seillier, an eight-year-old girl who played the clarinet at the service I attended there. It was a moving occasion and to all those involved I offer my thanks and respect.

talk.start.para: —I wish to give praise to the opening of the St Francis Xavier College on Friday, 5 August 2005. I had the privilege of opening this great new education facility in the electorate of La Trobe. The special guests of the day were Bishop Coffey, the Bishop of Sale; Father Hugh Brown, Chairperson of St Francis Xavier College board; Father Peter Slater, Vicar General, Parish Priest of St Michael’s, Berwick; Father John Allen, Parish Priest of Our Lady Help of Christians, Narre Warren; Father Thomas Karamakuzhiyl, Assistant Priest of Our Lady Help of Christians, Narre Warren; and, of course, the principal of the school, Mr Paul Desmond. There were other special guests there but I have confined my comments to the local ones. I would also like to acknowledge the great work of the school captains from the senior school, Tim McKay and Melanie Van Diemen—they did a fantastic job MCing the entire day. Also, thanks must go to the principal’s secretary, Mrs Leslie Lancaster, the business manager of the school, Dominic Langdon, and the head of campus, Malcolm Joseph. I would also like to acknowledge the singers and the band; they did a fantastic job on the day.

speech.para: The opening of St Francis Xavier College is a very important addition to the educational services in La Trobe. St Francis Xavier will offer a new junior campus catering to years 7, 8 and 9 for approximately 900 students. It is great to see. The buildings consist of 12 general-purpose classrooms, a science room, art, drama, music, technology rooms, home economics, library, hall, and administration facilities. The grand total project cost was $14.6 million. I am very proud to say that the Howard government contributed $3.6 million.

The original campus was developed in Beaconsfield and, as a result of recent growth in the local community, the site now caters to years 10, 11 and 12 students in Berwick. As the south-eastern corridor continues to expand—we are actually part of the fastest growing corridor in Australia—all of these new educational facilities are absolutely fantastic for our area. The school will focus heavily on literacy standards, as emphasised by the Howard government. It is a drug-free school and it has excellent facilities. The students there are going to have a great future. I commend the staff and the parents for their professionalism. The opening was a great day. It was very professional and there was a fantastic service. It was a privilege and an honour for me to be there on the day.

talk.start.para: —I am always keen to celebrate the success of the community in the Shortland electorate. At the moment, I have Phill Pallas, a social work student from the University of Newcastle, working in my office and he wrote the speech that I am presenting today. He is working closely with the youth sector in the Wyong shire to identify the recreational needs of young people living in the southern end of my electorate. With one of the fastest growing populations in our nation, the Wyong shire is popular for young families and families with teenagers. There are some 9,000 young people living in the northern part of the Wyong shire.

speech.para: The issues affecting these young people are diverse and varied. They include mental health concerns, access to alternative education, job creation and family violence. Through consultation with local youth services and young people, we have identified that a major issue for young people is the availability of social and recreational activities in the area. One local youth service operates up to seven youth centres with four part-time workers. Often these centres are only open for a few hours per week. Whilst the youth workers are some of the best in their field, everyone would agree that it is a tough task to build positive rapport with the young people in the local community with such limited time and resources. What is required is more funding for youth services to be able to offer quality service provision for young people throughout Wyong shire.

Even more of an issue is access to the services that do exist to serve young people. There are many pockets of young people who are unable to access services, due to the deplorable state of our transport system, which is basically a private bus company that operates in the area. In one such place, Mannering Park, there is one bus in and one bus out of the suburb on the weekend. With no youth specific activities organised in these areas, young people are placed at an extreme disadvantage. Affordable frequent transport is required if we are to demonstrate to young people that they are a valuable part of our society. Despite the lack of services and transportation, there lies within the community a real strength to band together, to draw upon the assets they have and to move forward. There is an emerging generation of young people within the Wyong shire who are committed to positive contributions to the wider community. It is indeed sad to see the media focus on the small percentage of young people who seem to be doing the wrong thing and to see how it never promotes the strong movement of young people committed to building the community which makes our nation.

I am a big believer in giving honour where honour is due. It is a joy to see Wyong Shire Council receive a local government award for the second year in a row. That award this year was for the most innovative youth week program—a program in which 7,000 young people were involved. The youth development officer of Wyong Shire Council, Sarah Masters, is to be congratulated on her consistent and dedicated approach to her role. Young people are the future of Australia, with their creativity, enthusiasm and zeal for life. We must support and foster their many talents as they contribute to our nation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)—In accordance with standing order 193 the time for members’ statements has concluded.

debate.para: Debate resumed from 11 August, on motion by Mr Howard:

item.para: notes that 15 August 2005 (VP Day) marks 60 years since the Japanese surrender which ended World War II;
recalls with profound gratitude the heroic achievements and sacrifices of those Australians who served in the defence forces during the war, as well as those who contributed on the civilian front;
particularly remembers the thousands of Australians who lost their lives or were wounded in the conflict, and especially recalls the suffering of so many Australians taken as prisoners of war;
whilst never forgetting those who suffered during World War II, acknowledges the strength and importance of the post World War II relationship between Australia and Japan; and
resolves that Australia’s efforts should always be directed to ensuring that a conflict of that magnitude never occurs again.

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)—Both the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition spoke to the motion for 11 minutes. Standing orders allow 15 minutes, but I suggest to the whips that, as there is a long list of speakers, if members could restrict their contributions to no more than 10 minutes it would be appreciated.

—I am very pleased to speak on this important motion. The debate opened with appropriate remarks from both the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. It is appropriate that this House marks the end of the war in the Pacific. This is an opportunity for the generations who came after the generation who won World War II to say thank you. The Leader of the Opposition referred to the generation who won World War II as ‘Australia’s toughest’—something I certainly endorse. World War II was the only period in our history where our very existence as a nation was brought under threat. There is a historical debate about whether there was any real prospect of Australia being physically invaded. That debate will never be resolved. Historians on both sides have legitimate points of view, but I think this is largely hypothetical and irrelevant. There is no doubt that, if Great Britain had fallen, at that stage it would have been unsustainable for Australia to continue as a sovereign nation. The generation that won World War II can say, ‘I saved my country.’ There are not many people who can say that, but the one million Australians who served in our armed forces could say that and the 200,000 of those who are still with us still can say that. We should take every opportunity to say thank you to these people.

speech.para: A few months ago I was struck by how quickly generations can leave us. I was looking through pictures of the commemoration in Gallipoli in 1990 when former Prime Minister Hawke took a group of World War I veterans with him to celebrate and commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Gallipoli landings. About 30 World War I veterans—heroes—accompanied Prime Minister Hawke, and it struck me that none of those gentlemen are with us any longer. That was only 15 years ago. It is very easy to think that World War II veterans will always be with us. Of course they will not. Their numbers thin every day. We should take every opportunity to thank them for their service and to thank them for saving our nation.

We took the opportunity in my electorate on Monday of thanking our veterans who served in World War II. I was honoured to present medallions marking the 60th anniversary of the end of the war to Ellen Ashcroft, David Barnett, Cecil Boland, Mark Bush, Gwen Chaumont, Thelma Daley, Anthony Ebejer, Dan Goadsby, Enid Harris, June Hudson, Samuel Hull, Doreen Hunns, Lesley McHenry, Hugh Morrison, William O’Connell, Sidney Payne, Clifford Reid, Raymond Sansome, Freda Scarboro, Colin Smith and George Winch. There are, of course, many other medallions to present in coming months, but those are the ones I presented on VP Day. I thank Fairfield RSL for hosting the ceremony in the evening and Fairfield council for hosting the ceremony in the morning.

It is a time when we remember all those who served and those who made the ultimate sacrifice. We remember the names of people like Sir Roden Cutler and Keith Payne who won the nation’s highest military honour for acts of bravery that remain inspirational to this day, six decades after they occurred. We remember a similarly inspirational character in Weary Dunlop, and we remember all his mates and colleagues who served in the prisoner of war camps with stoicism and sometimes with humour—and with that showed they were better men than their captors.

We remember the thousands of heroes who did not win high honours but who made the highest sacrifice. I can think of no more eloquent exposition of the legacy of these heroes than that of former Prime Minister Keating, who on 11 November 1993 spoke at the interment of Australia’s unknown soldier. He said:

quote.para: On all sides they were the heroes of that war; not the generals and the politicians but soldiers and sailors and nurses—those who taught us to endure hardship, to show courage, to be bold as well as resilient, to believe in ourselves, to stick together.

The Unknown Australian Soldier whom we are interring today was one of those who, by his deeds, proved that real nobility and grandeur belongs not to empires and nations, but to the people on whom they, in the last resort, always depend.

speech.para: Those remarks, of course, refer to World War I but the principles equally refer to World War II.

We remember some of the great battles in which Australians cemented their reputation as great warriors but, more importantly, as good men who would make the final sacrifice to help their mates. We remember Kokoda. The Japanese there were fanatical warriors; it was a campaign with colossal casualties. More Australians died in that campaign than any other. The average age of soldiers who died in that campaign was between 18 and 19, a very sobering thought. Between July and November 1942, 600 men were killed and over a thousand were wounded.

We should also take this opportunity to pay tribute to the natives of New Guinea who have been immortalised as the ‘fuzzy wuzzy angels’. I think that it is a matter of some regret that this nation has not formally recognised the efforts of the fuzzy wuzzy angels. I know this is a matter that the Hon. Charlie Lynn, a Liberal member of the New South Wales upper house, has been pursuing and I support him in that campaign. I believe that we as a nation should give recognition through a medal or some other form to those fuzzy wuzzy angels who are no longer with us. I once had the privilege of meeting one of them—funnily enough, at an AFL game which he was brought down to watch as part of the AFL’s tribute to the fuzzy wuzzy angels. I think that we can do better. This nation needs to pay tribute to the natives of New Guinea who saved so many Australians.

talk.start.para: —Were you watching AFL too?

—I always take the opportunity to watch the AFL. We remember, of course, the Battle of the Coral Sea, fought between 5 and 8 May 1942. The Japanese hoped to attack Port Moresby, but they had to gain the advantage in the south-west Pacific first. This battle was an important boost to the morale of our allies around the world. It was the first significant victory of the Allies over the Japanese and, of course, it followed Pearl Harbour and the surrender of Singapore.

speech.para: We remember the Battle of Midway. Here our friend and ally, the United States, heavily outnumbered, won an amazing victory. This was a battle that the United States can be proud of. Australians, of course, played a vital role through naval signals and intelligence. It was a vital battle in heading off any potential invasion of Australia. We remember Milne Bay. This battle ended any chance of the Japanese taking Port Moresby. The Japanese landed on Milne Bay on 25 and 26 August 1942. Within 10 days the allies had turned them back.

These battles, together with the Battle of the Beachheads and the Battle of Wau, represent the battle for Australia. On 5 September, Smithfield RSL in my electorate will be holding a commemoration of the Battle for Australia, which I hope to be present at, with the permission of my chief whip—parliament is sitting that day and I may be a couple of hours late for parliament. I hope to be present at Smithfield RSL to mark that important commemoration.

I want to make brief particular mention of the role of women in World War II. We often talk about our brave soldiers, as we should, but women played a vital role in securing our country through attachments to the services, the Women’s Land Army, the Red Cross, St John Ambulance and a whole range of other organisations, in often dangerous circumstances. They won the victory just as much as anyone else.

I have spoken about the brave service of Australian men and women; I also want to take a moment to talk about the political leadership of the Allies and the service provided to the cause of freedom by three men in particular. It has often been said that three of our greatest leaders were brought forward during the war. By universal acclamation, the greatest Prime Minister that Great Britain has ever had was Winston Churchill—that is certainly a remark that I endorse. He, as John Kennedy said, ‘mobilised the English language and sent it into war’. He certainly played a role in motivating the English people when it seemed that all was lost. He was a hero, and today we pay tribute to him. He also, of course, made mistakes, but at least he was trying to find strategic ways of beating the biggest threat to Western civilisation ever, when others were prepared to give up. From the other side of the world, we pay tribute to Winston Churchill.

Again, Franklin Delano Roosevelt is often regarded, with Washington and Lincoln, as being amongst the best presidents the United States has ever had. He showed great leadership, was a great motivating force and had a great strategic mind, and we are thankful that he was there to lead us at that stage in World War II.

Then there was our own John Joseph Curtin: in my mind, he was the greatest Prime Minister this nation has ever had. He warned that this crisis was coming and he was ignored. He felt very keenly the loss of any Australian serviceman. There are legendary stories of him walking at night around the gardens of the Lodge, less than a kilometre away, worrying about the deaths of Australian soldiers on the transports bringing them back to Australia. He has been criticised for that. I note that David Barnett wrote an article in the Australian a few months ago criticising him for that, saying he was a lesser man because he worried about the deaths of Australian soldiers.

That is an argument I reject completely. He was a greater man for that. He took the tough decisions. They were not easy decisions: he knew he was risking Australian lives. He did it because he felt Australia was under attack, but he did not do it in a blase manner. He did not do it in a manner which indicated that he was relaxed about the loss of any life; he did it in a manner that shows he knew the value of human life, and he worried about his decisions. I think that made him a greater man. He was prepared to make those tough decisions but also prepared to worry so deeply and personally about the consequences.
VP Day on 15 August represents an opportunity for Australia to remember and to give thanks, and that is what we do. As a parliament and a nation, we will remember them. Lest we forget.
A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

interrupt.para: Sitting suspended from 10.12 am to 10.29 am

talker.name: Lloyd, Jim, MP
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads
talker.name: Mr LLOYD

talk.start.para: —I welcome this opportunity to provide my support for the 60th anniversary of VP Day—the end of the war in the Pacific—on 15 August 2005 and, of course, my support for our wonderful World War II veterans, widows and families. More than one million Australians served in one form or another in the Second World War. That is a quite amazing figure when you consider that the population of Australia was estimated by the ABS at that time, in 1939, as just under seven million. Tragically, 40,000 Australians lost their lives and 30,000 were imprisoned as prisoners of war during the six long years of World War II. Those significant losses meant that almost every Australian family was in some way affected by the war.

speech.para: I think it is very important on the 60th anniversary of VP Day to recognise both sacrifices of the young Australian men and women who lost their lives and also the lives and achievements of those returned soldiers who not only lived through the dark days of World War II but also rebuilt their lives and rebuilt Australia following the war. I would like to thank the Prime Minister and parliament for having suspended parliament on Monday, 15 August. Parliament was due to sit, and the suspension enabled all members and senators to return to their electorates or home states to participate in the presentation of medallions or in other events to commemorate the 60th anniversary of VP Day.

It was certainly my great honour to host a function at the Central Coast Leagues Club in Gosford for some 94 veterans and war widows and many of their children, grandchildren and other family members. There were around 300 people at that function, and it was a very moving experience for me. I was very honoured to have the opportunity to say thank you to the veterans in the speech I gave at that ceremony. I highlighted the fact that the presentation of the 60th anniversary medallions was, in some very small way, a way of saying thank you from the Australian parliament and, more importantly, the Australian community, as well as personally from me on behalf of the constituents of my electorate of Robertson. It was saying thank you for the effort that these men and women had made during World War II, for the sacrifices they had made, for the losses they had taken and, more importantly, for what they had done to rebuild their own lives and Australia.

They are a very special generation. Most if not all of them are now aged over 80. I believe my electorate of Robertson has one of the highest populations of surviving World War II veterans anywhere in Australia. The Department of Veterans’ Affairs estimates that I have 1,700 World War II veterans in Robertson and I know there are a similar number in the neighbouring electorate of Dobell, so around 3,400 World War II veterans are living on the Central Coast of New South Wales. So it was very important that we had the opportunity to present these medallions.

As I said, some 94 veterans, as well as widows and families, turned up at this event. It was a very moving occasion for them, for me and for the other people who participated. It was very moving to see those very proud old men stand when their names were called to come forward. We had only one step for them to step up onto the stage; some of them needed assistance to do that, and we had TS Hawkesbury naval cadets there to give that assistance. Some of them could not even manage to come onto the platform so I came to them. You could see many of them had tears in their eyes. They said, ‘It is such an honour to receive this medallion.’ In return I was able to say to them: ‘No, it is a great honour and a great privilege for me to be able to present this medallion to you on behalf of the Australian people.’ Obviously it paled into insignificance compared to the war service medals that many of them were proudly wearing at the time.

I would like to thank very much a number of people involved in the organisation of this event. It was a very large event and it was important to the community and me that it ran smoothly. I would like to thank the board, management and staff of the Central Coast Leagues Club Pty Ltd for their hospitality and for providing the room and the venue for our ceremony free of charge. There was also a donation and floral tribute given by the Creighton, Palmdale, Greenway Group in support of this occasion. The senior students and players from the Sydney Conservatorium of Music travelled from Sydney to the Central Coast to provide music from the forties and fifties. That was certainly enjoyed by all who attended. I would like to thank Dr Rod Bain from the Gosford RSL sub-branch who contributed in a very significant way by arranging for the players from the Sydney Conservatorium of Music to attend and also the cadets from the TS Hawkesbury naval cadet unit. The fact that we had the naval cadets who were able to provide the flag party to come into the hall was certainly a highlight of the event. It was an inspiration to the people who were there, to the veterans and their families.

We hear a lot of negativity about young Australians but overall I believe that our younger generation are a fantastic generation. They will do our country proud as they grow into adulthood, and among the great examples of that are the young men and women who join our cadet units—our Army, Air Force and Navy cadets. I have known the cadets of the TS Hawkesbury for a very long time and back in about 1998, with the assistance of the then Minister Bronwyn Bishop, secured funding for the establishment of a new headquarters for TS Hawkesbury. I am very proud to be associated with that naval cadet unit. They are a wonderful group of young men and women and they did themselves proud by providing the flag party on the day and also supporting and assisting the veterans, widows and their families to come to the stage to have the medallions presented to them.

It is a day of reflection. It is a day of commemoration. It means a great deal and different things to many people. Those people who were actually there at the time when we celebrated victory in the Pacific, when we celebrated the end of that terrible war, must have mixed emotions. I know when I speak to many of the veterans they do have mixed emotions. Of course, there is sadness when they remember the mates, the colleagues, the family members who were lost or injured in the conflict. Even now, as the years have gone by, many of the veterans are saddened by the loss of so many of their friends whom they had known for so many years. As the years go by, many more of them are passing on.

So VP Day means different things to different people, but the one thing that it means to me is that, as someone from a younger generation, I try to pass on to those who are even younger than me, the kids and teenagers on the Central Coast, that we must never forget the sacrifices of those men and women not only in World War II but in all the major conflicts that Australia has been involved in. Without their struggle, without their sacrifice, we would not enjoy the freedom and privileges that we have in what is a wonderful country. The fact that we can stand in this parliament and we can debate and argue over issues that we believe are important and have our own views is a testament to the success of those men and women who fought in World War II for freedom.

Every day we should give thanks to those men and women because without their sacrifice we would not have the freedoms, we would not have the country that we have and we would not have the opportunities as we go into the future. I appreciate the opportunity to be able to put my comments on the record. Obviously, there are limited opportunities in the parliament for ministers to speak on electorate issues or issues of this nature, so I really appreciate the opportunity to provide these comments today. As I said, it was a very moving service and it was a great opportunity for me to say, on behalf of the constituents of Robertson, thank you to those very wonderful, proud men and women who served and fought in World War II.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to be participating in this debate. The end of the Second World War obviously brought about a great change to the way in which we viewed ourselves as a nation, to the way we viewed our neighbours and to our relationships with other countries. Most importantly, the war once again demonstrated the resilience, commitment and sacrifice of young Australians, their ability to comprehend the moment and to seize their opportunity to ensure that this country would have a future which was based on the fundamental principles of democracy and freedom. That is what this war was all about.

speech.para: There is dispute and a live debate about whether or not the end of the Pacific war was necessarily immediately due to the dropping of the bombs on Nagasaki and Hiroshima. There is certainly debate about whether or not the dropping of those bombs and the killing of so many innocent civilians—hundreds of thousands of them died as a result of those two atomic explosions—was necessary to end the war. There is a live debate about whether or not the dropping of those bombs was as much about politics in terms of preventing the Soviet Union being involved in Japan as it was about getting the Emperor of Japan to declare an end to the war.

It was clear in the lead-up to those horrendous two days that conventional bombing was having almost as devastating an impact upon the Japanese civilian population as was eventually brought about by the use of these two nuclear weapons. I have to say that, for me, the end of the war symbolises a great change in the way in which the world viewed itself. We saw ourselves, as a result of those bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, entering a new era, one which continues today in the continuing debate about the issue of nuclear proliferation.

The end of the war brought about peace, but at huge cost. We in Australia lost 40,000 killed. And when you contemplate that almost 30,000 were held as prisoners of war, that is a huge number of people. There were a million people under arms out of a population of seven million.

I talked briefly about the attacks on civilian populations in Japan. Let there be no doubt about it, this war saw a real change in the way in which we treated each other, from the horrendous abuse of civilian populations by the Germans and the use of gas chambers to the very unheroic bombing of Dresden by the British and, I might say, the unheroic bombing of civilian populations by both sides during that war. I regard those as very sad things. While there will be people who rejoice and say that the bombing of Dresden was really important to bring the Germans to their knees and that the use of atomic weapons on Hiroshima and Nagasaki was ultimately the catalyst that brought about the defeat of the Japanese, the human impact of those exercises should not be forgotten, just as the human impact of the war on this country—our nation—should not be forgotten.

I speak as someone who was not born, not even in the mind’s eye of my parents, at the time. But, like my grandfather and his brothers who served in the First World War, my father and his brothers served in the Second World War and my mother’s family served in the Second World War, fighting overseas for this nation. And they did so with the most heroic of motives. Those are the things that are important to me. Remember the impact of this war on civilian populations and the moral arguments about whether the carpet bombing of civilian populations in Germany and in England by the English and the Germans was appropriate. There was also the carpet bombing, effectively, of Japan by the United States and the attacks in China—the killing of hundreds of thousands of civilians by the Japanese. As human beings, we should all be very concerned. But that is what happened during this war.

Its end was a time of great joy and, for us allies, a time of great triumph. But I think it is lost on many Australians, especially the current generation, that this war had an immediate impact on this continent. From 19 February 1942, when 188 Japanese aircraft touched the Northern Territory coastline to bomb Darwin, until the end of the war, Darwin was bombed 64 times. Elsewhere in Northern Australia there were 37 other raids. In the course of those raids, 900 people lost their lives. Australia lost 77 aircraft and the Japanese lost 131.

I am sure that when you talk about the war to most kids, and even to people of our generation, very few know or understand how close we were to an occupation of this country. Very few know how our territorial integrity was abused by a foreign nation’s forces in an attempt to subjugate us—to horrify the bejesus out of us, to the point where there were midget submarines in Sydney Harbour. The war was very close. In the Top End, there were many people who would not normally have been part of this. My own town of Alice Springs, where I live, was integral to Australia’s war effort. It was a staging post for soldiers going up to the Top End. Towns along the way such as Larrimah and Katherine were extremely important to our war effort. We know that Darwin was a point of embarkation for some of the most heroic moments of Australia’s involvement in the Second World War.

Who will forget—many do not know but if they do know they should not forget—Z Force, Gull Force and the 2nd/2nd Commandos who embarked from Darwin in January and February 1942 to act as a guerrilla force in Timor? They lost very few people over a nine- or 10-month period and then were brought back. They were replaced by the 2nd/4th Commandos in November of that year. We know about this because that particular effort left a legacy with us: we were protected by the East Timorese, and it is to those people that we owe such a great debt. I am pleased to say this has partly been honoured, but we have a continuing obligation because of our historical relationship, brought about by the events of World War II.

My father, as it happens, served with the 2nd/2nd Commandos, but not in Timor. He joined them after that and fought with them in New Guinea. I met these men over many years at their unit reunions—ordinary blokes, shearers, truck drivers, carpenters, office workers, painters and decorators.

talk.start.para: —They are extraordinary.

—They are ordinary people who had ordinary lives before this cataclysmic event. And my friend is right: they performed extraordinary deeds for our welfare, and for that we should never forget. I add just one example. I have recently been reading the history of the Kokoda Trail, and I have to say I am dumbstruck by the efforts of Australian personnel on the Kokoda Trail and the way they rebutted the overland advance of the Japanese, the tragedies that befell them and the hardships they endured. I wonder whether we will really ever understand. I do not know about your experience, Mr Deputy Speaker, but my experience is that my father very rarely spoke about the war. But I know the horror has tormented him and I know it has tormented his comrades. The survivors of that unit meet regularly. They are hosted by the SAS in Perth. There is a grove of trees in Kings Park commemorating their performance in the war. They are a substantial Western Australian unit, although my father was from Victoria. They are just one example and there are many others.

speech.para: We had people going to war aged 15, 16 and 17—some even younger. They did not have to be conscripted; they volunteered to go away and fight for our freedom. I do not think that fact should be lost. Next week I and some others will be spending some time with and observing Norforce, a largely Indigenous unit working out of Darwin. The forerunner to Norforce was Donald Thomson and the Nackeroos. These people used horses and the land to look after Australia’s coastline during the Second World War. They are unsung heroes. They caught prisoners and saved pilots, but there they were, Indigenous Australians, working with the expertise of the military to provide a very important cog in our border protection. The history of Australia needs to be understood by young people. I was talking to some humanities people this morning. Why is it that this part of our history is not so solid in the minds of all of us? It ought to be.

Then there is the role of that Indigenous person on the Tiwi Islands who captured a Japanese person. He walked up to him and said, ‘Stick ‘em up all the same, Hopalong Cassidy,’ and took a prisoner. A moment of levity, yes, but we can take great joy in the celebration of the end of the Second World War, VP Day. However, there are those moments when you have to think about the moral dilemma that is created by the killing of civilians. We ought to celebrate the heroism, the commitment, the courage and the tragedy that confronted so many of us, but really we should celebrate the commitment of Australians to Australia.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
talker.role: Minister for Vocational and Technical Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr HARDGRAVE

talk.start.para: —We are here today to talk about a most extraordinary generation, a group of people who in every way, shape and form in fact shaped the sort of Australia that we have today, and who certainly fought on the principles of freedom and democracy and sought to spread them to places that many of them, perhaps, had never found until they actually arrived there. People who were quite extraordinary in their deeds but very ordinary in their circumstances and background rose to every occasion with a very Australian sense of approach and spirit.

speech.para: This is not a tradition that is lost on the generation of today. As I look back on the VP commemorations that took place in my electorate of Moreton over the weekend, I think that there is an enormous understanding by everyday citizens, and particularly young citizens, about just how extraordinary these people were and how thankful we all should be as a nation. We should never take for granted for a moment that we can stand here and make the claim today that we are the sixth oldest continuous democracy in the world had it not been for the many generations of Australians who served this country in uniform in places well beyond our shores.

Unlike some of the other speakers, I am not talking about the generation of my own parents—they were youngsters. I am talking about my grandparents’ generation, my two grandfathers. Robert McKinnon served in the Middle East and Percy Hardgrave served in Horn Island and Charters Towers, providing support for the RAAF in their effort in Papua New Guinea, as the member for Lingiari mentioned. Neither of them talked very much about their time at war. In fact, my late grandfather Percy never sought the medals; he never saw a need to get them. I think there are something like 200,000 sets of medals still unclaimed in Australia today, many from that particular conflict.

I found out a few years ago that my great-grandfather, who had served at the Western Front—the battle of Polygon Wood of September 1917—and was severely hurt and psychologically traumatised by it, served again back here in Australia at barracks in Sydney after my great-grandmother coerced him to do something for their sons. He never claimed his Second World War medals either. And my grandfather Percy never wore his medals. He died about a week before the medals arrived in the mail.

I found others around who have similar stories to tell about their own grandparents or, indeed in many cases, great-grandparents. I found them on the weekend, including at the Moorooka Sports and Community Club where they hosted a fantastic bowls day—and it was a shout; they shouted. They organised some funds from us, as the Australian government, but they organised some funds from the local community as well. The Allen brothers’ butchery at Clifton Hill provided about 80 meat trays and everybody went home with a prize. It was a way of bringing the community together. It was a way of saying: ‘We are in Australia. Let us just value each other, but also let us not forget those who gave us the chance to have that kind of value applied.’

It was the Vietnam veteran generation who ran the day over the weekend. It was the Vietnam veteran generation who paid particular homage—because of the leadership they bring to the RSL these days—to those who are now very old by comparison and very doddery, unfortunately, in a physical sense but very, very sharp about the memories, and those ranks are so thin.

Rob Lippiatt from Sunnybank RSL presided over a magnificent memorial service which brought together a variety of people, many of whom I grew up with. Bob Davis was the groundsman at Runcorn State School when I was there and I got the chance to present his medallion to him. This is a bloke I had a lot to do with when I was in years 6 and 7. He is a guy who had an extraordinary story to tell because of his involvement in the Second World War, but he went on and served the community in other ways. Jim Pringle—the Pringles were amongst the first teachers at my old high school, MacGregor high school—taught science and other subjects; he was a teacher of mine. I got to present him with a medallion. It was very humbling for me as a private person, who happens to hold a representative office in this country, to be able to say to people I grew up with, ‘Thank you.’

Vi Thomas’s late husband, George, passed away many years ago but Mrs Thomas has been so involved with the RSL at Sunnybank. I grew up with her kids. She was there. She had received her medallion in the mail and did not want to make a fuss about the presentation, which is very typical of the generation that we are talking about in the motion before us today.

We saw Meg Arthurs OAM from the Red Cross there laying a floral tribute. The scouts and the guides with Judy Ellerington, MacGregor State School, Sunnybank High School, St Thomas More College and Eight Mile Plains State School, along with the Sunnybank and District Brass Band, presented a couple of very moving songs which brought tears to the eyes of heroes through their fine performances that day. I saw grown men proud and tall—in a lot of ways I guess the survivors were conscious of the mates that they had lost both through the attrition of the years and at the time of direct conflict in service—with tears in their eyes as they received medallions from me, just a mere inheritor of their service and of their sacrifice. I am afraid that I too had a few tears. It is not hard for any of us to think about people we know, because that conflict of all those years ago, like all conflicts, touched us in direct ways.
