Wally Sefjack, who served with the American forces and came and lived in Australia and for many years, through Sunnybank RSL, helped and gave enormous currency and importance to the cadets, particularly the air cadets, passed away on 3 August, but his family was there to join in on what I know Wally himself would have liked to have been a part of. I last saw Wally on Anzac Day. We helped to wheel him up the ramp at the Sunnybank RSL, but to think that he just missed out on the 60th anniversary by a week or so.

John Strachan OAM is the President of the Stephens RSL, and on Monday he brought together a lot of people, including Padre Roy Wakeling. Roy Wakeling is a Baptist minister. He was one of the Darwin defenders, and he wore a very proud badge that day that said he was one of the Darwin defenders. He has some of the service medals out of the Second World War, but not the full set. He missed out on active service by just a number of weeks, because he was in Darwin when things dropped. As the member for Lingiari reflected upon, hundreds of bombs were dropped on Darwin. Darwin was bombed more than Pearl Harbor was, but it is never really talked about because the government of the day—I guess rightly—kept it all a bit of a secret. Roy Wakeling continues to serve, providing spiritual help, and he is the honorary padre of Stephens RSL.

I listened to Nev Francis OAM, who was on Fraser Island on VP Day. He said, ‘I really did not do any of the running down the streets and jumping in front of trams like that famous fellow does in all the footage we see as we talk about VP Day. We were actually away from the celebrations and we still had work to do.’ Nev has gone on to work on Neighbourhood Watch and so many other community ventures. His sense of service has never declined as the years have gone on. Nev shared with us some of his reflections of that day.

Then there was Bill Moody MBE, MC, ED (retired). He won his Military Cross obviously for bravery. He said he was actually up on the Kokoda Track leading up to the declaration of peace, still defending the line. That is the way he tells the story. He tells of how there were days of uncertainty until the white flags came out. Until the word had actually been passed on that peace was now certain, none of them moved from their posts. That is the way he told the story, and I am not going to question the recollection he gave us the other day.

There were kids from Yeronga State High School and Rocklea State School. It is only a small school, but the kids were there. They were all paying tribute to these chaps, and rightly so. I think Australia has got better at saying thankyou to people who made a difference. I believe that it was the Australia Remembers year of 1995 which helped to redefine, and almost outed, the sacrifice that many of my grandparents’ generation kept to themselves. They did not really want to share or burden young blokes like me with all the information. Right from the time I could stand I was at Anzac Day marches. When I think back and look at the faces of people to whom I presented medallions over the weekend, I realise that there were so many people who served in so many ways who are part of the society which shaped who I am today. It just adds to the sacrifice and the service they gave during the war years.

The peace years and the way in which they built a great country is equally something that we should celebrate today. I look at the political leadership of this country, the many faces on both sides—people who were prisoners of war and people who fought with great gallantry, be they people like former prime ministers Gorton and Whitlam, be they people like Jim Killen, my predecessor, be they people like Sir William Knox and so many others who were part of my political party in Queensland for so many years—who came back, after facing all that they had during the Second World War, with a determination that they had an opportunity to now assert themselves and to shape a future for this country.

The many faces that make up the nation we have today are in themselves an often not spoken about testimony to the way Australian service personnel have served. Our cultural diversity reflects often where Australian service men and women have served. They saw people up close and personal in the defence of, or the promotion of, the ideals of freedom and democracy in their countries of birth, and that they have migrated to this country to be among those people is something that we should note in this discussion today.

My large Taiwanese-born community have reflected to me that they were the ones who fought the Japanese first and that the armies of China were very much in a conflict during what they called the ‘Japanese war’. Just a week or two ago I was in China and Vietnam around the time leading up to the 60th anniversary of the dropping of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombs, and there was a lot of talk about the ‘Japanese war’.

World wars impact on each and every one of the people of the world. The traditions that we have today—and I hope we can maintain the focus on VP Day that we were able to build over the weekend—are built very much on the great service that others have given to this country to create the sort of nation we have. Our freedom and our democracy should never be taken for granted. Those who have served have delivered it to us, and it is right that we say thank you to them. I commend this motion to the chamber. Our constant tribute to these people will ensure that other generations that come on—the generation of my children and, in time, my children’s children—will prove that Australians will never forget. Lest we forget.

talk.start.para: —In speaking in this debate I want to record my thanks and appreciation to all who contributed to the war effort in Australia, from those who went away from as early as 1939 to all who served overseas in the Middle East and Europe and to all who served closer to home in neighbouring countries, on the ground, on the sea, under the sea and in the air in the defence of our nation.

speech.para: I want to acknowledge too those who stayed at home and mobilised in support of those who went away. I know that it was a difficult period for many at home in the services who wanted desperately to get overseas, who wanted desperately to be there with their mates fighting the enemy. For many of course they were man-powered. For many the opportunity just did not arise where they could go overseas, but they were there, they were available and, had the opportunity arisen, they would have gone without a moment’s hesitation. I also want to acknowledge those who waited at home for news of their loved ones—the parents and the wives, particularly those who did not know whether their sons, daughters or spouses lived or died. These were indeed difficult years for Australia.

My father was one who went away, leaving a wife and a baby daughter. I was born in 1946, an early member of the baby boomer generation. But my dad had been knocked around during the war, and I grew up seeing him suffer. I saw him fighting for health and battling the authorities at the repatriation department, and all of this time he was trying to run his own business. My mother, indeed the whole family, spent many a day and many a weekend visiting Dad at Hollywood hospital. One of the enduring memories of my young life is the sound of my mother’s high heels as she walked on the duckboard towards where Dad was in a ward with six or seven other people. It was a sound that I know my father used to wait for and listen to, just as the other blokes used to wait for that all-important visit, perhaps once or twice a week, when their wives or other loved ones would come down and see them.

The suffering lingered long after the war was over, not just for those who went but also for those who loved them, those who looked after them, those who nursed them and those who tried to understand what they had gone through. The wives who nursed their husbands in the way that they did, without thanks, for so many years, are some of the great heroes of our nation.

I also want to speak briefly of some of the heroes that I knew as I grew up, some of the people like Weary Dunlop. If ever there was a greater Australian, I would like to know who it was. Weary Dunlop was a man of immense courage. He was one of those who should have been back in Australia. Because of the blue between the then Prime Minister of Australia and Churchill, who wanted our deployed forces kept overseas—it was not until Curtin stepped in and overrode Churchill; he said, ‘I want these people back here to defend Australia’—for some of them it was too late; they were captured. We know the dreadful story of so many of our young boys and young women who were captured. We know the dreadful things that they suffered. But people like Weary Dunlop were great men—great men in difficult times. What a wonderful Australian he was.

Anyone who knows the story of Sister Vivian Bullwinkle would have to put her on the same pedestal that you would put Weary Dunlop on. What a wonderful woman. What a wonderfully brave, warm-hearted, kind, courageous woman Vivian Bullwinkle was. She ended up living in Western Australia and I saw her just a few days before she passed away. They are two Australians that I put up on a pedestal, and I think that every Australian—every young Australian—should learn their stories and learn the true story of leadership, courage and sacrifice.

I also want to touch on the story of Teddy Sheehan. We all know that, in the history of the Royal Australian Navy, not one of its members has ever been awarded a VC. What a dreadful oversight that is, and what a slight it is on the Australian Navy. You would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in those days captains of ships could not make direct recommendations for certain medals. There was an Englishperson allocated in Australia. All they could do was to get those recommendations and forward them to London. As a result of that, Teddy Sheehan is one who perhaps should have received the VC, but never did. He was a young man—I think of 18 or 19 years of age—who was in the water with his mates when the Armidale was sunk. They were strafed by Japanese planes. He went back to the ship, strapped himself into the gun and fired at the planes as they were strafing his mates in the water. Even as the Armidale sank beneath the seas, he was still at his post, still firing that gun, still trying to defend his mates. That is so typical of the bravery, the courage and the mateship of so many of those men and women both overseas and at home who were determined that Australia was never going to fall into Japanese hands.

I have been involved in the HMAS Sydney Foundation for a number of years. Although we have not been as active in the last 12 months or so as we were in the past, others have carried the fight on. I want to say that I am absolutely thrilled at the Prime Minister’s decision to allocate $1.3 million to the search for the Sydney. It is something that I and others have argued for for some time, on a very strong bipartisan basis. Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, you would be aware of the wonderful work that was done by the defence subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee. They held an inquiry and travelled across Australia. They listened to all sorts of arguments—some of them reasoned and some of them not so reasoned—put forward by people who have one thing in mind and that is to find the Sydney.

It may well be that when the Sydney is found, because of the nature of the ship, the depth of the water, where she might lie or how she might lie, she will never tell us the story of what actually happened. But what is incredibly important to me and to others is that we, as a nation, should never stop searching for the HMAS Sydney, because we have a spiritual duty to bring those men home. We do not know where the ship lies but we do know that she is within a certain area off Geraldton and Carnarvon on the coast of Western Australia. It is a massive task. I remember the book by Tom Frame, where he said it is not as if we are looking for a needle in a haystack; we have not yet found the haystack. So good luck to everyone who is involved in that search. I certainly hope that they find the Sydney and bring those men home spiritually. I compliment the Prime Minister and the government for that grant.

In closing, I want to refer to the VP Day celebrations in my own electorate. We organised a concert at one of my local high schools. It was a concert organised by me, our local RSLs—we only have two RSLs, one established and one still being formed—and all of our local high schools, bar one, and colleges. We invited some 140 veterans. Unfortunately, we were a bit limited in those whom we could get along but we invited them to Girrawheen Senior High School, which is fairly central in my electorate. Other schools and colleges, like Ballajura Community College, Warwick Senior High School, Morley Senior High School, Kingsway Christian College, Greenwood Senior High School, Woodvale Senior High School and Mercy College, sent young people along to perform a few items to entertain and pay their respects to these veterans, war widows and others who contributed to the war effort during the Second World War. I was absolutely overwhelmed by the quality of the performances that these young people put on. I was absolutely overwhelmed at their determination to entertain, honour and show respect to the people of that Second World War generation. They did a fantastic job and I am incredibly proud of those young people.

I would like to record my thanks to Milton Kirk, the President of the Wanneroo Joondalup branch of the RSL; Steve Francis and Dave Howe from that RSL, who worked with us; Scotty Alcorn from the newly forming Ballajura RSL; Aurilie Bergin from the EDA association, who works strenuously for her members; Wayne Austin, the deputy at the school; Bill Mann, the principal of the school, who, when I approached him about this idea, said, ‘Graham, we’ll do anything and everything we can to do it, to host it and to make sure it is a success’; and Liz Chambers, the teacher who looks after the hospitality class—young people from the hospitality class provided the lunch.

It was a wonderful day and I felt very proud to be Australian, very proud of the way these young people conducted themselves and very proud of my father’s and mother’s generation, who did so much to defend Australia and the principle of freedom and to enhance the character of Australia—the character of our nation—and who did so much collectively to ensure that following generations would know peace and not war and would be able to live and pursue their lives without the horror and suffering of the era they went through.

In closing, I would like to say that I have an immense regard for young people today. They do not get a lot of good publicity, but I think they have as much courage and character as any previous generation of Australians. Let us hope and pray that they are not called on to show that courage and character in foreign lands on foreign soils in foreign battles.

talk.start.para: (Mr Quick)—I thank the honourable member for his moving tribute.

—American broadcaster Tom Brokaw referred to the World War II generation as ‘our greatest generation’. In Australia we can only echo similar comments. Almost a million Australians served in uniform during World War II, and you cannot have something like that happen without the whole ethos of selfless service being passed on to the community—and that is what we saw. When the war ended and this generation returned to civilian life, they took on leadership roles in their community. They ran the community organisations. Many ex-service men came into the parliament in 1949. They have taken that spirit of selfless service and they have been running our voluntary organisations and community groups for so long.

speech.para: They served in the Army, the Air Force and the Royal Australian Navy, and they were attached to the Royal Air Force in the United Kingdom. There were women serving in the auxiliary and the merchant navy. Going to the Anzac Day march this year really gave me a sense of what it meant for an entire generation to be involved in this effort for six years. All I can say is how much I really honour those who served during the Second World War and how much I respect their service, their commitment and the way they gave up what they were doing in their own lives to give something to their country.

Like many other members, I have been to a number of functions for Victory in the Pacific Day. There were two that really struck me as being very far sighted. One was the dinner I went to with the Pioneers Battalion. There were four Pioneers Battalions during the Second World War—one for each of our divisions. Allan Olson and Bill Thiele asked each of the World War II veterans attending the dinner to organise a table and bring their children, their grandchildren and some close friends. They have really fostered an understanding amongst these families of what their grandparents and parents went through. I also went to a lunch with the Ex-POW Association. Len Croxton, president of that association, Ron Zwar, its secretary and Bill Schmidt, a former president of the association, have built a memorial at an Adelaide school. They hold annual services there on 15 August and on 11 November and they spend a lot of time talking to the students about what it was like to be a prisoner of war.

I have three messages for young Australians. Firstly, take the opportunity to go to an Anzac Day march. Secondly, learn as much about your family history as you can. Speak to your grandparents; speak to your great-grandparents, if they are still alive. Thirdly, take the opportunity to visit the Australian War Memorial, or at least visit the War Memorial’s web site. As the member for Boothby and a member of parliament, it has been one of my great privileges to meet many people from this generation. I think of Lew Francis, who was in the 2/10 Australian Infantry Battalion that served in New Guinea and Borneo. I think of John Mathwin, a former state MP who was a veteran of the landings at Normandy. I think of Bernie Belfrage, who served with the Royal Australian Air Force. I think of Charles Hurl, a great supporter and one of my first campaign managers, who flew Lancaster bombers during the war. Sadly, they have all passed on.

I also think of current leaders of veterans groups in my electorate. I think of Ralph Aston, who was also part of the Empire Air Training Scheme. He does a very effective job of running the Mitcham RAAF Association. I think of Allan Olson, who runs the Pioneers Battalion Association. I think of Colin Hetzel, who served with the Australian Army and who is a former vice president of the state branch of the RSL. I think of Iris Crawford, one of my volunteers, who served in the women’s auxiliary. And I think of a great friend of mine and a former member of federal parliament, Jim Forbes, who won the Military Cross in Bougainville.

The war in the Pacific started later than the war in Europe. We had the sinking of HMAS Sydney in November 1941 and then the campaign in Malaya and Singapore, which saw most of the 8th Division captured. We had the Battle of the Java Sea, which the previous speaker mentioned. This is, to my knowledge, the largest naval battle the Royal Australian Navy has been in. We were there with American, British, Dutch and Australian ships. HMAS Perth was there; it was sunk and many of the survivors ended up as prisoners of war. We had the battle for Java. The ship, the Orcades, with the 2/3 Machine Gun Battalion and the 2/2 Pioneers, parts of the Black Force, landed in Java. They fought effectively in Java, but were captured in March 1942. We remember the veterans of Kokoda in New Guinea. What they did was simply magnificent. As previous speakers have said, and as Slim remarked in his memoirs, it was the first time that the Japanese were stopped on land. In Borneo, the Australians were involved in the landings at Balikpapan and Tarakan.

Of course, in this motion we remember those who were prisoners of war of the Japanese. I commend to other members many of the books that have been published recently: Hellfire by Cameron Forbes, One Fourteenth of an Elephant, by Ian Denys Peek and A Doctor’s War by Dr Rowley Richards. But one of the best books ever written about this is by Rohan Rivett. It came out a couple of months after he returned from being a prisoner of war. It is called Behind Bamboo.

In speaking on this motion, I would like to focus on two specific parts of the Second World War. Firstly, I would like to speak about the No. 1 Squadron of the Royal Australian Air Force. This was the first squadron to go overseas. They went overseas in July 1940 and were based at Sembawang in Singapore. They were later transferred up to Kota Bharu, which was the northern airfield in Malaya. This squadron was the first to sight the Japanese convoy heading towards landings in what were then Siam and Malaya, and it was also the first in action against the Japanese.

As everyone will remember, the Japanese coordinated attacks right across the Pacific. No. 1 Squadron, which was a reconnaissance bomber squadron, was in action against the Japanese one hour and 20 minutes before the attack on Pearl Harbour. They later went back to Sembawang in Singapore. Before the fall of Singapore they went to an airfield in Sumatra, and they ended up at airfields in Java. In March 1942 the No. 1 Squadron was asked to return to Australia. They were going to return to Australia by flying boat. The flying boats were from Broome, and they were destroyed in Japanese attacks. Members of No. 1 Squadron remained in Java, were captured and spent time as prisoners of war in Batavia, in Burma and in Thailand.

Keith Neighbour, a constituent of mine, was a pilot and a member of that squadron. So was my grandfather. When we remember this, 60 years after the end of the war in the Pacific, we should remember that 60 years ago my grandmother still did not know whether my grandfather was alive. She got a message in September that he had been reported safe in Siam on 19 August, and he did arrive back in Adelaide on 6 October 1945.

The second part of the Second World War that I want to talk about is the battle of El Alamein. In talking about the 9th Division, I am indebted to Mark Johnston’s book, That Magnificent 9th. El Alamein was one of the turning points of the war in the west. Churchill once said that we never won any battles before it and we never lost any after it. It went from 23 October to 4 November 1942. Australians were involved in the capture of a landmark called Trig 29. That involved incredibly intense fighting. After a week of holding the position, the 2nd/24th had only 80 soldiers who were able to walk out and the 2nd/48th had only 41 still standing after that battle. On Saturday night I was privileged to meet one of those individuals who walked out. On 31 October and 1 November there were ferocious attacks by Rommel’s best troops. There was an area called ‘the Saucer’ which was defended by the 24th Brigade. The 24th Brigade suffered 500 casualties from 30 October to 2 November. Mark Johnston, in a speech at the Australian War Memorial, said:

quote.para: With victory in sight, Brigadier Arthur Godfrey was holding a conference when a shell scored a direct hit on the dugout, mortally wounding him and killing three other officers.

speech.para: One of those officers was my wife’s great-uncle, Captain Keith Bishop of the brigade’s staff.

I have mentioned some of the people it has been my privilege to know who were part of this generation and some of their stories, just to show how widespread the impact still is, 60 years on. In closing, I would like to utter the words which have appeared on memorials including the memorial to Weary Dunlop: ‘When you go home, tell them of us and say: “For your tomorrow, we gave our today.”’

talk.start.para: —I rise to endorse the Prime Minister’s motion, which was seconded by the Leader of the Opposition, regarding the 60th anniversary of the end of the war in the Pacific. Over the past few days, as Australia recalls that national sense of elation which followed the end of hostilities in the Pacific 60 years ago, some of us may well have been confronted by what we have heard. On radio, on television and in the newspapers, Australian men and women with first-hand recollections of those times have frequently used phrases and words which assault modern Australian sensibilities. Words went off like 303s in the air—racial tags and horrific stories; words such as ‘nips’ and descriptions of the enemy as much less than human. To the average Australian of 2005, these words come pretty close to what we would now call racial vilification. If we dared use this language today to describe the nature and actions of an enemy, the radio chatback waves would be awash with indignation and demands for public apologies. But I have to say that these words and stories serve to remind us how different our world is now and how utterly unthinkable it is for Australia to be, yet again, facing a real and present danger of being occupied by a foreign force and potentially placed under a cruel and violent military regime.

speech.para: To those people recalling their first-hand memories in recent days, these words, terms and phrases were and are profoundly real. One of the aspects that we inheritors of the hard-won peace have difficulty remembering is that, to the men and women of Australia in the 1940s, war was not a vague concept fought somewhere else by someone else. It was not about other people’s sons and daughters dying for any ill-defined objective. These were Australians fighting for their homeland in an extremely real and literal sense. Australia had been attacked and was under threat of imminent invasion. In 1942, the darkest days of the war, we knew the enemy had crossed the vast seas and was now at our gates. Indeed, he had been detected inside our nation’s fortress. We know that plans had been drawn up to try to maintain an Australian enclave in the south-east of an otherwise Japanese controlled continent. It was and will always be a defining moment for Australia. The reality and proximity of the threat to our existence was felt in every Australian city, town and home.

Even in my home town of Bendigo, there was an almost personal fear of what might be about to happen. You could be forgiven for thinking that people in a country city hundreds of kilometres from the coast and thousands of kilometres from the bombed port of Darwin might feel a little remote from the conflict, but that was not the case. You can read newspaper reports of the day about schoolchildren being taught how to dig antistrafing trenches in Rosalind Park in the centre of Bendigo. Schoolchildren were being trained in how to protect themselves from attacking enemy aircraft. You begin to see just how real this was to everyone.

Bendigo’s sense of the nearness of war was amplified by the many hundreds of men and women who worked around the clock in the great Bendigo ordnance factory, pumping out the tools to try and equip our defenders. There are reports of chalk messages being scrawled onto the weapons and armaments coming out of the Bendigo factory, addressed to the unknown soldiers who would rely on them for their very survival and even to the more anonymous soldiers who would be their intended victims. If you talk to the locals who experienced first-hand the local aspects of the time, you cannot help but be overwhelmed by the way the war in the Pacific reached out to every corner of life. Air-raid sirens were installed, blackouts practised and so many normal activities of a country town cancelled. Manpower was scarce as more and more Bendigonians joined the battle for Australia.

The war was brought home to Bendigo in another equally shocking way. While the people of the city hosted visiting US soldiers as valiant defenders, there came with it a price. A Bendigo woman, Pauline Thompson, was one of the three victims of the notorious US Army’s Edward Joseph Leonski, who was later hanged for his awful crimes. It must have seemed as though the world was spinning off its axis.

But from there we move to 1945 and the realisation that a fierce enemy had been defeated. The surrender aboard the USS Missouri was felt in a real and personal way by all Australians. There is a delightful report in Bendigo of a city gone mad with delight: endless scenes of raucous celebrations in the street, of cars full of people zipping around and around the city—with suddenly procured petrol, of course—towing great lines of kerosene tins to add to the din. Bonfires were started and the city voted itself a day off. An estimated 10,000 people attended a thanksgiving service in Rosalind Park—the same park where, three years before, children had dug defensive trenches—and, while celebrating a great victory, there began the official mourning for so many lost in so many unknown places.

I was particularly affected by the situation of George Morgan, of St Andrews Avenue, who went to Melbourne to accept the George Cross not for himself but for his brave son, Lieutenant RG Morgan. He had been one of that selected and vital band of men who had set up communications in villages in the islands ahead of the Japanese advance. He had been sent to the Gilbert and Ellice Islands to report on the Japanese and, when all other Europeans were secretly evacuated, he opted to stay. He was killed at Tarawa in 1942.

The end of the war in the Pacific, 60 years ago, was just the start of a new way for the world. It was the start of the new Japan, which rammed home two words down the throats of its military: ‘Never again.’ It was the start of the new world in which Japan quickly learned the benefits of technology, democracy and trade. After the party ended on VP Day, many knew that the daunting task of reconstruction was just about to begin at all levels in our home towns, states, across the nation and, indeed, across the world. This was clearly understood then. For example, there is a report of the thanksgiving service at St Paul’s Cathedral in Bendigo when Canon Pickford warned that many thousands of Australian troops, civil servants, teachers and aid workers would have to live a lifetime in Germany, other parts of Europe and Japan to help build a world we could all live in.

I often wonder, as I think do many others, what sort of place we would be in now if the loss of 40,000 Australian lives, the imprisoning of 22,000 more and the sacrifices of millions had not achieved peace in the Pacific in 1945. It is as unthinkable now as it probably was then. I also sometimes wonder what character the Australian people would have adopted for themselves if the world had found diplomatic solutions to the issues which led to the world wars of the 20th century. Some of the battles can be seen in terms of the failure of diplomacy, but I am not sure if that could ever be said of the war in the Pacific. Was there a point at which our politicians of the time could have resolved the conflict before the killing began? I do not know, but we can never retreat from a democratic philosophy which regards war as the ultimate failure to find solutions. We must learn from the past.

On the 60th anniversary of VP Day, we say to those men and women of earlier generations and to those serving presently that we did learn something: we learnt to value freedom, democracy, the Australian way of life and our place on this planet and to understand that the things we could so easily take for granted were won with blood, sweat and tears. This was the first time that global warfare reached our shores and threatened our homes and, hopefully, it will be the only time. We responded to the threat in a way which even our former foe now says was magnificent.

Even in the most terrifying situations there are always lighter moments. I am indebted to Mr Jack King of Kangaroo Flat who provided me with a book entitled It Had to BU compiled by James H Harding. It is the life story of the RAAF 80th Squadron of Kittyhawks on duty in the Pacific islands during World War II. Also I am reminded, as a result of a passage in this book, about the Australian servicemen’s ingenuity and some of the completely amazing feats that they performed. There is no greater evidence of ingenuity, when it comes to keeping beer cold, than from the Australian serviceperson. As you would imagine in the Pacific islands, refrigeration was virtually non-existent or very limited. You would be aware of the long military socks that servicepeople were issued with at the time. They put the bottles of beer issued in their rations—we call them longnecks these days—into a sock, tied the sock with the beer bottle in it to a tree, suspended a small container of aviation fuel above it, which would drip down onto the sock, and the evaporative chemistry would then cool the beer down to a drinkable temperature. Of course, we can only shudder to think what would have happened if that base had come under attack—the tree would have exploded and so would the beer.

I would like to conclude by reading a passage from the book, which illustrates some of the other lighter moments that could have been a tragedy in those times. The passage relates to a Kittyhawk pilot who was undertaking a strafing mission or operation during that time. His name was John ‘Shorty’ Carroll. I quote:

quote.para: John pressed home his attack too low, pulled up but was below the trees. He saw an opening ahead of him so flew into it. It turned out to be a road and he flew along it with the jungle forming a roof overhead. After about 300 yards, he thought “this is stupid” so pulled up through the canopy. Circling above, we thought he had bought it, but where are the flames, then his plane burst out through the trees! Somebody gave vent to an expletive but nothing else was said. At debriefing, still nothing was said, but when an armourer brought in a small branch which he had found in a gun barrel, everybody roared laughing.

speech.para: So there were lighter moments. I guess all that remains now, in conclusion, is for us to say that we will never forget and to give our thanks.

talk.start.para: —It is a pleasure to speak on the Prime Minister’s motion remembering VP Day. When I sat down with local RSL presidents six or eight weeks ago and asked them how they would like to commemorate VP Day in the electorate of Casey the four of them said that they wanted to have a function that involved their RSL representatives but also local schoolchildren. They wanted to pass on the message of service and sacrifice to the next generation to ensure that the deeds and the contribution of their generation and what those who had lost their lives sacrificed would go on in the minds of the next generation.

speech.para: So on Monday that is exactly what we did in a function co-hosted with the RSLs and the Shire of Yarra Ranges. A function was held in Lilydale with representatives of 28 schools and we heard moving reflections from a local historian, Mr Anthony McAleer, from a local veteran from the Croydon RSL, Bill Lipscombe, and from two family members who gave a perspective on what it was like waiting for the return of their loved ones—from Cath Hill and from Sylvia Morse, both from Lilydale. We also heard from the Mayor of the Shire of the Yarra Ranges, David Hodgett, and from Bob Richardson from the Lilydale RSL. The four RSL presidents from Croydon, Lilydale, Monbulk and Mount Evelyn presented each of the students with a commemorative plaque and a native sapling that will stay in each of those schools as a lasting reminder of World War II and VP Day.

I particularly thank Ron Buisman from Lilydale Trophies and Engraving Services, who produced the plaques and did so in a short space of time, and Len Cox from Correa Nursery in Montrose for providing the native saplings. I thank all of the RSL presidents—John Surridge from Monbulk, Ken Gibbons from Croydon, Bill Sibley from Mount Evelyn and particularly Bob Richardson from the Lilydale RSL, who worked tirelessly to bring about the event on Monday and to make it the success it was. I also thank all of the school students, the principals, the teachers and the parents who came along and made the day the success it was.

It was a time to look back on the local contribution from Lilydale, Croydon, Mount Evelyn and the entire Casey electorate and to remember the fact that local communities paid an incredible price and made an incredible sacrifice as part of our national contribution to the Second World War. Anthony McAleer, the local historian, spoke in great detail of what Lilydale—still very much a country town but one that has grown—was like at the start of the war, through the war, and on VP Day in 1945 when news that the war was over reached the town. He spoke of the celebrations that occurred in Lilydale and in Croydon in the main street. Those celebrations are very particular to those local towns in some ways but really just reflective of what would have happened across Australia 60 years ago in the streets of every town, be it in the electorate of Casey or in my colleague’s electorate of McPherson, where local communities united as part of a national story.

And what a national story it was that we look back on! Sixty years ago Australia emerged from its greatest and longest conflict. Australians fought World War II from beginning to end to defend Australia, to defend our allies and to defend our free way of life. Through this motion, as we remember the end of that war 60 years ago, we rightly reflect on a truly special generation of Australians. We remember of course those brave Australians who gave their lives. We remember them first. We remember and thank those Australians who fought in the war and returned safely. As previous speakers, including the member for Bendigo, have done, we remember those who fought on the home front ensuring that our troops overseas had all the supplies they needed and keeping our economy going so that we could fight the war and win.

We thank both of those groups not just for everything they did during the war but, as the member for Boothby said, for everything they did after the war as well—for rebuilding Australia and for setting it on the path to success and opportunity that we all enjoy today and see 60 years on.

It is often rightly said that the diggers of 1939 to 1945 were very much like the Anzacs of World War I. There is a lot of truth in that. In many ways, they were. They went to war to defend the same principles. Like the first Anzacs, their character comprised courage, valour, selflessness, sacrifice and so much more. And like them, as previous speakers have referred to, they displayed that same unstinting mateship that has been part of our defence forces from day one. They also displayed that quintessential Australian ingenuity as they went about their duties—an ingenuity that was first on display in bucket loads on the shores of Gallipoli.

What is not so often recognised is that the diggers of 1939 to 1945 were in many ways different from the original Anzacs. It is these differences that make them special in our history—differences that make their feats and their service something that was a first for Australia. Unlike the original Anzacs, they went to war in 1939 and through the early 1940s with no illusions about war. They did not go to war wondering what it was like. Those who fought in the Second World War knew exactly what they were getting into. Those who fought in the Second World War had grown up knowing that fathers, uncles, brothers and family friends had been killed or maimed in the First World War. The diggers of World War II did not leave our shores with the romanticism the first Anzacs had. They did not leave with any innocent curiosity. They left knowing that war was not an adventure. They knew that it was a costly, awful and bloody business.

Many of the first Anzacs sailed from our shores with a tragic underestimation of what lay ahead in foreign lands, but the diggers of World War II left our shores with a tragic and stoic knowledge of precisely what lay ahead. The debt we owe all of those who served in that conflict—a massive conflict that reached our shores and was fought in our region as well as across the globe—can never be repaid. The contribution of those people has provided much to our nation and to other nations as well.

Like the first Anzacs, those who fought in the conflict and who paid the ultimate sacrifice and gave their lives may have thought—they certainly would have hoped—that they were fighting a war that would end all wars. They would be sad to know that that was not the case. They would be sad to know that there have been other conflicts and that the challenges to democracy, freedom and our way of life always continue in one form or another. But we can be sure that they would be humble that Australia has remembered them in the way it has this last week and that we are recognising them in the way we are in this parliament.

They would be proud to know that the principles that they fought and died for have been defended by brave servicemen and servicewomen of Australia in other conflicts. They would be relieved that the Australia they grew up in and loved and defended is today still a free and democratic country of opportunity. They would be amazed at the progress Australia has made in the past 60 years. But I think they would also be particularly proud that the nations of Germany and Japan and Italy, nations whom we fought against in the Second World War, are today also nations of freedom and democracy. To them, I think that would be confirmation that their gallant efforts did not just defend our way of life but spread opportunities and freedoms and the principles and values of democratic societies into other nations around the world so that the people of those nations today can have opportunities that did not exist 60 and 65 years ago.

talk.start.para: —We are here today to consider VP Day and the experience that we have had over recent days commemorating and remembering the sacrifices that so many made so many years ago. It has been a time that I have found most rewarding as a member of parliament, actually getting out into the electorate and meeting veterans and their families and hearing about what life was like 60 years ago, the circumstances of struggle and sacrifice, some of the terrible memories but also some of the good times that were had. It was a time well before I was born, but it was a time which was crucial in determining the type of world we have today. There is no doubt that many of the freedoms we now enjoy and the circumstances we now have as a nation date back to that time and to what so many did to ensure that the modern world was able to develop in the manner in which it has. As earlier as speakers have said, even though we now face plenty of problems, with threats and challenges that people 60 years ago would never have thought could occur, the fact is that the challenges then were challenges that were immediate, that were very definite and that went to the very fabric and fibre of life at that time.

speech.para: I would like to go through some statistics about Australia’s part in that war effort. They are statistics which highlight the massive commitment of Australians and of Australia as a nation, both in humanity and resources, at the time of the Second World War. I will also give some comparisons of costs to highlight different aspects. In defence expenditure, the Second World War cost Australia just over £2 billion, as against expenditure in the First World War of some £188 million. We all know in comparing pounds of those days with dollars today that that is a massive explosion of resources required and spent.

The figures which bring home the nature and size of the two world wars as tragedies are those for casualties. Battle related deaths in the Second World War were 19,235 versus 53,993 in the First World War. The figures I found fascinating were for non-battle deaths, which were 20,194 in the Second World War versus 7,727 in the First World War. The figures for wounded in action were: 23,477 in the Second World War versus 137,000 in the First World War. Thankfully, in the Second World War we did not have ‘gassed’ as a casualty figure to deal with. But the number of prisoners of war was 28,756 in the Second World War versus 3,647 in the First World War and the number of prisoner of war deaths was only 109 in the First World War but 8,031 in the Second. And when we consider where Australians fought overseas and of the experiences many of them had as prisoners of war in places like Sandakan and Hellfire Pass, we get some idea of the nature of the tragedy.

One of the things I found fascinating in the VP Day functions in my electorate and through some of the work done on oral history was finding out from individuals their experience. I found that a particularly moving aspect of the proceedings and certainly a great way to get a better personal understanding of what people went through.

On Sunday, I had the privilege of attending an ecumenical church service at St Andrew’s in Canberra. It was one of the most moving church services I have been to. Three special guests focused on different aspects in memory of VP Day. One was a gentleman, a veteran, who had fought in the Middle East, in New Guinea and in the islands. He told of his experience and related some particularly touching stories regarding the circumstances around the time of VP Day when, effectively, hostilities had ceased but guns were still being fired and people were still being killed. He told a very moving story of a young man, a recent reinforcement who had been very keen to do his duty and play his part, who was killed at Tarakan after the effective end of hostilities and became another casualty at a time when it was hoped tragedies had ended. Another lady, a daughter of a veteran, told stories about what it was like at home, the circumstances faced by families while breadwinners were serving elsewhere in the country or overseas in the military. She told of pitching in with economic activities and work, of rationing and of the psychological pain and suffering which those at home went through while waiting to find out what had happened to their loved ones. She told of the relief and joy when eventually the Japanese surrender went ahead and how, for many people, the realisation that loved ones would not be coming home meant that the nature of that struggle and sacrifice would live with them forever and a day.

Probably the most moving story was that of the sister of a serving airman who died over Europe as a crew member of a Lancaster bomber. This young man had written a letter to be sent to his family on the event of his death and it was duly passed on as part of his personal effects. This lady read from that letter and showed an enormous amount of poise and dignity in doing so. The letter was a phenomenal piece of writing from an obviously very gifted 20-year-old, who would have had an incredible life in front of him had he the opportunity to live it. It was a letter of simplicity and clarity which went through the reasons he was there, why he felt the need to be there and why he was content to do what he believed needed to be done. He said it was a cause worth fighting for and spoke of the camaraderie and positive aspects he found in his Air Force service. He recognised the likelihood that it would end in his death and stated that, although he knew they would grieve, he wanted his family to know that he felt what he was doing was worth while. It was a very touching moment and really did go to the essence of the sacrifice of so many—those who died, those who were wounded and those who came back.

That letter encapsulated the necessary nature of that conflict—the fact that the forces that had to be opposed in that war really had to be dealt with and the fact that many ordinary Australians as well as many ordinary men and women from the allied countries recognised that and were prepared to step forward into the breach to do what had to be done.

Sixty years later it is important that we do remember that. We still have a lot of World War II veterans out there, but as they grow older, as each significant anniversary passes, there will be fewer of them around. It was great to present commemorative medallions to quite a number of veterans in my electorate on Monday. It was just great to see them get up when they could—and sometimes they could not—stepping forward, shaking their hands and thanking them for what they did. And war widows need to be remembered. They suffered for a long time, given the sacrifice they and their husbands made. Theirs was a very special penalty.

It was not just men who served but also women. Our Army nurses particularly ought to be remembered as doing a great job in difficult circumstances, having themselves been casualties. The valour displayed by Australian forces in so many locations throughout the Pacific, Europe, including Crete, and the Middle East highlights the tremendous effort undertaken by so many on behalf of the great cause of democracy. I am sure many of them, when looking at world events over the last 60 years, would be disappointed that, although we have not seen conflagrations the size of World War II since, there have been some rather terrible conflicts. It is sad that that is the world we live in, but that does not take away from the sacrifices made and the tremendous effort that went to ensuring that the Second World War was won by the forces of good.

When we look at what has happened to those who were our enemies at that time—Japan, Germany and Italy—we can say that there is hope for the world. They are countries that were rebuilt in a manner whereby they have become good citizens in the world of nations and have shown that from bad things good things can come. In these circumstances I think we owe a debt to all those involved in the effort around World War II in helping to bring that good to pass and for providing the basis for a modern democratic world which, despite its problems, we can build on and be proud of. I take the opportunity today to register my gratitude and thanks to all those involved. It was a tremendous effort by so many in this country at that time. It is a great honour to be in this place to honour them on this occasion.

talk.start.para: —Who can forget Ben Chifley’s famous words in 1945 when he said, ‘Fellow citizens, the war is over,’ or the statement of President Harry Truman of the United States when he said, ‘This is the day when fascism finally dies.’ Indeed, the Second World War was an extraordinary global battle against fascism in every corner of the world, from Europe to Asia.

speech.para: On that day, 15 August 1945, at noon, Japan Standard Time, Emperor Hirohito announced that Japan would surrender to the allied forces and thus end the Second World War, which had raged for six long years. The war in the Pacific, whose end we commemorated a few days ago, had been an especially brutal one. The cruel and often sadistic treatment of Australian prisoners of war by the Japanese gave Australians an experience of a kind of war that they had not experienced in prior conflicts.

Only a few weeks ago, I dined with one of my constituents, Dr Frank Mills—now well into his 90s. He was a prisoner of war at Sandakan and was one of only six out of 2,000 who survived a final death march at the war’s end. Dr Mills returned to Sydney and went on to pioneer open-heart surgery. Like so many of his generation, he recognised then and recognises today that the answer to war is not revenge and hatred, but forgiveness and love. For the generations that came after, surely the Second World War generation was the greatest generation. We who contemplate the achievements of that greatest generation stand in awe of their heroism, tenacity and dogged determination to survive against all the odds.

But we should also stand in awe of their forgiveness. When we consider how many conflicts around the world are grounded, are sourced, in battles and resentments and hatreds from centuries past, it is remarkable that it was the veterans of the Second World War—this greatest generation—who, as the Prime Minister said, barely 12 years after the end of that terrible war and barely 12 years after experiencing cruelty of a kind that had been unknown in the Australian experience entered into the first commerce agreement with Japan. That forgiveness is the most remarkable achievement. It is a lesson that all of us would do well to learn from and it is a lesson that I hope other people in other countries would learn from. If they did, our world would be a more peaceful one today.

It was a great time to rejoice in 1945. Tens of thousands poured onto the streets of Sydney, dancing and waving flags. Their joy, of course, was overshadowed by the loss of so many young Australians who we remember today. One million Australians served during the war. Almost 40,000 were killed and 30,000 were taken prisoner. In the ensuing months, Australian service men and women returned home. They were closely followed by a new wave of immigrants from Europe, the new wave of immigration that was driven by the extraordinary turmoil of the Second World War. Many Greeks, for example, left their homeland and came to Australia, and many settled in the electorate of Wentworth—as did many Hungarians and many Jews. The demographic face of my electorate is, in large measure, a consequence of the massive movements of peoples that followed the Second World War. As all of them left unhappy situations in their own countries, they too came to Australia, just as our servicemen returned, with forgiveness and optimism in their hearts. They worked together to create the wonderful, diverse community that we have both in Wentworth and across Australia.

More than 100,000 people, almost a third of this city’s population, attended Monday’s Salute to Veterans event in Canberra, which culminated at night with magnificent fireworks and two F111 fighter planes swooping over the lake, their afterburners leaving a trail of fire against the darkness of the Canberra sky. Earlier in the day the Prime Minister and other distinguished VIPs, including Japan’s ambassador, laid wreaths at the cenotaph at the Australian War Memorial to honour those who fought and died. It was a gesture of acceptance, but only one of many that have been made over the decades, between old enemies who had now become close friends. In Tokyo, the Japanese Prime Minister, Mr Koizumi, reiterated a sincere apology: ‘Our country through colonial rule and aggression caused tremendous damage and suffering to the people of many countries.’ That type of acknowledgement is one that is all too rarely made.

The electorate of Wentworth was attacked in the Second World War. We often think of Darwin as being the only part of the Australian mainland that was attacked. But in May 1942 several Japanese midget submarines entered Sydney Harbour and fired shells into the surrounding suburbs, including Rose Bay, and torpedoed a ferry killing 19 sailors and thereby brought Sydney right into the front line. Wentworth has many World War II veterans, but of course every year sadly there are fewer.

Last Sunday, this significant event in our wartime history was commemorated by the Bondi Junction-Waverley RSL sub-branch at a morning service, which my wife, Lucy, and I attended, at the Waverley Park cenotaph. It was followed by a lunch at their headquarters in Bondi Junction, just across the road from my electorate office. It was an invaluable opportunity to publicly thank the club’s 320 World War II veterans for their contribution in the war, for fighting to protect our freedom and democracy and for their continuing contribution to our community in the years subsequent.

On Monday, the Rose Bay RSL sub-branch also held a commemoration and service and a lunch at their club on the Rose Bay foreshore, where 63 years ago there were shells flying through the air from the Japanese submarines. I was delighted that $5,000 was made available to the Bondi Junction-Waverley RSL sub-branch and $2,000 to the Rose Bay RSL sub-branch for these important events under the Howard government’s Saluting their Service program of 2005. Bill Harrigan, the President of Bondi Junction-Waverley RSL, and John Fraser, the Honorary Secretary of Rose Bay RSL sub-branch, should be congratulated, together with their committees, on these initiatives.

Events such as these heighten community awareness about Victory in the Pacific Day and its place in Australian history. The Howard government, in partnership with these two RSLs, made certain that the Wentworth community remembered and honoured the men and women who defended our nation at its time of greatest danger. The Anzac spirit which began in Gallipoli and which continued through all of Australia’s conflicts, most especially in the Second World War, glowed brightly in Wentworth on Victory in the Pacific Day.

talk.start.para: —At the outset I want to congratulate a number of organisations for their commitment and work in my electorate. Included amongst the activities that occurred over the last week or so were a tree planting by Lidcombe RSL yesterday and the repositioning of a war memorial in the Holroyd council area at Merrylands, a project undertaken by the council in conjunction with the RSL. Previously, individuals were commemorated by trees and small plaques positioned along Memorial Avenue. There was a view that, over recent years, maintenance had been inappropriate and that those commemorations really did not stand out. I congratulate all those involved in the new memorial. It is very futuristic and, with its general visage looking towards the council chambers, which itself was built in recent years, it is quite impressive. Last weekend the Granville RSL held a dinner dance, at which wartime music was played. That function was organised by the Granville Historical Society in conjunction with Rotary. Most importantly, a video was made for all schools in the Reid electorate about the Second World War and victory in the Pacific. The Granville RSL will hold another function next week.

speech.para: I have to put on record my appreciation of the work of the Granville Historical Society. Given the nature of the area where it exists and the people it attracts, it is quite an enterprising and competent group which has now had about six publications. It is always ready to drop all other jobs and follow up an interesting, quaint or esoteric suggestion that I make about exploring the history of an individual et cetera. On the basis of what was presented at the dinner last Friday night, the video will be extremely impressive. Those are the main events in the electorate. I place on the record my appreciation of the work undertaken by all those involved.

Coincidentally, I received an email from my aunt yesterday which gave some indication of the day itself. She recalls, as a young schoolgirl, walking down Guildford Road from the local church, passing the hotel in Guildford Road and the owner, a Mr Inch, rushing out to say, ‘It’s over.’ She suggested to her mother that they should all go into the city to join everyone else in the celebrations. It was only later that she thought that her mother, after a hard day at work in a munitions factory at St Mary’s, would not be as enthusiastic as she was. Obviously we are commemorating the end of these events.

Perhaps it is a bit left field, but I would also like to commemorate the deaths at Hiroshima. By August 1946, it was estimated that 118,000 people had already died as a consequence of the bomb, 30,000 had been severely injured and another 48,000 were missing. In the interim, of course, the number of deaths has increased greatly, to almost a quarter of a million people now, of whom 5,000 last year were regarded as victims. Their deaths were consequent upon the destruction at Hiroshima. Just to give one description of it all, it is said:

quote.para: The blast of furnace heat flattened forty-two square miles of Hiroshima, and set what was left on fire. About 78,000 people died immediately, over 40,000 were horribly burned and some 14,000 were missing. Of 76,327 buildings, about 48,000 were completely destroyed and more than 22,000 severely damaged. Some 180,000 survivors were homeless, many of them soon to develop a deadly new illness they called atomic disease.

speech.para: Obviously you hear about many of the victims of Japanese atrocities, such as the people that were jailed after Singapore and captured in Timor. They have a view that they would not be alive today but for the decision by Truman. There is a very strong contention that the war might not have ended as early but for the dropping of the bomb. I do not contest that, but I have read in the last few years a very interesting series of essays by Gore Vidal, the acclaimed American writer. It is worth while sometimes being challenged in your perceptions of what is a set history. I do not say that he is correct, but he puts forward the very interesting contention that the peace party in Japan was far stronger than has been portrayed in later history. There were significant forces in a very undemocratic government which saw the writing on the wall and had a belief that Japan should capitulate. He puts forward the proposition that, whilst there might have been an element that sought to conclude the war—and that is quite viable: the Americans, Australians and others might have thought it at the time—there was also the possibility that this was meant as a warning signal to the Soviet Union, in its expansion into eastern Europe, that America had possession and that the Soviet Union should understand the repercussions of its aggression into Germany and other parts of Europe. That opened up the possibility of the atomic age. We are now seeing that many other countries are on the verge of or involved in the nuclear weapons industry.

Obviously, it also opened up the atomic age, and we now see a situation where so many other countries are on the verge of or involved in the nuclear weapons industry. The cynicism in international affairs was demonstrated this week by an article in the Sydney Morning Herald which exposed that Britain a few decades ago secretly supplied the Israelis with requirements for their nuclear program, not telling the Americans—keeping it secret from America. And Britain supplied this material on totally commercial grounds—there was big money in it for the nuclear industry in Britain and it went ahead.

As I said, the common belief is that dropping the bomb was necessary, that the war would otherwise have gone on for longer and that these people were collateral damage. There are strong points to that argument. We know about the Japanese aggression, we know it was a militaristic society and we know that those implicated in the aggression in China and other parts of Asia and in the move towards Australia were not easy to talk to, but there is a possibility that elements in Japan were realistic about where things were going.

I forgot to mention one of the events held in my electorate, and that was the very worthwhile service at St Mark’s Anglican Church at Granville on Sunday involving the RSL club, the Anglican congregation and other interested parties. It is worth noting that that church was designed by Blacket and is one of the most impressive churches in the whole of Sydney. In his address at the service there, the Rev. James McPherson repeated the famous words attributed to William Tecumseh Sherman at the Michigan Military Academy on 19 June 1879:

quote.para: War is at best barbarism ...Its glory is all moonshine. It is only those that have neither fired a shot nor heard the shrieks and groans of the wounded who cry aloud for blood, more vengeance, more desolation. War is hell.

speech.para: That was the theme of what I thought was a very good sermon on Sunday.

The other point we should remember is that the victory over Japan and the Axis powers was against tremendous odds. I have recently been reading a few books about early post-war France and also about the Vichy period, when De Gaulle had to flee to Britain and was basically regarded as a traitor to the French for disobeying the Vichy government’s capitulation to the Germans. And I think it was only in early 1944 that MacArthur actually had more Americans under his command than Australians, because American public opinion after the First World War and the isolationist push had rejected President Wilson and American involvement in the League of Nations and in the world. It was a very difficult situation for Britain and Australia, joined by the vestiges of Polish, Dutch and Belgian forces. As I said, there was very late involvement by the United States and there was great suspicion between the Soviet Union and the Western powers. The non-aggression pact between Hitler and Stalin at one stage was a very disturbing move by the Soviet Union. On the other hand, there had been the failure of the allies to support the republican government in Spain against fascist intervention there.

So it was a close thing. But the effort of this country, on a per capita basis, was monumental. We had a situation where for the first time women were largely encompassed in the non-household work force, including working in munitions. There was major rationing throughout the period. People had to make enormous sacrifices in their own country. People in auxiliary industries were not allowed to change their employment. My mother recalls the blacking-out of windows, the lights out, the shortages through the whole period. There were wardens. Schools had trenches dug through the school grounds for air-raid protection. All of those things indicate the degree of commitment in the country and the fact that it was not only the soldiers at the frontline but other large parts of Australian society that were involved.

This week, of course, has seen widespread commemoration of the 30,000-plus who were killed and the 180,000 who were wounded, but, as I said, at the same time we do not want to underestimate the efforts of those who supported the war effort. There was a need for armament construction and for homeland protection.

I want to join with all the other speakers in recognising the particular contribution of this country, which in per capita terms was very significant. It was significant in very real terms at Milne Bay and El Alamein et cetera. If you take an overview of the Second World War, Australia did play a very major role and that is what we recognise today—the contribution of individuals and of the broad Australian population in the defeat of the Axis powers.

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Mr HUNT

talk.start.para: —I want to acknowledge the service of the Australians who are commemorated on the 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific Day, and I want to do that in three stages. Firstly, I want to discuss the contribution of the many veterans who now reside in my electorate; secondly, I want to commemorate the nature of the conflict—the service, the struggle and the sacrifice that Australians and the war generation in particular made during the course of the Second World War; and, thirdly, I want to examine briefly some of the consequences and long-term challenges which we face even today as the echoes of that conflict continue through our world.

speech.para: I was fortunate to have the honour of representing the Australian government at nine Victory in the Pacific 60th anniversary commemoration celebrations within my electorate of Flinders during the course of the weekend. They were held at Phillip Island, Sorrento, Rye, Rosebud, Crib Point, Hastings and Dromana-Red Hill RSLs and, in addition, at Jean Turner Lodge, Lotus Lodge and Koorootang Retirement Village. I was able to meet with veterans and to present them with 60th anniversary commemorative medals. At that time, they told me their stories. They told me stories of Milne Bay, Kokoda, the Philippines and Ambon. They told me of service not just in the Pacific but also at Tobruk, in the Middle East more generally, in North Africa, in the Mediterranean, in the European conflict and in the Atlantic. These men and women were in just one electorate, one small part of Australia, and they served Australia in different ways during the Second World War.

To a person, they were modest about their achievements and their contributions. To a person, they had a tremendous respect for and remembrance of those who had served with them and whom they had lost. All knew young Australians who never saw middle age. All had friends and family who had been involved in the conflict but who had not returned. It is that personal element, combined with the sense of getting on with life, which I think symbolises not just the Australian contribution but the Australian spirit during the Second World War, that sense of energy, commitment, personal humility and respect for and remembrance of their colleagues, their friends and their families. It was an extraordinary contribution. But the conflict as a whole, as we look back over 60 years, represents the defining moment of the 20th century.

The 60th anniversary of 15 August represents 60 years since the Japanese surrender. The end of World War II recalls to mind the fact that there were 40,000 Australians who lost their lives, 30,000 Australians who served as prisoners of war and, by some records, 150,000 Australians who suffered serious injury of some form or other. There was an entire generation of Australians who served directly in the military, who worked in support of military activities or who had friends and families who maintained the country during the time in which it was entirely on a war footing.

The threat to Australia was real. Australians played a critical role at Milne Bay, where there was the first defeat of Japanese forces in the Pacific—led by Australians, conducted by Australians and with Australian casualties. The message from Milne Bay was that the conflict could be turned around. It was a critical time. The threat, had that not happened, was that Papua New Guinea would be used as a staging base for attacks against Northern Australia. There was no doubt that one of the objectives was the colonisation of Australian soil. It was a different time; Japan was then a different country from the one it is today. So we take no issue with and we have enormous respect for contemporary Japan. But it is critical that we acknowledge the depth of the threat and the strength of resolve and courage of those who placed themselves in harm’s way—many knowing that the risk of death was exceptionally high and there was virtually no likelihood that they themselves would survive. Sadly, that was the case for 40,000 Australians during the conflict. In the Pacific the places where they served—places such as Balikpapan; Sandakan; Ambon, which I mentioned earlier; Timor; the Philippines; Burma; Singapore; Malaysia; and so many other, different places—echo still today with the remembrance of service given, of conflicts fought and of lives lost.

On behalf of not just the Australian government but also succeeding generations within my electorate of Flinders, I want to express the profound gratitude we have for the service of those people within that Second World War generation. There was, of course, the bravery, skill and commitment of the soldiers. On the civilian front there was an extraordinarily powerful, galvanised nation. There was bipartisan support, for the most part, during the course of the Second World War. Politics, sadly, was not completely shelved, but there was a whole-of-nation approach. So the way in which the nation was led, firstly under the government of Prime Minister Menzies and secondly under the Labor Party, served Australia in its capacity to deal more generally with the outside world and in its capacity to deal internally with what could otherwise have been divisive issues.

I note in particular that Australians played a critical role not just in the Pacific but also in the North African campaign. The Rats of Tobruk, famous for their stoicism, were part of the resistance which ultimately allowed allied forces to retake North Africa and, from there, to move on to Italy, to Greece and to southern France. That was a decisive part to play in the European theatre of conflict. The strength of character shown, the extraordinary resilience and the good humour of Australian troops meant that the Allies maintained a foothold and a base at a critical juncture during that conflict.

Throughout the war, Australians were not only killed and injured but taken prisoner. So we remember now the Burma railway and Sandakan and we remember the hardship. There are famous incidents such as the wartime service of Sir Edward ‘Weary’ Dunlop. Those incidents and those names speak not just for themselves but for all of those other Australians who suffered during the war as prisoners of war. I was fortunate during my time at Melbourne university to come to know Sir Edward ‘Weary’ Dunlop. He was an extraordinarily warm and generous person. He carried no rancour for those who had interned him during the course of the Second World War, and he carried a great goodwill and generosity. The fact that as an individual he had those capacities shone very brightly. It said that Australians—and in a sense he exemplifies Australians—have the capacity to look forwards rather than backwards. So, whilst we look backwards today to remember, to honour and to recollect, none of that generation would want us to wallow in the past.

What is of profound importance is that within barely a decade the Australian government, particularly through the work of John McEwen, was able to forge with Japan, which had been 12 years before a bitter enemy, the 1957 Japan-Australia trade agreement. That was not just a critical economic step for Australia but also an extremely important diplomatic step in establishing Australia’s foothold within North Asia and also in moving forwards from that conflict. It was a controversial action. It was an action which received criticism within Australia and was the subject of debate and opposition within the parliament, but it spoke of a willingness, a commitment and a resolution to go forwards rather than backwards. In 1957 the government was not willing to let Australians be held prisoner to the past. Firstly, it wanted to help secure the economic future of Australia; secondly, it wanted to move forward in a way which represented a new world, not an old world.

This brings me to the third point that I wish to make today, and that is in relation to the consequences of the Second World War. There was the immediate consequence, after the extraordinary toll of human suffering—and Oxford academic Alan Bullock, in his book Hitler and Stalin, estimates that about 40 million lives, both military and civilian, were lost over the course of the Second World War. Beyond that extraordinary human toll, the consequences were twofold: there was the division of the world into the Eastern and Western blocs, in geostrategic terms, and, under Stalin, the Soviet Union extended its influence into eastern Europe and parts of central Europe. The result was that for the best part of half a century the world potentially faced the third great conflict of the 20th century. That we were able to avoid that conflict was in large part due to an absolute commitment by people, certainly on the allied side, not to repeat a cataclysmic conflict and to make that commitment from a position of strength, not weakness. They had learnt the lesson of the 1930s that, yes, history should work on a cooperative basis and diplomacy should be a primary tool, but when you are dealing with authoritarian regimes there must be a recognition that the currency, the language, is of resistance and strength, not acquiescence.

That brings me to the message which faces our world today. We live in a world where there is extraordinary cooperation. Japan, Germany and Italy are all integral parts of the community of advanced developed nations. They are nations of great good faith; they are nations of economic prosperity. They each face their own challenges, but they are an integral part of the world. They are an integral part of the world because of the resistance of the generation during the Second World War and because of the foresight of those who were involved in the reconciliation and the reconstruction after the Second World War. The lesson of the First World War was fortunately adhered to, and that was not to ‘beggar thy neighbour’ after the conflict.

So today, in dealing with a new type of conflict, there are two lessons that we draw from both the First World War and the Second World War. The first is that we cannot take a position of weakness in relation to terror and in relation to hostility and conflict. The only way of preventing wholesale slaughter and of preventing attacks is through a position of strength. If we are to withdraw from fronts and leave a vacuum, then that vacuum will be filled by those of hostile intent. Iraq and Afghanistan will be used as a staging point and a base for hostile activities. That was the case with Afghanistan prior to September 11. A weak internal structure was used as the basis for an international movement. It gathered its pace by, and sourced its strength from, preying on the host of a weak internal regime. So the first of the lessons we have to take from World War II is that we must show strength in resistance to hostile forces. They must understand that there is good intent and goodwill but an absolute commitment of resolve.

The second of the messages is that there must be an alternative for people so that they can find their dignity, find their future and have a sense of what is possible. We see that the descent of Germany, after the First World War, during the late 1920s and early 1930s, into an authoritarian state was in large measure due to the fact that the people had been denied economic opportunity. So we have a responsibility to help in the development and promotion of economic freedom and individual hope and capacity within Middle Eastern states, and within those areas where radical Islam would challenge. That must also be tied to the process of giving them a chance for individual freedom. That is why democratisation, slow as it may be, is fundamentally important in the Middle East, and why activities in Afghanistan, Iraq and Lebanon are fundamental to the future. The challenge remains for Saudi Arabia, Syria and Iran to take those steps. That is, ultimately, the legacy which we must pursue if we are truly to honour the veterans of World War II. In summation, I acknowledge, respect and honour the debt of gratitude which this generation owes to previous generations, and I thank all of those veterans who served Australia in World War II. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On Monday this nation commemorated 60 years since World War II was finally won on 15 August 1945.
