While our military personnel have fought wars on foreign soil between then and now, in this country of ours we have enjoyed 60 years of peace since that day. We have seen children born and grow up to become parents and then grandparents in a world of security and safety. That world was paid for by the courage and blood of another generation—the men and women who served our country in World War II—and by the courage, tenacity, fear and grief of those that remained behind.

speech.para: From a population of seven million people, 993,000—almost one million—men and women enlisted for service, which was almost one in seven people. Thirty-nine thousand Australians gave their lives, and their names are recorded on the Australian War Memorial Roll of Honour. Forty-seven thousand Australians were wounded, and 22,000 captured as prisoners of war.

In Parramatta, we commemorated the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II at the Lancer Barracks, which is the oldest working barracks in Australia, situated right in the heart of the CBD. It is fitting that we did. In recognising service to the country, you will not find a finer example than the men and women who have served and who currently serve with the Lancers in our local community. It is the nature of Australia that to its people, living in peace without hostile borders, war is a distant thing. For those of us born post World War II—and most of us were—we can and do live our lives without any real awareness of the level of commitment and service of our military men and women. There are men and women who stand ready to fight today, ready to risk their own lives for my life and for yours. That is an extraordinary thing. Even though I was raised in an army family, with my father joining the army when he was about 30 and serving as a musician in the 1st Military District Band, I still find it quite extraordinary when I meet the military men and women who serve in my community.

Following Australia’s decision to join the coalition of the willing in Iraq, I visited the war graves in Singapore. It was my own personal ritual: my own way of acknowledging, somewhat distantly I have to say, the consequences of engaging in a war, whether right or wrong. It seemed to me slightly amoral to be so far from the consequences of a war, yet to enjoy its possible benefits. When I visited those graves I found that the vast majority of epitaphs said, ‘beloved son’ or ‘beloved brother’. There were very few that referred to a ‘beloved husband’, and I came to realise only then how young these men and women were. They were cut down before they enjoyed the benefits of marriage, and quite often before they were even in love. They were incredibly young. Many of the people who paid in that war were the parents of those young men and women. Those parents, of course, passed away quite some time ago—probably 10 or 15 years ago—so we commemorated on Monday with the widows and the veterans who live 60 years later. We should remember that, at the time, and for the last 60 years, parents have lived without their sons and daughters. Many lived 40 or 50 years without their sons and daughters.

Several of the veterans who attended the commemoration and service on Monday told me that they had enlisted at the barracks on the very spot where we acknowledged our debt to them some 60 years later. They were by no means the first. The regiment dates back to 1885 and it is one of the longest continuously serving units in Australia. The Lancers were one of the very first colonial troops to arrive in South Africa in 1899, before Federation, for service in the Boer War. In 1935, they were given the title of ‘Royal’ and a year later they went from serving as a mounted cavalry battalion to serving as a mechanised machine gun regiment. In 1942 the Lancers were incorporated into the AIF as an armoured regiment and equipped with Matilda infantry support tanks. The Lancers have successfully secured their place in Australia’s military history as one of the key battalions who pioneered the use of tanks in jungle terrain as they did in Borneo and New Guinea in the Second World War.

Having served in South Africa, Rumani, Jerusalem, Jaffa, Jericho, Jordan, New Guinea and Borneo, as well as a number of other key conflicts since 1899, and with 21 battle honours, the battalion is the most highly decorated unit in the Australian Army. The Lancers played a significant role in World War II and had many actively serving men who celebrated the end of World War II in the Pacific while on active duty on 15 August 1945. They fought in Borneo and New Guinea and most significantly were the only amphibious battalion to have served in a battle in the Pacific, as they did in Balikpapan. The Lancers role in Balikpapan saw them launch Australia’s heaviest tank attack of the war.

The barracks held an open day last Saturday as an opportunity for the people of Parramatta to come and see at first hand Australia’s oldest serving barracks. The barracks are in the middle of the CBD in Parramatta. In fact, Parramatta has literally grown up around the barracks. I realised this while standing in the parade ground in the middle of the barracks during the commemorative service. The juxtaposition of the newly built office towers around the smaller, squat, heritage listed buildings of the barracks is quite astounding. For me it served as a great reminder that the men and women who fought for our country have truly given us the opportunities that we have today.

The Lancer museum, which is located in historic Linden House at the barracks, provides a fitting home for Australia’s oldest regimental museum. In keeping with the origin of the regiment, it is the product of the voluntary efforts of ordinary Australian citizens devoted to preserving our history and traditions. Over 400 people attended the open day at the barracks—a fantastic turnout to remember and commemorate the 60th anniversary of VP Day by the people of Parramatta.

On Monday the barracks coordinated a moving commemorative service to remember those who had fallen during the war and to honour those who were with us on Monday. This was a great opportunity to truly embrace the 60th anniversary and I was honoured to present the commemorative medallions to the 45 veterans and widows who came to the service. The barracks was the perfect setting for the ceremony—an operational barracks where the soldiers of the present and the greater community joined together to honour the lives lost and the lives lived in building the country which we so easily enjoy today.

We honoured on Monday one of the toughest generations of Australians—a generation who wrote the rule book of jungle warfare under the worst conditions of the war. Australians served wherever the battles raged, but the Pacific was a diabolical struggle in the most heartless of terrain—mountainous jungle and swamps—faced with tropical heat, humidity, jungle rot, malaria and new standards in savagery. They faced an unseen enemy that believed in victory or extermination. These are really the toughest of Australians.

On Monday we gathered with the greatest respect, affection and gratitude to honour this tough generation: those who served, those who suffered and those who gave their lives in service of our country. We gathered to give thanks to the veterans of World War II—those who fought and the men and women who loved and lost them in unimaginable circumstances. By this act of remembrance we reminded ourselves that this special place we live in and the way of life we enjoy has been hard won through the commitment and sacrifice of those who served, paid for with lives cut off too young, with hopes and aspirations destroyed. It is a very precious inheritance willed to us by the men and women who stood with us on Monday and the men and women who fought and died at their side.

The horrors of war do not end with the war. Wives grieved for decades and children grew up without their parents. For those that returned, even families that were reunited suffered from the years lost and from the experiences and horror of their men, which were never shared in many cases, and through illness, both physical and emotional. Father-child relations were forever changed by the absence of the fathers. Our lives now were paid for not just in the lives lost but in many cases by the lives altered and lived through the last 60 years.

The service and open day would not have been a success without the work of some important people, and I want to extend my thanks on behalf of the Parramatta community to John Howells and Len Koles from the Barracks museum, both retired servicemen who served in the Lancers; Colonel Don Tate, retired; Commanding Officer Lieutenant Colonel Brett Barlow; Regimental Sergeant Major Warrant Officer Class 1 Bill Baxter; Warrant Officer Class 2 Mark Byrne from the 1/15 New South Wales Lancers Battalion; Colin Smith, President of Parramatta RSL sub-branch; Maurice Greene, Deputy President of Parramatta RSL sub-branch; and Bob Durbin, Honorary Secretary of Parramatta RSL sub-branch. Without the important work of these people, we would not have been able to commemorate Victory in the Pacific Day in Parramatta in the way we did. We would not have been able to give the honour to our veterans that we gave to them on Monday. For those who served their country, those who gave their lives, those whose loved ones lie in foreign soil and those who lived through the mud and horror to stand with us 60 years on, on behalf of the people of Parramatta I honour them and thank them.
Debate (on motion by Ms Hall) adjourned.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005:

item.para: Is the Minister aware that Mr Woo Jin Park, who formally worked at Unit 12, 5 Bayview Avenue, The Entrance, NSW, fled when confronted by Immigration officers.
Is the Minister aware that Mr Park was deported as an illegal overstayer and used a fake company to subcontract his services to the Di Lorenzo Company of Sydney.
Can the Minister advise of the circumstances surrounding this case.
Is the Minister aware that Mr Jin Park has returned to Australia on a false passport under a different name and has been seen by former co-workers.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Departmental records indicate that Mr Park did not attempt to flee Immigration officers.

Mr Park was removed from Australia on 15 December 2002. He is believed to have been a Director of two tiling companies in Australia. These two companies were registered with ASIC in 1996 and 2000 respectively and were deregistered after strike off action in 2001 and 2004 respectively. Records indicate a possible link with Di Lorenzo but my Department can not confirm this.

Mr Park was brought to the attention of my Department in April 2002 through community information alleging that he was engaging illegal workers. He was subsequently identified as an unlawful non-citizen and removed.
Mr Park returned to Australia as the holder of a sponsored spouse visa in December 2004. The case is being investigated.

In May 2003 my Department received information alleging that Mr Park had returned to Sydney. Checks of departmental records and databases do not confirm this. The Department could find no evidence that he had entered with another passport.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 12 May 2005:

item.para: How many complaints have been made to the Commonwealth Ombudsman in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001, (g) 2002, (h) 2003, (i) 2004, and (j) 2005 in relation to the actions of (i) his department, (ii) AusAID, and (iii) Austrade.
How many of the complaints were upheld.
What was the nature of each complaint that was upheld.
What action has the Department taken in response to complaints upheld by the Ombudsman.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: DFAT

item.para: This information is available in the Annual Reports of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. The Department’s Annual Reports also provide an overview of those complaints received by the Ombudsman that are referred to the Department for comment, investigation or action. Not all complaints received by the Ombudsman are referred to the Department for comment, investigation or action.
This information is available in the Annual Reports of the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

The nature of each complaint that was upheld (ie. where a finding of “agency defect” was made) is set out below. This data has been drawn from Departmental records and confirmed by the Commonwealth Ombudsman. Depending on the number of substantive issues involved in a complaint, more than one finding may be made in respect of individual complaints.

For privacy reasons, it is not appropriate to provide any additional detail concerning individual cases. Neither the Department nor the Ombudsman’s Office is able to provide information relating to (a) 1996, (b) 1997, and (c) 1998.

It would be too resource intensive to provide details concerning every case over the last 10 years where the Ombudsman has made a finding of “agency defect”. In general terms, the types of action taken by the Department include: review of internal procedures; letters of clarification; provision of information; consideration of or further review of cases under the Commonwealth Scheme for Compensation for Detriment caused by Defective Administration (CDDA).

quote.para: AusAID

item.para: This information is available in the Annual Reports of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. The Agency also provides an overview of complaints to the Ombudsman handled by the Agency in its Annual Report. However, not all complaints received by the Ombudsman are referred to the Agency for comment, investigation or action.
The Commonwealth Ombudsman upheld a finding of defective administration in relation to three complaints during the relevant period.

Two complaints were from recipients of scholarships funded from Australia’s overseas aid program who complained that they should not have to repay the cost of their scholarships after they sought to remain in Australia contrary to the conditions of their scholarships. One complaint was in relation to the timeliness of provision of information about applying for a scholarship.

In relation to the two complaints about repayment, AusAID decided not to pursue debt recovery and it adopted a new policy position whereby debt recovery would only be pursued where there was an agreement with the student that clearly established the amount and conditions under which a debt to the Commonwealth would be incurred. In relation to the single complaint about the provision of information, AusAID supplied relevant information to the complainant.

quote.para: Austrade

item.para: Austrade was to review a decision made under FOI legislation.
Austrade conducted an internal review of the decision that resulted in further material being released.

quote.para: AusAID

item.para: This information is available in the Annual Reports of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. The Agency also provides an overview of complaints to the Ombudsman handled by the Agency in its Annual Report. However, not all complaints received by the Ombudsman are referred to the Agency for comment, investigation or action.
The Commonwealth Ombudsman upheld a finding of defective administration in relation to three complaints during the relevant period.

In relation to the two complaints about repayment, AusAID decided not to pursue debt recovery and it adopted a new policy position whereby debt recovery would only be pursued where there was an agreement with the student that clearly established the amount and conditions under which a debt to the Commonwealth would be incurred. In relation to the single complaint about the provision of information, AusAID supplied relevant information to the complainant.

item.para: Austrade was to review a decision made under FOI legislation.
Austrade conducted an internal review of the decision that resulted in further material being released.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: and (2) Table 1 shows the number of locally engaged staff (LES) employed by, and performing duties for, my department from 1996 to 2005. Table 2 shows the number of LES employed (that is, engaged) by my department but funded and performing duties for other agencies for 2004 and 2005.

While DFAT engages LES on behalf of other agencies, those agencies are responsible for determining the composition of their LES profiles at overseas posts. Numbers of attached agency LES are only included in Table 2 for 2004 and 2005 because, prior to this, DFAT did not maintain centrally comprehensive data on LES performing duties on behalf of other agencies at DFAT-managed posts.
Table 1
*DFAT LES numbers from 1996-2004 are as at 30 June as reported in the DFAT Annual Report. 2005 DFAT LES numbers are as at 18 May 2005.
Table 2
*Attached Agency LES numbers are as at 30 June 2004 and 18 May 2005.
All LES undergo a probity check prior to their employment being confirmed. This is an identity check which includes a police records check.

LES who occupy a designated security assessed position undergo a security clearance process. This process must be successfully completed prior to their employment being confirmed. Security clearances are re-assessed every five years in accordance with the guidelines set out in the Commonwealth Protective Security Manual.

subdebateinfo.title: Heads of Mission: Visit to Australia

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 12 May 2005:

item.para: In respect of the visit to Australia by Australia’s European Heads of Mission between 14 and 22 February 2005, (a) how many and which Heads of Mission participated in the visit, (b) how many and which Heads of Mission were accompanied by spouses or partners, (c) what sum was spent by the department on (i) airfares to Australia, (ii) transport, (iii) accommodation, (iv) social functions/entertainment, and (v) travel allowances for Heads of Mission and their accompanying spouses or partners.
Which cities did the Heads of Mission visit while in Australia.
What was the program of activities for the visit.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: 16. These were Australian Ambassadors to: Austria, Belgium/EU, Denmark, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, the Netherlands, Poland, Russia, Serbia & Montenegro, Spain, Sweden and Turkey. The Ambassador-Designate to France and the High Commissioner-Designate to the United Kingdom also attended. Three Ambassadors took the opportunity to combine the meeting with scheduled mid-term consultations, resulting in savings for the department.

item.label: (b)
item.para: One Head of Mission was accompanied by a spouse as part of that staff member’s entitlement to mid-term leave fares and was not attributed to the Head of Mission meeting.

item.label: (iii)
item.para: and (v) A total of $33,544.54.

All Heads of Mission visited Canberra and Sydney, and 15 Heads of Mission visited Melbourne. In addition, individual Heads of Mission visited: the Hunter region (including Newcastle, Pokolbin and Singleton), the Riverina region (including Griffith, Leeton and Wagga Wagga), Bendigo, Brisbane, the Gold Coast region, Campania, Hobart, Fremantle, New Norcia and Perth.

The Heads of Mission had meetings with Federal and State Government officials and representatives from a range of private industries. The purpose of these meetings was to explore opportunities to further Australian business and other interests. The Ambassador to Sweden combined the visit with participation in the official visit to Australia by the Prime Minister of Sweden.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: DFAT does not deploy A-based staff overseas to work exclusively on consular issues. Consular work is an integral part of the responsibilities of A-based overseas staff generally.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 12 May 2005:

item.para: Further to the answer to question No. 560 (Hansard, 14 March 2005, page 176), has he read the report titled ‘Corby’s team accuses AFP of lying’ in The Canberra Times on 18 April 2005 which reported that there had been a lack of cooperation from the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and that it had refused to assist Indonesian authorities with finger-printing the plastic bag containing marijuana.

Has he seen the report on the Sunday Program on 8 May 2005 which showed an AFP Officer describing new evidence supporting Ms Schappelle Corby’s claim that baggage handlers could have been involved in the drug smuggling and that in June 1997 the Australian Consulate in Bali was advised by an Australian couple that they arrived at their Bali hotel on a flight from Melbourne and found a large block of compressed marijuana in their luggage.
Can he confirm that the Australian Consulate in Bali has previously advised Australians who found illegal drugs in their luggage to destroy or dispose of the drugs; if not, why not.
Has this ever been investigated by the AFP; if so, when and what are the details, if not, why not.

Did the Australian Consulate advise (a) Ms Corby’s defence or (b) Indonesian authorities that other Australians had previously arrived in Bali unsuspectingly carrying illegal drugs; if so, when and what are the details; if not, why not.
Has the Australian Government assisted Ms Corby’s defence; if so, how, if not, why not.
Has the Australian Government made any representations to Indonesian authorities on Ms Corby’s behalf; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.
Yes.

An Australian citizen has claimed that in 1997 he reported to a consular official in Bali that he had discovered drugs in his luggage when he opened it on arrival at his hotel. A consular official who was in Bali at that time recalls being contacted about the reported incident. He suggested a number of options the Australians might consider but did not advise a specific course of action.
Questions about Australian Federal Police investigations should be directed to the Attorney-General.
The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Canberra spoke about the incident described in the answer to Question 3 with Ms Corby’s Australian lawyers, Hoolihans, on 31 March 2005.
The conduct of Ms Corby’s defence is primarily a matter for Ms Corby and her legal team and not the Australian Government.

The Australian Government has responded to all reasonable requests for assistance from Ms Corby’s lawyers. At the request of Ms Corby’s lawyers on 12 May 2005, my department informed them on 13 May about a police investigation into the involvement of baggage handlers in drug-trafficking through Sydney Airport. The letter noted that the police believed the baggage handlers that they were investigating had been on duty on 8 October 2004, when a large shipment of cocaine had been brought into Australia. Ms Corby’s lawyers submitted the letter to the judge on 16 May.

On 27 June 2005, the Minister for Justice and Customs wrote to Qantas, the Sydney Airport Authority and Brisbane Airport Corporation passing on requests from Ms Corby’s lawyers for access to possible witnesses. The Minister for Justice and Customs wrote again to Qantas and Sydney Airport on 15 July 2005 passing further requests for information. On 13 July 2005, the Minister for Justice and Customs wrote to the Victorian Minister for Corrections and the NSW Minister for Justice passing on requests from Ms Corby’s lawyers for access to possible witnesses currently in custody or on parole in those two states. On 13 July 2005, the Minister for Justice and Customs provided contact details for the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions and relevant authorities in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland to Ms Corby’s lawyers. Also on 13 July 2005, the Minister for Justice and Customs wrote to the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions to advise him that Ms Corby’s lawyers may approach him with an application for immunity.

On 8 July 2005, the Minister for Justice and Customs advised Ms Corby’s lawyers that the Australian Government would provide video link facilities in Australia for anyone who wished to give evidence but was unable or unwilling to travel to Indonesia. This offer was reiterated on 13 July 2005 and addresses of facilities in Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane were provided to Ms Corby’s lawyers on 19 July 2005. This assistance follows the extensive assistance provided by the Australian Government prior to and during her trial, which included making arrangements for a Victorian prisoner to travel to Bali to give evidence in response to a request for mutual assistance from the Indonesian Government.

Ms Corby was informed that she could apply for further assistance under the Special Circumstances (Overseas) Scheme, administered by the Attorney-General, for legal and related costs, including the out of pocket expenses (travel expenses, video link expenses and the like) associated with the attendance of witnesses to give evidence in foreign countries. An application for further assistance will be assessed in the usual way to determine whether it meets the Scheme criteria.

Before Ms Corby’s conviction on 27 May I raised her case with my Indonesian counterpart, Mr Hassan Wirajuda, on 17 March, pointing out that the Australian Government was following the legal proceedings closely. The Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice and Customs met with representatives of Ms Corby’s legal defence team on 18 March 2005, as did the Australian Federal Police. The Minister for Justice and Customs also wrote on 23 March to his Indonesian counterpart, the Minister for Law and Human Rights, Dr Hamid Awaluddin, about the case. On 7 April 2005, in Jakarta, the Minister for Justice and Customs again met with Ms Corby’s defence team and also spoke with the Indonesian Attorney-General, Abdul Rahman Saleh.

During President Yudhoyono’s visit to Australia on 5 April 2005, the Attorney-General raised the case with him in the presence of the Prime Minister. President Yudhoyono said publicly during his visit that, while he could not intervene in independent judicial processes, he believed the process and outcome must be fair and recognised as such both nationally and internationally.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 25 May 2005:

quote.para: In respect of each counter-terrorism exercise conducted or coordinated by the Government since March 1996, (a) what was the name of the exercise, (b) when was it conducted, (c) which Commonwealth Government (i) departments and (ii) agencies participated in the exercise, and (d) which State and Territory government (i) departments and (ii) agencies participated in the exercise

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: In respect of each counter-terrorism exercise conducted or coordinated by the Government, I have provided information regarding counter-terrorism exercises since March 1996, (a) (b) Counter-terrorism exercise names and dates are detailed in the table below. (c) (i) (ii) Australian Government departments and agencies have participated in every counter-terrorism exercise since March 1996. Participating departments and agencies are drawn from the Australian Government Counter-Terrorism Committee (formerly the Special Inter-Departmental Committee for Protection Against Violence) members and the National Counter-Terrorism Committee (NCTC) (formerly the Standing Advisory Committee on Commonwealth and State/Territory Cooperation for Protection Against Violence). (d) (i) (ii) State and Territory government departments and agencies have participated in every counter-terrorism exercise since March 1996. Participating departments and agencies are drawn from the NCTC.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 25 May 2005:

item.para: How many calls were received by the National Security Hotline each month since it was established on 27 December 2002.

How many calls received by the Hotline (a) provided information, (b) involved requests for information, (c) were assessed to be hoax or crank calls, and (d) were referred for further investigation to (i) the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, (ii) the Australian Federal Police, (iii) the Australian Customs Service, (iv) State and/or Territory Police, (v) the Australian Tax Office, and (vi) any other agency.

How many investigations undertaken as a consequence of calls made to the Hotline (a) revealed information relating to terrorist activities (i) in Australia and (ii) overseas, and (b) resulted in the arrest of any person in relation to suspected terrorist offences.

Has the Hotline received any false or malicious allegations relating to persons; if so, what measures have been taken in relation to persons using the Hotline to make false or malicious allegations about other persons.
What is done with information received by the Hotline that is assessed not to be relevant to terrorism or national security and do any agencies retain this information.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The National Security Hotline has received the calls below as at 31 May 2005:

item.label: (a)
item.para: As at 31 May 2005, the National Security Hotline had received and processed 24,100 calls which provided information.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The National Security Hotline also provides information to clients, principally giving guidance and support to callers. Classified as assurance calls, a caller can be given advice on other agency contacts where more specific information may be obtained, such as travel advice or venue security. The National Security Hotline has since its establishment, received and provided information to some 3,611 such assurance calls.

(c) (d) (i) (ii) (iii) (iv) (v) (vi) All calls received at the National Security Hotline and processed as information calls are forwarded to the respective state/territory police authorities, ASIO and the Australian Federal Police. It remains the responsibility of these authorities and agencies to undertake analysis and investigation, determine the relevance of the information call, and to decide whether to share relevant information with other government departments and agencies.

(3) (a) (i) (ii) All information received at the National Security Hotline is treated as serious and forwarded directly to ASIO, the Australian Federal Police and the relevant state and/or territory police jurisdiction for their analysis and investigation. It remains their responsibility to determine the relevance of the information to terrorist activities.

item.label: (c) (d)
item.para: (i) (ii) (iii) (iv) (v) (vi) All calls received at the National Security Hotline and processed as information calls are forwarded to the respective state/territory police authorities, ASIO and the Australian Federal Police. It remains the responsibility of these authorities and agencies to undertake analysis and investigation, determine the relevance of the information call, and to decide whether to share relevant information with other government departments and agencies.

(3) (a) (i) (ii) All information received at the National Security Hotline is treated as serious and forwarded directly to ASIO, the Australian Federal Police and the relevant state and/or territory police jurisdiction for their analysis and investigation. It remains their responsibility to determine the relevance of the information to terrorist activities.

item.label: (b)
item.para: All analysis and investigation of information received at the National Security Hotline is undertaken by state and/or territory police authorities and federal agencies. It remains their responsibility to determine the relevance of the information as it pertains to the resulting arrest of any person(s) involved in terrorist activities.

item.label: (a)
item.para: (ii) All information received at the National Security Hotline is treated as serious and forwarded directly to ASIO, the Australian Federal Police and the relevant state and/or territory police jurisdiction for their analysis and investigation. It remains their responsibility to determine the relevance of the information to terrorist activities.

item.label: (b)
item.para: All analysis and investigation of information received at the National Security Hotline is undertaken by state and/or territory police authorities and federal agencies. It remains their responsibility to determine the relevance of the information as it pertains to the resulting arrest of any person(s) involved in terrorist activities.
The decision that a call received at the National Security Hotline is a hoax or malicious is the responsibility of the state and/or territory police authorities and federal agencies.

All information calls received by the National Security Hotline are forwarded for analysis and investigation by state and/or territory police authorities and federal agencies. Any decision taken as to an information call being relevant to terrorism or national security, rests with these authorities or agencies.

The National Security Hotline holds within its secure database and Class C vault, all information received from callers. The Hotline is unable to confirm the retention policies of state and/or territory police and federal agencies on information forwarded to them and subsequently deemed not relevant to terrorism or national security.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 24 May 2005:

item.para: How many individuals have reached the Medicare Safety Net Threshold during (a) 2003 and (b) 2004 in (i) New South Wales and (ii) in the electoral division of Werriwa.

How many individuals have reached the Medicare Safety Net threshold during (a) 2003 and (b) 2004 in the postcode area (i) 2167, (ii) 2168, (iii) 2170, (iv) 2171, (v) 2174, (vi) 2178, (vii) 2179, (viii) 2560, (ix) 2564, (x) 2565 and (xi) 2566.
How many families have reached the Medicare Safety Net Threshold during (a) 2003 and (b) 2004 in (i) New South Wales and (ii) in the electoral division of Werriwa.

How many families have reached the Medicare Safety Net threshold during (a) 2003 and (b) 2004 in the postcode area (i) 2167, (ii) 2168, (iii) 2170, (iv) 2171, (v) 2174, (vi) 2178, (vii) 2179, (viii) 2560, (ix) 2564, (x) 2565 and (xi) 2566.
How many families have registered for the Medicare Safety Net during (a) 2003 and (b) 2004 in (i) New South Wales and (ii) the electoral division of Werriwa.

How many families have registered for the Medicare Safety Net during (a) 2003 and (b) 2004 in the postcode area (i) 2167, (ii) 2168, (iii) 2170, (iv) 2171, (v) 2174, (vi) 2178, (vii) 2179, (viii) 2560, (ix) 2564, (x) 2565 and (xi) 2566.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The smallest geographical area for which the department routinely produces statistics is by electoral division. The postcodes you have nominated are contained within or overlap the electorates of Werriwa, Fowler, Hughes, Hume, Macarthur and Prospect. The requested statistics cover each of these electorates.

item.para: and (2) The number of individuals who reached the Medicare Safety Net threshold up to 31 July 2004 in (i) New South Wales, (ii) the electoral division of Werriwa and (iii) other relevant electorates, is as follows:

entry.para: EXTENDED MEDICARE SAFETY NET NUMBER OF INDIVIDUALS WHO REACHED THE SAFETY NET THRESHOLD

item.para: Note - based on substantiated and unsubstantiated claims.

and (4) The number of families that reached the Medicare Safety Net threshold up to 31 July 2004 in (i) New South Wales, (ii) the electoral division of Werriwa, and (iii) other relevant electorates, is as follows:

entry.para: EXTENDED MEDICARE SAFETY NET NUMBER OF FAMILIES WHO REACHED THE SAFETY NET THRESHOLD AND NUMBER OF PERSONS IN THOSE FAMILIES TO 31 JULY 2004
No. of Persons in those Families

item.para: Note - based on substantiated and unsubstantiated claims.

and (6) The number of families that were registered for the Medicare Safety Net at 29 August 2004 in (i) New South Wales, (ii) the electoral division of Werriwa, and (iii) other relevant electorates, is as follows:
Notes to the Tables:

The most recently published statistics on individuals and families who have reached Extended Medicare Safety Net thresholds, and on Extended Medicare Safety Net benefits, have regard to claims processed by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) up to and including 31 July 2004. Statistics relating to families registered are as at 29 August 2004.
The statistics were compiled from postcode level data (postcode of the head of the household, otherwise postcode of the oldest member of the family) and are based on 2001 electorate boundaries.

Where a postcode overlapped electorate boundaries, statistics were allocated to electorate using a concordance file derived from population census data. This can result in some data being erroneously allocated to an adjoining electorate. Data for people using post office boxes or private mail bags are excluded from electorate reporting as this cannot be appropriately allocated. Data have also been excluded if postcodes were not present on the concordance files.

The statistics on families and individuals who appear to have reached the Safety Net thresholds, include families and individuals who need to verify that they have paid the full fee charged, where claims have been lodged with the HIC prior to paying the treating practitioner (unsubstantiated claims).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 25 May 2005:

item.para: How many Job Network providers are currently operating in the electoral division of Werriwa and what are their names and addresses.
How many job seekers are currently registered with (a) each Job Network provider and (b) each office of each provider operating in the electoral division of Werriwa.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003 and (e) 2004, in (i) Australia and (ii) the electoral division of Werriwa, how many Newstart and Youth Allowance recipients were placed into jobs through job assistance from Job Network providers.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003 and (e) 2004, how many long-term unemployed people (i) in total and (ii) as a proportion of all unemployed people, participated in intensive assistance programs in the electoral division of Werriwa.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003 and (e) 2004, how many people who have participated in intensive assistance in the electoral division of Werriwa have participated on (i) one occasion, (ii) two occasions, (iii) three occasions, and (iv) more than three occasions.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003 and (e) 2004, how many job seekers who participated in intensive assistance in the electoral division of Werriwa found employment and what proportion found (i) full-time, (ii) part-time and (iii) casual employment.
How many Work for the Dole providers are currently operating in the electoral division of Werriwa, what are their names and addresses and what programs do they offer.
For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many people who participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Werriwa found employment.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, what proportion of people who participated in the Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Werriwa found (i) full-time, (ii) part-time and (iii) casual employment following their placement.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many people who participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Werriwa were in (i) full-time, (ii) parttime and (iii) casual employment three months after completing their placement.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr Andrews

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: and (2) Job Network is administered on the basis of 19 Labour Market Regions and 137 Employment Services Areas (ESAs), the boundaries of which do not align with those of Federal Electorates. Job seekers choose Job Network members for a variety of reasons including location, proximity to transport routes and Centrelink offices, or the satisfaction of friends and others. Job seekers residing in one electorate or ESA may elect to be assisted through Job Network sites located in adjoining electorates or ESAs. For illustration, job seekers residing in the electorate of Werriwa may be assisted through Job Network sites located in the electorates of Hughes, Lindsay, Macarthur, Prospect and Fowler. The Fairfield/Liverpool and Macarthur ESAs are most closely aligned with the electorate of Werriwa and, therefore, answers are provided with reference to these ESAs.

There are currently 25 Job Network members and other Job Placement Organisations operating in the Fairfield/Liverpool ESA and 16 in the Macarthur ESA. Their names, office locations and the number of job seekers on their caseloads are shown in Table 1.
Table 1—Job Network Sites - Fairfield/Liverpool and Macarthur Employment Services Areas

*JPO = Job Placement Organisation.

Notes: Site details and job seeker numbers are as at 20 May 2005. Caseload numbers are for the “JN Active Caseload”, that is job seekers currently in assistance with a JN site or very recently referred for assistance. Caseload numbers are at a point in time and change as job seekers are referred to a site or exit assistance at the site. JPOs are not allocated a specific business share, but compete to secure vacancies from employers and to refer eligible job seekers.

The numbers of Newstart and Youth Allowance (Other) recipients placed into jobs by Job Network providers and other Job Placement Organisations in the years 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003 and 2004, in (i) Australia and (ii) the Fairfield/Liverpool and Macarthur ESAs are shown in Table 2.

Details of the number of long term unemployed jobseekers commencing in Intensive Assistance in the Fairfield/Liverpool and Macarthur ESAs in the years 2000, 2001, 2002 and 2003 are shown in Table 3.

The delivery of Intensive Assistance ceased on 30 June 2003. The delivery of the new Intensive Support service under the Active Participation Model (APM) commenced on 1 July 2003. Details of long term unemployed Intensive Support participant numbers in the Fairfield/Liverpool and Macarthur ESAs in the years 2003 and 2004 are shown in Table 4.

item.para: Notes: Long term unemployed job seekers are those registered as unemployed for 12 months or more. Numbers for Intensive Support in 2003 are from 1 July 2003 when the APM commenced. Job seekers eligible for Job Search Support Only have been excluded from the calculation of percentages. The number of participants refers to all job seekers assisted in Intensive Support in that year.
In view of the 12 month duration of Intensive Assistance it is not practical to report on the numbers of job seekers who participated on multiple occasions in 2000, 2001, 2002 and 2003.

Delivery of Intensive Assistance ceased on 30 June 2003. From 1 July 2003, improvements to the delivery of Job Network services were introduced through implementation of the APM. While Intensive Assistance allowed for multiple episodes of assistance, the new APM arrangements provide for job seekers to be assisted by a single Job Network member for the full duration of their unemployment, allowing the service provider to develop a detailed understanding of each job seeker’s needs.

The Post-Programme Monitoring (PPM) survey conducted by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations (DEWR) measures job seekers’ outcomes three months after they have left assistance. PPM survey results are an estimate of outcomes levels based on responses from a sample of clients rather than the full population.
PPM outcomes results on a geographic basis are only available at the DEWR Employment Service Area (ESA) level. The Werriwa electorate is primarily within the Fairfield/Liverpool and Macarthur ESA’s.

Aggregated outcomes estimates for Intensive Assistance (IA) for these ESA’s are shown in Table 5. Table 5 includes (a) the total proportion in employment and (b) the proportions in (i) full-time, (ii) part-time and (iii) casual employment 3 months after exiting their placements.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 25 May 2005:

item.para: How many people in the electoral division of Werriwa were eligible to apply for the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme in (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004.
How many people in the electoral division of Werriwa successfully applied for the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme in (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004.

How many graduates in the electoral division of Werriwa found employment or were in business within three months of the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme assistance ending in (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004.
How many graduates in the electoral division of Werriwa were still running their business 18 months after the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme assistance had ended.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr Andrews

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS) is administered on the basis of 19 Labour Market Regions and 137 Employment Services Areas (ESAs), the boundaries of which do not align with those of Federal Electorates. The Fairfield/Liverpool and Macarthur ESAs are most closely aligned with the electorate of Werriwa and, therefore, answers are provided with reference to those ESAs.
The number of eligible job seekers is a point in time figure and it is therefore not practical to report on the number of people who were eligible to apply for NEIS for the years specified.
To be eligible to participate in NEIS a person must be:

The number of people in the ESAs of Fairfield/Liverpool and Macarthur who successfully applied for and commenced in NEIS in the calendar years 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003 and 2004 are presented in Table 1.
Table 1 NEIS Commencements by Calendar Year

The Post-Programme Monitoring (PPM) survey conducted by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations measures job seekers’ outcomes three months after they have left assistance. In determining the post-assistance outcome level for NEIS a statistical minimum number of PPM survey responses are required to provide sufficiently reliable results. Given that not all job seekers are followed up through the PPM survey and the small numbers of NEIS participants in each electorate, there is an insufficient number of survey responses to provide statistically reliable post-assistance outcomes results at the electorate level.
The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations does not collect information relating to the status of clients 18 months after NEIS assistance has ended.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads, in writing, on 25 May 2005:

quote.para: What sum was allocated to local government in financial assistance grants during (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004 to the (i) City of Liverpool and (ii) City of Campbelltown.

talker.name: Lloyd, Jim, MP
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads
talker.name: Mr Lloyd

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Each year the Federal Government provides financial assistance grants to Local Government paid through the States under the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1995. The financial assistance grants have two components – general purpose grants and identified local roads grants – and both components are untied in the hands of the receiving council. This means that councils are able to spend the grant (including the local road grant) according to the priorities of their communities.

The Act specifies how the quantum of the grant is determined and how it is distributed between States. Within States, the grant is distributed to councils according to the recommendation of the respective Local Government Grants Commission established by each State as a condition of receiving funding under the Act. Further details are provided in the Report on the Operation of the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1995 (commonly known as the National Report) tabled in Parliament as soon as practicable after 30 June each year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, in writing, on 25 May 2005:

item.para: Has the Minister’s department or any agency in the Minister’s portfolio made any grants for any purpose to the national or state or territory branches of (a) the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, (b) the Australian Industry Group, (c) the National Farmers Federation, (d) the Business Council of Australia, (e) the Motor Traders Association of Australia, (f) Employers First, (g) Australian Business Limited, (h) the National Retailers Association, (i) the Australian Liquor Association, (j) the National Electrical Contractors Association, (k) the State Chamber of Commerce (NSW), and (l) the Housing Industry Association in (i) 2003-2004, (ii) 2004-2005, and (iii) 2005-2006.
What the purpose and amount of each grant and on what date was each grant awarded.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources
talker.name: Mr Ian Macfarlane

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources
Details of grants (and similar payments) made to these organisations by the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources are provided in the table below.
Note: Figures provided are exclusive of GST.

entry.para: Project Title: Australian Industry Innovation Exchange Network (InnovationXchange)

Amount / Date(s) Paid: A grant of $1 million was awarded to the Australian Industry Group for the InnovationXchange initiative. The grant agreement was signed in November 2002 and payments have been made in instalments as follows.

Purpose: The InnovationXchange is an initiative of the Australian Industry Group and its charitable education trust, the Tyree Foundation. The objective of the project is to provide a ‘one stop shop’ for innovation and technology diffusion for Australian industry. The project seeks to help Australian firms, particularly small and medium sized enterprises, improve their: (a) understanding of, and access to new technologies; (b) access to information networks; (c) access to resources promoting a more innovative management culture; and (d) access to resources for staff training in entrepreneurship and innovation.
This grant was awarded under the Innovation Access Program.
Project Title: InnovationXchange Trusted Intermediary Services Pilot

Amount / Date(s) Paid: A grant of $222,500 was awarded to the Australian Industry Group for the InnovationXchange Trusted Intermediary Services Pilot. The grant agreement was signed in June 2004 and payments have been made in instalments as follows.

Purpose: The InnovationXchange Trusted Intermediary Services Pilot (to be known as BRIDGE services) is designed to test the concept of intermediated innovation services with a consortium of small and large organisations in and around the life/health sciences sector.

Sharing between small and large organisations is a notable problem that slows down and often cuts off small firms from critical opportunities. The objective of BRIDGE is to help small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs) overcome the intellectual property barrier when trying to attract strategic partners among other SMEs, large firms and global players. It seeks to achieve this through the use of trusted intermediaries - knowledgeable experts employed by a non-profit organisation such as the InnovationXchange Network, who are able to forge connections between different firms without exposing intellectual property between them until an appropriate win-win opportunity is found.
This grant was awarded under the Innovation Access Program.
Project Title: Australia-Thailand Free Trade Agreement – Industry Visit to Thailand
Amount / Date(s) Paid: An amount of $4,744.36 was paid to Australian Industry Group in November 2003.

Purpose: This payment was for reimbursement of travel and accommodation expenses incurred by the Australian Industry Group representative to participate in the Australia-Thailand FTA Industry visit to Thailand, 25‑29 August 2003.
Amount / Date(s) Paid: A grant of $3,000 was awarded to the Australian Industry Group in June 2004 to facilitate ‘The Great Innovation Debate’.

Purpose: The ‘Great Innovation Debate’ was organised to promote innovation awareness through informed debate and discussion and to provide the audience with an increased understanding of the benefits of innovation. The funding was for promotional activities and organising the debate.
This grant was awarded under the National Innovation Awareness Strategy program.
Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry
Project Title: Australia-Thailand Free Trade Agreement – Industry Visit
Amount / Date(s) Paid: An amount of $5270.85 was paid to the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry in October 2003.

Purpose: This payment was for reimbursement of travel and accommodation expenses incurred by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry representative to participate in the Australia-Thailand FTA Industry visit to Thailand, 25‑29 August 2003.
Project Title: Innovation Package for Regional Areas

Amount / Date(s) Paid: A grant of $100,000 was awarded to Australian Business Limited for a regional innovation package. The grant agreement was signed in November 2002 and payments were made in instalments as follows.
Purpose: The purpose of the grant was to enable support and delivery of a multi faceted innovation package to regional areas.
This grant was awarded under the National Innovation Awareness Strategy program.
Project Title: Skills for Growth - Small to Medium Business Managers

Amount / Date(s) Paid: A grant of $181,568 was awarded to Australian Business Limited for small business support services. The grant agreement was signed in June 2004. The first payment of $145,254 (representing 80% of the total grant) was also paid in June 2004.
Purpose: The purpose of the grant was to assist a customised small business mentoring and support system in the Central Coast region of NSW. This project ends on 30 March 2006.
This grant was awarded under the Small Business Enterprise Culture Program.

Records held indicate that there have been no grants made to these organisations by the other agencies in the Industry, Tourism and Resources portfolio during the period in question.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: Further to the answer to question No. 141 (Hansard, 10 May 2005, page 82), on what date did the Governor‑General start receiving copies of Cabinet Minutes.
Was the supply of Cabinet Minutes to the Governor‑General initiated at the request of His Excellency; if so, when was the request made.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: 11 August 2003.
The Official Secretary requested, on behalf of the then Administrator and the then Governor-General Designate that the minutes be supplied; 27 June 2003.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 30 May 2005:

item.para: In which financial year will monies held in the Future Fund first be disbursed to defray the cost of public service superannuation payments falling due in that year.
In which financial year will capital in the Future Fund (as opposed to Fund earnings) first be disbursed to defray the cost of public service superannuation payments falling due in that year.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The legislation establishing the Future Fund will be introduced into the Parliament later this year. It will include a provision that the Future Fund can only be drawn down when the assets in the Fund are sufficient to offset the unfunded liabilities. The actual level of contributions (to be made from realised surpluses) and the investment performance of the Fund will be key determinants of whether there are sufficient assets to offset the unfunded liabilities. There is no distinction between capital (assets) held in the Fund and earnings on those assets with respect to draw down arrangements.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 31 May 2005:
—The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: This information is contained in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade Annual Reports for those years.

The Department does not collect statistics that relate specifically to staff turnover rates. However, retention rates, as recorded in the annual State of the Service Report, provide a guide to the rate of staff turnover. The retention rates of the Department for the years 1999-2000, 2000-2001, 2001-2002, 2002-2003 and 2003-2004, as recorded in the annual State of the Service Report, were
Figures are not available for the retention rates in 1996-97, 1997-98, 1998-99.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 31 May 2005:
—The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Figures for (a) 1996-97 to (d) 1999-2000 include ITSA which was then a part of the Department.

(2) (a) to (f) The Department’s HRMIS has only been operational since March 2002. Therefore prior data is not available as the previous system is no longer maintained. Information can only be sourced if it was recorded in Annual Reports or other formal publications. Data is available commencing from the 2002-2003 financial year and is provided below.

Note: The Department measures its turnover primarily as employee-initiated separation, consistent with Australian National Audit Office methodology. The employee-initiated separation is calculated as no. of employee-initiated separations in the nominated year ¸ headcount at 30 June of that year x 100.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 31 May 2005:
—The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: FaCS was formed following the October 1998 election. Staffing figures are reported from that year.
¹ Staffing numbers as reported in FaCS Annual Reports 1998-99 to 2003-04. The 2004-05 figures are as at 31 May 2005.
FaCS Staff turnover.¹

¹ The FaCS Staff Turnover rate has been calculated using staff turnover divided by Headcount. It includes all separations from FaCS - resignations, transfers/promotions to other APS agencies, death, invalidity, voluntary redundancy and end of temporary contracts.

² Following the formation of FaCS in 1998, the department continued to use a Centrelink Mainframe system called ADMINS for payroll and reporting purposes until 30 September 1999. FaCS then moved to its own SAP HR Information System. ADMINS is now a legacy system, with dated technology that is no longer capable of producing staffing reports. Consequently the department is unable to provide a response to (2)(c).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 2 June 2005:

item.para: How many parents in the electoral division of Griffith pay more than $57 per day per child for childcare.

In respect of the 2005-2006 budget allocation for 84,300 new outside-of-school-hours care places, 2,500 family day care places and 1,000 in-home care places, how will the distribution of these places be decided.
How will the Minister ensure the allocation process is undertaken transparently and fairly according to areas of greatest need.

Has the Minister considered the effect the commencement of the preparatory year of schooling in 2007 will have on childcare in (a) the electoral division of Griffith and (b) Queensland; if so, what is the policy response to the commencement of the preparatory year of schooling in the electoral division of Griffith and Queensland.
Can the Minister explain why the results of a survey into childcare conducted by the Department of Families and Community Services in 2004 have not been made public.
Can the Minister explain why the Government will not hold a national summit on child care.
Can the Minister explain why the budget makes no provisions for new long day care places when 46,000 children are waiting for long day care places.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: No service in the electorate of Griffith which responded to the 2004 Australian Government Census of Child Care Services survey reported a daily fee of more than $57 per day. (Source: 2004 Australian Government Census of Child Care Services)

On 18 and 25 June 2005 the Department advertised in the press inviting applications for the new outside school hours care places for 2005-06. The distribution of these places will be determined by the Department of Family and Community Services, taking into account the relative needs of different areas.

The Department will take advice from Planning Advisory Committees in every state and territory. Planning Advisory Committees include representatives from the child care sector associations and state and local governments and are chaired by the manager of the state or territory office of the Department.

(4) (a) (b) The Department is working with the Queensland Government to ensure that the transitional effects on child care of the commencement of the preparatory year of schooling in 2007 are anticipated and accommodated. This transition will occur over two years.

item.label: (4) (a)
item.para: (b) The Department is working with the Queensland Government to ensure that the transitional effects on child care of the commencement of the preparatory year of schooling in 2007 are anticipated and accommodated. This transition will occur over two years.
The results of the 2004 Australian Government Census of Child Care Services are publicly available.

The Minister regularly consults her state and territory counterparts through the Community and Disability Services Ministers’ Conference process. Consultative mechanisms already exist to enable the Minister and the Department to discuss issues with the child care sector, including through the Minister’s advisory child care group, the the Child Care Reference Group, which has representatives from the peak child care associations..

There are no limits to the number of places available to long day care centres. Any approved long day care centre can have as many places as it needs provided that it meets state or territory licensing requirements.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 14 June 2005:

item.para: Is the Minister aware of reports that in 1997 two Australians on arriving at their accommodation in Bali, Indonesia, discovered a quantity of marijuana packed into their luggage.

Can he confirm that they sought advice from the Australia Consulate in Bali and they were advised to dispose of the marijuana before it was discovered by the Indonesian authorities; if so, can he provide details of that advice.
Is he aware of other instances where Australians have discovered drugs in their possession after travelling abroad from Australian airports.
What action will he take to ensure Australians travelling abroad are better informed of risks associated with the illicit transport of drugs through Australia’s airports.
Will he authorise the issuing of travel warnings while risks associated with the illicit transport of drugs through Australia’s airports exist; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

As file records from 1997 have since been disposed of (in accordance with archival procedures), my department has no documentary record of this contact. The officer who dealt with this matter recalled advising the informant of three options he could consider: report the matter to the Indonesian police, seek legal advice, or dispose of the marijuana. He recalls not recommending any particular option, but rather advising that it was up to the individual to decide an appropriate course of action.
No.

and (5) My department does not issue travel advice or consular information on matters related to Australian airports. It has published information on the smartraveller website (www.smartraveller.gov.au) about how to minimise the risk of difficulties with drugs overseas and issues related to overseas arrests. The booklet Hints for Australian Travellers, which is issued with every new passport, is being updated to provide similar information.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 15 June 2005:

item.para: Has he read the report titled ‘Thousands of slaves see their chance of freedom slip away’ in The Sydney Morning Herald on 7 March 2005 which reported that “a ceremony during which at least 7,000 men, women and children in Niger in West Africa were to be freed from slavery has been cancelled at the last minute by the Government” and “at least 43,000 people are thought to be slaves”.
Is he able to confirm that despite the ownership of slaves being made illegal in Niger in May 2004 that that law has made little difference to the slave-owners; if not, why not.

Can he confirm that slaves in (a) Chad, (b) Mali, (c) Mauritania, and (d) Niger are used for domestic and farm labour, are routinely beaten, sexually abused and subjected to international trafficking and that babies born into slavery are passed from one owner to another as gifts or dowry; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.
What does the Government propose to do to bring domestic slavery in these countries and the slave trade to international attention.

What assistance will the Government provide to (a) Anti-Slavery International and (b) the United Nations Human Rights Commission to investigate and stop domestic slavery and the international trafficking of slaves and to restore human dignity to those affected by this crime.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: In relation to part (1), the answer is no, I have not read the article in question.
The Government shares concerns about slavery and human rights abuses more generally in Africa, including in the four countries to which the question referred.

Australia has taken action, both bilaterally and in multilateral forums, to help eradicate slavery and other human rights abuses. Australia remains a signatory to four multilateral anti-slavery treaties. I would refer the honourable member to my department’s website at www.dfat.gov.au for further details on these treaties.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 16 June 2005:

item.para: Is the Minister aware of the Senate Community Affairs Committee’s Report on poverty and financial hardship which states that people who cannot access credit, typically low income earners and disadvantaged people, are using payday lenders to get advances on their incomes, often with exorbitant fees and rates of interest and onerous terms and conditions.

What steps has the Minister taken to ensure that amendments in line with Recommendation 35 of the Senate Community Affairs Committee’s Report on poverty and financial hardship are made to the Consumer Credit Code.
What steps has the Minister taken to ensure that the Consumer Credit Code prohibits bills of sale, also known as ‘blackmail securities’, over essential household goods.

What steps has the Minister taken to close existing loopholes in the consumer Credit Code that allow fringe credit services to escape the code’s regulations by registering as pawn brokering or brokering businesses.

Has the Minister’s department assessed the effect of current government policy on the number of low income earners seeking loan agreements from payday lenders; if so, what was the outcome; if not, will the Minister instruct the department to undertake such an assessment.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The Government response to the Senate Community Affairs Committee’s Report on poverty and financial hardship is being prepared by the Department of Family and Community Services in consultation with a number of other Departments.

(2) (3), (4) and (5) The Consumer Credit Code is the responsibility of the states and territories. Changes to the Consumer Credit Code are negotiated by the Uniform Consumer Credit Code Management Committee (UCCCMC), which does not include a Commonwealth representative.

, (4) and (5) The Consumer Credit Code is the responsibility of the states and territories. Changes to the Consumer Credit Code are negotiated by the Uniform Consumer Credit Code Management Committee (UCCCMC), which does not include a Commonwealth representative.
