talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Is he able to confirm reports by Human Rights Watch monitors in the International Herald Tribune that the UN Special Rapporteur on Freedom and Religion, Asma Jahangir, was beaten and stripped in public on 14 May by police, for organizing a mixed-gender marathon.
Is he able to confirm that on the same day Hina Jilani, UN Special Rapporteur on the situation of human rights defenders, was arrested for attending the marathon.
Is he able to say whether Hina Jilani was also beaten by police while being detained.
Is he able to confirm the report that these two beatings were perpetrated under orders from senior Pakistani police officers.
Did Australia’s mission in Islamabad make any representations about this incident to the Pakistani Government; if so, what was the Pakistani Government’s response; if not, why not.
Is he able to say whether the Prime Minister raised Pakistan’s human rights record during President Musharraf’s visit to Australia.
Did he raise human rights in Pakistan with President Musharraf; if so, what was the President’s response; if not, why not.
Will the bilateral cooperation under the Australia-Pakistan MOU on counter-terrorism involve work with the Pakistani military and police.
What measures is he taking to ensure that the transfer of counter-terrorism training and expertise will not be used by Pakistani security agencies in human rights abuses against the Pakistani people.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: I am informed that Asma Jahangir was arrested by Pakistani security service personnel on 14 May in Lahore in connection with her attendance at a mixed-gender marathon in that city. I understand that she was detained for several hours, was not charged with any offence and was subsequently released.

I am informed that Hina Jilani was arrested for attending the same mixed-gender marathon in Lahore. I understand that she was detained for several hours, was not charged with any offence and was subsequently released.
No.
No.
The mission regularly makes representations to the Government of Pakistan, including on human rights matters.
I am unable to comment on the substance of the Prime Minister’s discussion with President Musharraf.
The Australian Government has made clear to the Government of Pakistan on numerous occasions the importance it attaches to the promotion and protection of human rights.

The memorandum of understanding on Counter-Terrorism with Pakistan will facilitate practical cooperation between the two countries in areas such as law enforcement, intelligence, security and border control.

The Australian Government has made clear to the Government of Pakistan on numerous occasions the importance it attaches to the promotion and protection of human rights. The memorandum of understanding provides that cooperation pursuant to the memorandum be in conformity with the relevant provisions of national and international law, including international standards of human rights. The negotiation of memorandums of understanding on counter-terrorism should also be seen in the context of the Australian Government’s commitment to combating the very great threat to human rights that terrorism poses.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Can he confirm that the Mugabe regime in Zimbabwe, under the guise of “Operation Restore Order,” has demolished the homes and businesses of more than 200,000 people in Harare and other cities, areas which voted against the ZANU-PF party at the recent elections.
Can he confirm that non-government organisations have been prevented from assisting those evicted from their homes.

Can he confirm that the majority of the people of Zimbabwe are continuing to suffer severe food shortages and health problems, including an out-of-control HIV/AIDS epidemic, as a result of the destructive policies and actions of the Mugabe regime.
What steps has he taken to convey to the Zimbabwe government Australia’s condemnation of these actions.
What steps has he taken to raise Australia’s opposition to the policies of Zimbabwe in international forums.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: According to initial United Nations’ estimates, more than 200,000 people in Zimbabwe had their homes demolished under Operations Restore Order and Murambatsvina (drive out rubbish). In a later estimate, the International Organisation for Migration put the number at approximately 370,000. The majority of demolitions have occurred in the capital, Harare, and other urban areas, although there are reports of some demolitions occurring in rural areas. As a general rule, Zimbabweans who live in urban areas have shown a greater tendency than rural Zimbabweans to vote for the main opposition party, rather than the governing Zanu-PF party.

Media reports in late May 2005 and in early June indicated that in some areas non-government organisations (NGOs) were being prevented by the Zimbabwean police from assisting those evicted from their homes by the campaign. It was reported that police were obstructing distribution of aid and confiscating relief items in some areas. Further, in late May 2005, President Mugabe publicly condemned and warned NGOs against providing assistance to the victims. In early June, the Government of Zimbabwe stated that all humanitarian aid must be channelled through government structures or else aid delivery would be viewed as “resistance” or “obstruction”. In mid-June 2005, under mounting international pressure, the Government of Zimbabwe gave permission for local and international non-government organisations to provide relief to the victims of the campaign. Currently multilateral agencies and non-government organisations are coordinating their aid responses with government departments, churches and other charitable groups.
Yes.

Australia continues to take a strong stand against the human rights abuses and undemocratic practices of the Zimbabwe Government and has strongly condemned its actions under Operations Restore Order and Murambatsvina.

My media release of 14 June condemned the massive destruction of homes and livelihoods under Operation Restore Order and called upon the Zimbabwe Government to immediately halt the operation and provide food and shelter to those in need. I also announced the removal of transit-without-visa privileges for Zimbabwean passport holders, an additional measure to reinforce our existing smart sanctions against the Zimbabwe Government.

On 24 June, Mr Billson called on the Government of Zimbabwe to halt the operation and allow all willing organisations to provide assistance to those in need. He also announced the provision of emergency relief aid for the victims of Operation Restore Order, to be delivered through the International Organisation for Migration and CARE Zimbabwe.

On 2 July, I met with New Zealand Foreign Minister Goff to discuss, among other things, the situation in Zimbabwe. We jointly announced a range of actions designed to increase international pressure on the Mugabe regime. Those measures are discussed in more detail below.

The Government has consistently raised its serious concerns over human rights abuses in Zimbabwe in international forums, including the UN Commission on Human Rights. We have made these concerns clear in our Item 9 country statements before the Commission (available on the DFAT website) and we have been strongly supportive in past years of EU efforts to have the Commission adopt a resolution condemning human rights abuses in Zimbabwe.
The Government has also sought to raise Australia’s opposition to the current activities of the Mugabe regime in other international forums.

In the lead up to the African Union Summit in Libya, 4 to 5 July, representations were made to countries in the Southern African Development Community (SADC) urging that a statement be made at that summit calling on the Government of Zimbabwe to halt these activities, provide adequate food and shelter to those who have lost their homes and allow NGOs to provide assistance to those in need without hindrance. Unfortunately, those efforts appear to have been unsuccessful in generating such a statement, though they did provide an opportunity for Australia to reiterate its concerns with Zimbabwe’s neighbours in southern Africa.

On 2 July, I jointly announced with my New Zealand counterpart, Mr Phil Goff, a range of additional actions in international forums that our Governments will pursue in order to increase international pressure on the Mugabe Government. These include:
Representations to the International Cricket Council, urging it to allow teams to not proceed with tours to Zimbabwe without penalty while serious human rights abuses are occurring;
exploration with like-minded countries of a total sporting ban on all Zimbabwean representative teams;
representations to G8 members, urging them to address the Zimbabwe issue at its 6 to 8 July meeting in Scotland;
representations to the UN Commissioner on Human Rights and members of the Security Council urging investigation of past and present human rights abuses in Zimbabwe;
support for continuing moves to expel Zimbabwe from the International Monetary Fund;
a proposal to the UN Security Council that the situation in Zimbabwe be referred to the International Criminal Court; and
representations to Zimbabwe’s southern African neighbours, urging them to place diplomatic pressure on Zimbabwe to conform with international human rights standards.

Joint representations to the International Cricket Council and to G8 member countries have already been made. The Gleneagles G8 Chairman’s Summary contained strong criticism of the current situation in Zimbabwe. Action on other proposed measures is being advanced.

subdebateinfo.title: International Code of Conduct Against Ballistic Missile Proliferation

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

quote.para: In respect of the International Code of Conduct against Ballistic Missile Proliferation (otherwise known as the Hague Code of Conduct), what diplomatic efforts and specific representations has the Australian Government made to encourage (a) India, (b) Pakistan, (c) Iran, (d) Syria, (e) Israel, (f) Indonesia, (g) the People’s Republic of China, and (h) the Democratic People’s Republic of North Korea, to subscribe to the Code of Conduct.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Australia has encouraged various countries – including China, Pakistan, Iran, India and Indonesia – to subscribe to the Hague Code of Conduct (HCOC) in the course of bilateral discussions on non-proliferation issues. Australia also actively supports the HCOC chair in its outreach to non-subscribing States.

subdebateinfo.title: International Code of Conduct Against Ballistic Missile Proliferation

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: In respect of each annual declaration concerning ballistic missile programs made by (a) the United States; (b) the Russian Federation, (c) France, (d) the United Kingdom, and (e) Japan, under the provisions of paragraph 4(a)(i) of the International Code of Conduct against Ballistic Missile Proliferation (otherwise known as the Hague Code of Conduct), what were the numbers and generic classes of ballistic missiles launched during each year.

In respect of each annual declaration concerning expendable Space Launch Vehicle programs made by (a) the United States; (b) the Russian Federation, (c) France, (d) the United Kingdom, and (e) Japan, under the provisions of paragraph 4(a)(ii) of the Hague Code of Conduct, what were the numbers and generic classes of Space Launch Vehicles launched during each year.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Hague Code of Conduct (HCOC) subscribing States have mixed practice in classifying their annual declarations concerning ballistic missile programs and space launch vehicle programs. As an HCOC subscribing State, Australia has received these documents on a confidential basis. We are not therefore in a position to release the information requested.

subdebateinfo.title: International Code of Conduct Against Ballistic Missile Proliferation

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: In respect of each pre-launch notification made by (a) the United States; (b) the Russian Federation, (c) France, (d) the United Kingdom, and (e) Japan, under the provisions of paragraph 4(a)(iii) of the International Code of Conduct against Ballistic Missile Proliferation (otherwise known as the Hague Code of Conduct): what was the (i) date of notification, (ii) generic class of ballistic missile or Space Launch Vehicle, (iii) planned launch notification window, (iv) launch area and planned direction of launch.

Is the Australian Government aware of any ballistic missile or Space Launch Vehicle launches by States subscribing to the Hague Code of Conduct that were not the subject of a pre-launch notification in accordance with paragraph 4(a)(iii) of the Code; if so, what was the (a) responsible State, (b) date of launch, (c) generic class of ballistic missile or Space Launch Vehicle, and (d) launch area, for each known launch.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Hague Code of Conduct (HCOC) subscribing States have mixed practice in classifying their pre-launch notifications. As an HCOC subscribing State, Australia has received these documents on a confidential basis. We are not therefore in a position to release the information requested.
Australia is not in a position to release information on ballistic or space launch vehicle launches gained from sensitive sources.

subdebateinfo.title: Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Meeting: Funding

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Which departments will receive funding for the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meeting in 2007.
What is the breakdown of the allocation of the department’s APEC funding.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The following departments/agencies will receive funding for Australia’s hosting of the APEC meetings in 2007:

entry.para: Attorney-General’s Department – Protective Security Coordination Centre
Department of the Prime Minister & Cabinet Taskforce
Department of Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs

item.para: This information can be found in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade’s Portfolio Budget Statements 2005-06 on pages 25 and 38.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: With which countries has Australia reached agreement to have air security officers on certain flights from Australia.
Do the agreements involve reciprocal arrangements permitting other countries to have air security officers on certain international flights into Australia.
Has the Government provided legal expertise and other assistance to countries to develop their own framework for air security officers.
How long has the Australian government been in discussion with these countries on arrangements for air security officers.
How does Australia address the jurisdictional question of the laws governing air security officers in foreign air space.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Singapore and the United States.
Yes.
No. However, legal and technical issues relating to the deployment of ASOs have been raised during the course of bilateral discussions.

The period of time during which ASO-related discussions have taken place varies from country to country. Discussions with Indonesia commenced in late 2002 and with Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines in mid-2004.

Jurisdictional issues governing air security officers in foreign air space are covered by the UN Convention on Offences and Certain other Acts Committed on Board Aircraft (the Tokyo Convention), the Civil Aviation Act 1988 and Regulations, and the Aviation Transport Security Act 2004 and Regulations. The Tokyo Convention allows a State in which an aircraft is registered to exercise jurisdiction over acts committed on board that aircraft. Australia exercises jurisdiction over Australian registered aircraft through the Civil Aviation Act. The Aviation Transport Security Regulations 2005 allow ASOs, while on duty, to enter sterile areas in airports and to carry weapons and prohibited items on aircraft.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Is the employment of locally engaged staff in (a) Bangkok, (b) Jakarta, (c) Phnom Penh, (d) Rangoon, (e) Hanoi, and (f) Vientiane in accordance with (i) local labour laws or Australian labour laws.
Which laws apply where there is a difference between the local and Australian labour laws.
Do employment conditions for locally engaged staff in (a) Bangkok, (b) Jakarta, (c) Phnom Penh, (d) Rangoon, (e) Hanoi, and (f) Vientiane take account of recent changes to local labour laws.

Do missions in (a) Bangkok, (b) Jakarta, (c) Manila, (d) Phnom Penh, and (e) Vientiane offer conditions to locally engaged staff above and beyond those provided by local labour laws; if so, which particular conditions.
Do missions in (a) Bangkok, (b) Jakarta, (c) Manila, (d) Rangoon, (e) Hanoi, (f) Phnom Penh, and (g) Vientiane seek advice from local lawyers on the employment of locally engaged staff.
How many days recreation leave are offered to locally engaged staff at the mission in (a) Bangkok, (b) Jakarta, (c) Manila, (d) Rangoon, (e) Hanoi, (f) Phnom Penh, and (g) Vientiane.
Are locally engaged staff offered overtime payments at these missions; if so, for the last six months, (a) how many locally engaged staff have been paid overtime and what sum was paid for overtime.

What insurance or workers compensation arrangements are in place for locally engaged staff at the mission in (a) Bangkok, (b) Jakarta, (c) Manila, (d) Rangoon, (e) Hanoi, (f) Phnom Penh, and (g) Vientiane.

Do locally engaged staff members at the mission in (a) Bangkok, (b) Jakarta, (c) Manila, (d) Rangoon, (e) Hanoi, (f) Phnom Penh, and (g) Vientiane have the right to refuse to travel to a dangerous location or work under dangerous conditions; if not, why not.

How often are locally engaged staff salary rates at the mission in (a) Bangkok, (b) Jakarta, (c) Manila, (d) Rangoon, (e) Hanoi, (f) Phnom Penh, and (g) Vientiane reviewed to keep in step with inflation rates in these countries.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Locally Engaged Staff (LES) are employed under the provisions of local law in all posts. The principle observed is that LES are offered salaries and conditions of service that are competitive in the labour market of the host country, and which either meet or exceed the requirements of local labour laws.

Posts are required to ensure that LES employment conforms fully to local legal requirements at a minimum. In addition, posts are required to ensure that LES employment practices adhere to Australian Public Service (APS) Values and uphold the principles of workplace diversity and anti-discrimination.
All posts are required to ensure that their arrangements for the employment of LES are updated as necessary when changes in relevant local laws occur.

As indicated in (1) and (2) above, posts may apply conditions of service to LES which exceed the requirements of local law. To provide details of which conditions are above and beyond those provided by local laws in the posts mentioned would entail an unreasonable diversion of resources.
All posts are required to be in regular contact with local labour lawyers on questions relating to the employment of LES.
LES recreation leave entitlements at the posts mentioned are as follows:
Jakarta: 15 days per annum
Bangkok: 15 days per annum, 20 days for staff with 10 or more years service
Manila: 15 days per annum. Staff employed on or before 1 May 2002 are entitled to 20 days per annum after 10 years continuous service

Phnom Penh: 18 days per annum. Staff who have been continuously employed for 3 years receive an additional day of recreation leave on 1 January immediately following completion of 3 years service. For every additional three years of continuous service, an additional day may be accrued.
Vientiane: 20 days per annum
Hanoi: 20 days per annum
Rangoon: 20 days per annum, 25 days for permanent staff with 15 or more years service. 16 days per annum for fixed-term contract staff.

LES at all posts listed in the question are paid overtime where officially required to work beyond normal hours. In many posts LES may elect to take time off in lieu of payment for overtime, or a mixture of both. To provide details of overtime paid in the last six months would entail an unreasonable diversion of resources.

Compensation arrangements for locally engaged staff in all overseas missions are in accordance with section 117 of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (the “SRC Act”). As stipulated by section 117 of the SRC Act, benefits are provided for persons in the event of their death or incapacity due to an injury or disease occurring in circumstances connected with their employment in accordance with an applicable local workers’ compensation scheme. Where no local workers’ compensation scheme applies locally engaged staff are paid in accordance with the provisions of the SRC Act.

DFAT takes seriously its duty of care under the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1991 and obligations to take all reasonable practicable steps to protect the health and safety of employees at work, including through cooperative consultative relationships with locally engaged employees on health and safety issues. Any concerns raised by LES of a health and safety nature, including travel in dangerous locations, would be considered accordingly.

As a good employer, DFAT is committed to providing salary increases for LES from time to time, in line with movements in local market salaries in the host country, and in accordance with the capacity of DFAT and other agencies to pay. Posts are responsible for monitoring the employment market in whatever way is appropriate to local circumstances. Inflation would normally be taken into account as part of this monitoring process.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Do departmental officials based in Australian missions in (a) Rangoon, (b) Bangkok, (c) Phnom Penh, (d) Vientiane, and (e) Hanoi engage in political level discussions with host governments on people trafficking.

How often have departmental officials in the missions in (a) Rangoon, (b) Bangkok, (c) Phnom Penh, (d) Vientiane, and (e) Hanoi raised people trafficking with government officials in (i) 1996, (ii) 1997, (iii) 1998, (iv) 1999, (v) 2000, (vi) 2001, (vii) 2002, (viii) 2003, and (viii) 2004.
How many victims of people trafficking have been returned from Australia to these countries in the last year.
What was the involvement of missions in (a) Rangoon, (b) Bangkok, (c) Phnom Penh, (d) Vientiane, and (e) Hanoi in the return of victims of people trafficking
Are reintegration and counselling services provided by Australian authorities or by the host government and who funds this assistance.
How many of the victims of people trafficking from Australia have assisted Australian police in the investigation of the perpetrators of people trafficking.
How many of the victims of people trafficking have acted as witnesses in the prosecution of perpetrators of people trafficking.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes, as required.

Departmental officials and officials from other Government agencies including AusAID, the AFP and DIMIA raise people trafficking with officials in our region, including in the context of the Bali Process on People Smuggling, Trafficking in Persons and Related Transnational Crime, as required. Further breakdown of representations since 1996 by the nominated posts would involve a significant diversion of resources and, in the circumstances, I do not consider the additional work can be justified.

The return of victims of trafficking falls under the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Senator the Hon Amanda Vanstone, and the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator the Hon Chris Ellison.

The return of victims of trafficking falls under the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Senator the Hon Amanda Vanstone, and the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator the Hon Chris Ellison.

AusAID funds several projects that address reintegration and counselling services for victims of trafficking. For example, AusAID provides funding (currently totalling almost $5.4 million) towards the International Organization for Migration’s (IOM) Return and Reintegration of Trafficked Women and Children in the Mekong Region.
AusAID is also in the process of finalising a $500,000 Return and Reintegration project for Thai victims of trafficking returning from Australia, also delivered through the IOM.

People trafficking investigations fall under the portfolio responsibilities of the Attorney-General, the Hon Philip Ruddock, MP and the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator the Hon Chris Ellison.
People trafficking prosecutions fall under the portfolio responsibilities of the Attorney-General, the Hon Philip Ruddock, MP and the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator the Hon Chris Ellison.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Which missions had their security upgraded in the 2004-2005 financial year.
Which missions will receive the additional funding announced by him in May 2005.
How many security incidents or breaches of security have occurred at the missions identified parts (1) and (2) in 2004 and 2005 and what was the nature of these incidents and breaches.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: In the financial year 2004-2005, 83 overseas missions managed by DFAT and 12 overseas offices managed by AUSTRADE received funds or had works undertaken to upgrade security.
The additional funding announced in May 2005 will be expended at 84 DFAT managed missions and 39 AUSTRADE managed offices.

Of the missions and offices identified in parts (1) and (2), 71 DFAT managed missions and 5 AUSTRADE managed offices have experienced either security incidents or a breach of security. The security incidents cover a wide spectrum from criminal activity, threats against missions to breaches resulting from staff not fully following correct procedures. Due to national security considerations it is not appropriate to provide further details.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Does his department have plans to forge links between the Bali Process on People Smuggling, People Trafficking and Transnational Crime (a process initiated by the Australian and Indonesian Governments in 2002) and the Bali Process on Counter-terrorism (a process initiated by the Australian and Indonesian Governments in 2004); if not, why not; if so, are there plans to link the two processes.
Does his department plan to hold future Ministerial meetings on either process; if not, why not.
How many workshops or activities were held under each process in 2004-2005 and which issues did these workshops cover.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Given the substantial differences between the two processes there are no plans to link them. Officials consult to avoid duplication between the processes.

There are no plans to hold a future Ministerial meeting for the Bali Process on People Smuggling, Trafficking in Persons and Related Transnational Crime, although the option of doing so has been kept under review by myself and my Indonesian counterpart, Dr Hassan Wirajuda, as the process’ Co-Chairs. Process objectives are being taken forward through a programme of practical capacity-building activities.

There are no plans to hold a future Ministerial meeting for the Bali Counter-Terrorism Process. At the February 2004 Bali Ministerial Meeting on Counter-Terrorism, Ministers agreed to the establishment of the Legal Issues Working Group and the Law Enforcement Working Group, which are progressing the recommendations made by Ministers. The working groups will report to Ministers on their efforts to implement the recommendations.
The activities held under the auspices of the Bali process on People Smuggling, Trafficking in Persons and Related Transnational Crime in calendar years 2004 and 2005 are as follows:
Identity management: Challenges and Opportunities for Cooperation workshop (Bangkok THAILAND, 17-19 March 2004).
Reconciling Legitimate State Interest to Control Immigration with Refugee Protection workshop (Nadi FIJI, 27-19 April 2004).
Bali process Steering Group Meeting (Wellington NEW ZEALAND, 4 May 2004).
Bali-Budapest Working Group on Return workshop (Perth AUSTRALIA, 13-14 May 2004).
Inaugural People Smuggling Regional Targeting workshop (Bangkok THAILAND, 24-25 May 2004).
Bali process Senior Officials’ Meeting (Brisbane AUSTRALIA, 7-8 June 2004).
Best Practices in Operational Cooperation workshop (Macau SAR CHINA, 13-15 September 2004).
Protection of Victims of International Trafficking and Public Awareness workshop (Seoul REPUBLIC OF KOREA, 11-12 November 2004).
Bali process Steering Group Meeting (Bali INDONESIA, 8 December 2004).
Protection, Return and Reintegration of the Victims of Human Trafficking workshop (Bali INDONESIA, 9-10 December 2004).
Multi Jurisdictional People Smuggling Targeting Meeting (Colombo, SRI LANKA, 15-17 December 2004).
Enabling Electronic Exchange of Lost & Stolen Travel Document Information workshop (Bangkok THAILAND, 20-22 April 2005).
Developing a Co-ordinated Inter-Agency National Action Plan to Eradicate Trafficking in Persons workshop (Tokyo JAPAN, 27-28 June 2005).
The activities held under the auspices of the Bali Counter-Terrorism Process in calendar years 2004 and 2005 are as follows:
Bali Regional Ministerial Meeting on Counter-Terrorism (Bali, INDONESIA, 4-5 February 2004)
Legal Issues Working Group meeting (Canberra, AUSTRALIA, 4-5 August 2004)
Law Enforcement Working Group meeting (Bali, INDONESIA, 12-13 August 2004)
First workshop of the Criminalisation stream of the Legal Issues Working Group (Tokyo, JAPAN, 1-3 December 2004)
First workshop of the International Legal Cooperation stream of the Legal Issues Working Group (Bangkok, THAILAND, 17-19 January 2005)
Second workshop of the International Legal Cooperation stream of the Legal Issues Working Group (Phuket, THAILAND, 27-29 June 2005).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: How often are Australian missions audited (a) internally within the mission and (b) by a Canberra-based audit team.
Which missions were audited in the 2004-2005 and when was the last time these missions were audited.
What were the findings of the 2004-2005 audits and did the audits take into account miscellaneous or suspense accounts.
What steps does the department take to ensure that missions comply with the auditors recommendations.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Australian missions are audited (a) internally within the mission approximately every three years and (b) by a Canberra-based audit team approximately every five years.
The following missions were audited by a Canberra-based audit team in 2004-05 (date of previous audit provided in parentheses following the post name):
Tarawa (2000-01)
Copenhagen (2002-03)
Ho Chi Minh City (2001-02)
The Hague (1998-99)
Brussels (1998-99)
Nairobi (2001-02)
Bangkok (1999-00)
Manila (1999-00)
Harare (2002-03)
Pretoria (2002-03)
Port Louis (2002-03)
Colombo (2001-02)
In addition, a range of posts conducted internal self-audits during the year.
A number of administrative and management findings were made in the course of 2004-05. All official bank accounts held at an overseas mission are examined as part of an audit.

The department ensures that missions comply with the auditors’ recommendations by including a follow-up phase in the process where the auditors are assured that the recommendations have been addressed.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: When was the last time the Embassy in Buenos Aires was audited by a Canberra-based audit team or otherwise audited externally.
How often are the accounts of the Embassy in Buenos Aires reviewed.
Has the Embassy consistently met its budget for the last financial year.
What changes are implemented to the financial structure if budgets are not met.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Each account payment is approved by the Finance Manager (the A-based Senior Administrative Officer) or, in her absence, the person delegated to carry out this function. The Finance Manager also reviews, on a weekly basis, the budgetary position of the Embassy.
Yes.

If the budget of an overseas post is projected to be under-spent, funds are generally returned to the centre for reallocation to other departmental priorities. If the budget of an overseas post is projected to be over-spent, posts generally request additional funding from the centre or request approval to overspend.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Were new accounting standards recently introduced at the High Commission in London; if so, when.
How do the accounting standards used by the High Commission in London differ from the accounting standards employed throughout the Department.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: No.
They do not differ.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

quote.para: Are Australian missions overseas required to comply with the Department of Finance and Administration’s procurement guidelines; If so what steps does the Department take to ensure that the procurement guidelines are met; If not, do individual missions have their own procurement guidelines, and if they do, what are the guidelines.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Yes, they are required to comply. The Department has a Procurement Manual to guide posts through their procurement responsibilities. The mandatory Financial Management training course includes a section on the procurement guidelines. A Contract Management and Policy Unit is available to posts to provide advice.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: When were the accounts of the High Commission in Nairobi last audited.
When was representational expenditure in High Commission in Nairobi last audited.
Was any action taken or recommendations made as a result of the audit.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Recommendations were made as a result of the audit and action has been taken to implement these.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

quote.para: In respect of official events held at Australian missions, do all acquittals for all functions require a full guest list of those who attended the event.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Staff are required to account for the use of official representation funds with supporting documentation. In the case of functions, guest lists are required, however, it is recognised that detailed lists for some functions are not possible, especially those open to the public or large business or community groups.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: How many official vehicles does the Permanent Mission to the United Nations in New York own or lease (including Head of Mission and Deputy Head of Mission vehicles).
What are the guidelines for the use of official vehicles at the Permanent Mission to the United Nations in New York.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Two.
Use of official vehicles at the Permanent Mission to the United Nations in New York is governed by the department’s guidelines on the use of official vehicles at overseas missions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Does the department have guidelines for the use of Government cars by spouses of diplomatic officers.
For what purpose are spouses entitled to use Government cars.
Do auditors assess the use of official vehicles.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

Under the Executive Vehicle Scheme, SES officers in Australia and at posts have an entitlement to a Government car for both official and private use, and they may authorise their spouses to use the car for personal use subject to the operational requirements of the post. In addition, at overseas posts spouses may use Government cars for transportation to any official engagements, functions or activities related to the work of the Mission or representing Australia in the country of accreditation; transportation to and from the points of arrival in the city of posting at any time, including for periods of leave; and other official uses which would apply to any Mission pool vehicle including reasonable use for personal needs in posts where security or related problems preclude self-drive arrangements.
Yes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Did he issue a media release on 31 May 2005 to mark the second anniversary of Aung San Suu Kyi’s detention; if not why not.
Did he use the occasion on 31 May 2005 to condemn the reported extension of Aung San Suu Kyi’s detention until September 2005; if not why not.
Has the Australian Embassy in Rangoon made any representations to the Burmese junta about the continued detention of Aung San Suu Kyi since 31 May 2004; if so, when.
Did Australia make any representations in the context of any ASEAN meetings in which it participated in 2005 regarding the detention of Aung San Suu Kyi.
When was the policy of constructive engagement with the ruling State Peace and Democracy Council (SPDC) last reviewed.
On what basis did the Government make the decision to continue its policy of constructive engagement.
Does Australia have a “smart sanctions” regime imposed on Burma; if so, can the Minister provide an overview of those sanctions.
Are Burmese passport holders, including diplomatic passport holders, able to transit Australian airports without a visa.

Are there any restrictions on SPDC travel to Australia; if not, (a) has consideration been given to imposing these restriction and (b) on what basis did the Government decide against imposing these restrictions.
Has consideration been given to restricting international financial transactions of SPDC funds; if not, why not.
Is the department aware of any SPDC assets held in Australia; if so, has consideration been given to freezing those assets and, if it has not, why not.

Do the US and European restrictions on financial transfers into Rangoon apply to the Australia Embassy in Rangoon; if so, (a) how does it receive funds from Australia and (b) what impact have these restrictions had on its financial operations.
Has the department made representations or had any discussions about Burma taking up the ASEAN chair in 2006; if so, when and to whom.
Would Australia be represented at ASEAN meetings in 2006 hosted by Burma; if so, at what level would Australia be represented.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: to (4) Australia makes regular representations about human rights, including the detention of Aung San Suu Kyi and other political prisoners. This included representations on 16, 17 and 18 May and 6 June in Rangoon.
and (6) This is not Australia’s policy.
to (11) Australia does not permit arms sales to Burma and restricts travel to Australia by senior members of the Burmese regime.
Restrictions affect all financial transfers into Rangoon. We have made arrangements for bank transfers outside Burma. The Embassy continues to function.
and (14) ASEAN arrangements are a matter for its members.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: How does the Department record its consular case load.
Has the Department recorded an increase in the number of consular cases that Australian Embassies deal with.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Consular staff use the Consular Management Information System (CMIS) database to record, manage and archive information on consular cases.
Yes. Consular statistics are published annually in the Department’s Annual Report.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: What training does the Department provide to locally engaged staff on the commencement of their employment.
Does the Department provide training for the locally-engaged guards and counter staff at Australian missions; if so, what type of training.
What training does the department offer to its locally-engaged staff to acquaint them with Australian culture and society so that they will be able to represent Australia.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: and (3) Australian missions are responsible for providing locally engaged and contract staff with appropriate training to enable them to perform the duties of the positions for which they have been recruited. This principle applies to guards and counter staff and extends to acquainting locally engaged and contract staff with Australian culture and society. In addition, the department brings a number of its locally engaged staff to Australia each year for a Leadership and Management Program to strengthen their skills, and their knowledge and understanding of Australia.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Does the department encourage its staff to seek further professional development and what policies does it have to encourage staff to undertake further study or professional development.
How many officers are currently undertaking further study in Department and how many of these officers are studying at their own expense.

What incentives are given to officers to work in difficult or remote missions and how does the department ensure that these positions are filled with due regard to the importance of fostering talent and individual needs.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes. The department has a comprehensive Training and Development Strategy.
Departmental staff studying at their own expense are not required to disclose this. I am unable to say, therefore, how many staff in total currently are undertaking further study.

The department’s overseas conditions of service package is intended to allow staff and their families to maintain a similar quality of life to that available in Australia. Staff working in difficult or remote localities receive a hardship allowance in addition to DFAT’s standard overseas conditions of service package and, depending on the locality, may have access to additional recreation leave.

Decisions on non-HOM postings are made following recommendations by a Posting Advisory Committee which is required to take into account relevant operational requirements, including the suitability of staff, the human resource development needs of the department, EEO requirements, staff preferences and career development needs and personal considerations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Is the department working towards launching a campaign for a United Nations Security Council seat.
Why did he abandon his plan to launch a campaign for a Security Council seat for Australia in 2002.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: No.
The Government takes decisions on candidacies bearing in mind the full range of considerations at the time.

subdebateinfo.title: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Will he outline the areas of continuing concern for the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination in its assessment of Australia.
How has Australia responded to the concluding observations of the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination since they were released in March 2005.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Comments by the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination concerning Australia are publicly available in the Committee’s Concluding Observations concerning Australia’s thirteenth and fourteenth periodic reports to the Committee and Australia’s appearance before the Committee on 1-2 March 2005. The Concluding Observations are available on the web site of the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) in the documents covering the Committee’s 66th session at www.ohchr.org/english/bodies/cerd/cerds66.htm.

In its Concluding Observations, the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination has requested specific information within one year concerning the Committee’s recommendations in paragraphs 10, 11, 16 and 17 of the Concluding Observations. The Government intends to respond to the Committee’s request within that timeframe.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

quote.para: Does he support Permanent Seats on the UN Security Council for (a) Japan, (b) Brazil, (c) Germany, (d) Indonesia, and (e) India.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: I have mentioned Japan, Brazil, India and Indonesia as potential new permanent members of an expanded Security Council. Australia’s position on specific proposals for Security Council expansion will depend on the final text of UN resolutions on this issue and on which candidates nominate for membership.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

quote.para: Has the department discussed the matter of reform of the UN Security Council with Chinese officials; if so, what were China’s views.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: It would not be appropriate to divulge views on UN Security Council reform expressed in confidential discussions with foreign governments.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: How do Australia’s missions in (a) Geneva, (b) Vienna, and (c) New York select which UN meetings Australia will attend.
Does the department seek advice on the level of representation from other countries before deciding on Australia’s representation at a given meeting.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: In most instances Australia’s missions in Geneva, Vienna and New York attend UN meetings on the basis of guidance provided by Ministers, my department or, as appropriate, other departments and agencies.
The level of Australian representation at UN meetings is determined by Australian national interests and priorities.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Has the Australian Embassy in Egypt assisted Australian companies with operations or interests in Syria; if so, which companies and what is the dollar value of their interest or operations.
Are there any Australian companies with oil concessions in Syria; if so, which companies.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Austrade has supported 13 Australian companies that have expressed interest in the Syrian market in the last financial year (2004/05). To date, none of these companies have reported any commercial success in the Syrian market.
We have no knowledge of Australian companies participating in or holding oil concessions in Syria.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Did his department prepare legal advice on the constitutionality under Papua New Guinea (PNG) law of the Joint Agreement between Australia and PNG; if so, what was the advice.
Did he seek a legal assessment of the constitutionality under PNG law of the Joint Agreement between Australia and PNG from the PNG Government; if so, what was the advice.
What, if any, provisions were there in the agreement to respond to situation of legal immunity not being accorded to the Australian Federal Police (AFP).

Was his department advised by the PNG Government that the Agreement would be subject to judicial review; if so, when was the department advised and was it advised before the AFP and other government officials were sent to PNG.
What avenues is his department exploring to overcome the legal problems raised by the unanimous ruling of the PNG Supreme Court.
How long will it take for his department to address the legal issues in discussion with the PNG Government.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Consistent with the practice of successive Governments, information is not given on whether legal advice has been prepared or on the content of any advice.

Constitutional issues were discussed in the course of meetings between Australian and PNG officials at various stages of the discussions on the ECP Treaty and its implementation. On 4 June 2004, it was made clear by PNG Ministers, including publicly, that PNG had worked through any constitutional concerns they may have had, and no longer had any concerns.

Article 8 of the ECP Treaty establishes a system of concurrent criminal jurisdiction over ECP personnel and their dependants. If the PNG Government failed to comply with its obligations under the ECP Treaty, the dispute would be resolved by consultation and negotiation between the Australian and PNG governments, in accordance with Article 20 of the Treaty.

No. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was not advised by the PNG Government that the ECP Treaty would be subject to judicial review. On 9 August 2004, the PNG Attorney-General, Francis Damem, advised us that his Department had been served with a Supreme Court reference challenging the constitutional validity of the ECP Act. A number of Australian officials were in PNG before this date.
Australian and PNG officials are considering options to address the issues raised by the Supreme Court’s ruling. It would not be appropriate to comment on specific proposals at this stage.
The issues are complex and will take time to work through. It is not possible to predict how long these discussions with PNG officials will continue.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: What is the Government’s policy on the human rights situation in Uganda.
Has he released any statements on human rights in Northern Uganda, and in particular, the issue of child soldiers in that region; if so, what was stated.
Does Uganda receive any humanitarian aid from the Australian Government; if so, what sum and for what purposes.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The Australian Government strongly supports international efforts to end the conflict in northern Uganda and reduce the suffering of the people of that region. Australia has consistently supported investigations by the International Criminal Court of senior Lord’s Resistance Army (LRA) leaders suspected of committing crimes against humanity.

Statements and speeches made by myself, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade, Mr Vaile, and the Parliamentary Secretary for Foreign Affairs, Mr Billson are available on the department’s website at www.dfat.gov.au
In 2004, Australia provided $550,000 to UNICEF to assist in improving health and education services for 300,000 children living in the affected districts.
On 1 July, I announced that we would provide a further $2 million for food assistance to Internally Displaced Persons in camps in northern Uganda, to be delivered through the World Food Program.
